2.	O

In	O
Aircore	O
(	O
AC	O
)	O
drilling	O
,	O
composite	O
4	O
metre	O
samples	O
were	O
collected	O
with	O
smaller	O
composites	O
if	O
end	O
of	O
hole	O
reached	O
within	O
a	O
4m	O
interval.	O

One	O
metre	O
individual	O
samples	O
are	O
submitted	O
for	O
priority	O
analysis	O
where	O
4m	O
composite	O
assays	O
are	O
greater	O
than	O
100ppb	O
Au.	O

All	O
samples	O
are	O
analysed	O
using	O
a	O
50g	O
fire	O
assay	O
with	O
ICP-MS	O
(	O
inductively	O
coupled	O
plasma	O
-	O

mass	O
spectrometry	O
)	O
finish	O
gold	O
analysis	O
(	O
0.005ppm	O
detection	O
limit	O
)	O
by	O
Genalysis-Intertek	O
in	O
Maddington	O
,	O
Western	O
Australia	O
3.	O

g/t	O
(	O
grams	O
per	O
tonne	O
)	O
,	O
ppm	O
(	O
parts	O
per	O
million	O
)	O
,	O
ppb	O
(	O
parts	O
per	O
billion	O
)	O
,	O
X	O
=	O
below	O
detection	O
limit	O
,	O
NSI	O
=	O
no	O
significant	O
intercept	O
above	O
100ppb	O
Au	O
4.	O

Intersections	O
are	O
generally	O
calculated	O
over	O
intervals	O
>0.1g/t	O
where	O
zones	O
of	O
internal	O
dilution	O
are	O
not	O
weaker	O
than	O
2m	O
<	O
0.1g/t	O
Au.	O

9	O
JORC	O
TABLE	O
1	O
Section	O
1	O
Sampling	O
Techniques	O
and	O
Data	O
Criteria	O
Explanation	O
Commentary	O
Sampling	O
Nature	O
and	O
quality	O
of	O
sampling	O
(	O
e.g.	O

cut	O
channels	O
,	O
The	O
drill	O
hole	O
sampling	O
in	O
this	O
release	O
has	O
been	O
carried	O
out	O
on	O
Lake	O
Austin	O
techniques	O
random	O
chips	O
,	O
or	O
specific	O
specialised	O
industry	O
as	O
part	O
of	O
the	O
Cue	O
Joint	O
Venture	O
with	O
Evolution	O
mining	O
Ltd.	O

The	O
drill	O
standard	O
measurement	O
tools	O
appropriate	O
to	O
the	O
program	O
comprises	O
aircore	O
drill	O
holes	O
(	O
436	O
drill	O
holes	O
for	O
48	O
,	O
895m	O
)	O
varying	O
minerals	O
under	O
investigation	O
,	O
such	O
as	O
down	O
hole	O
in	O
depth	O
from	O
5m	O
to	O
180m.	O

All	O
drill	O
holes	O
were	O
drilled	O
at	O
either	O
-60o	O
,	O
-70o	O
gamma	O
sondes	O
,	O
or	O
handheld	O
XRF	O
instruments	O
,	O
etc	O
)	O
.	O

or	O
-90o	O
and	O
at	O
variable	O
spacing	O
but	O
nominally	O
50m	O
spacings	O
along	O
lines	O
These	O
examples	O
should	O
not	O
be	O
taken	O
as	O
limiting	O
the	O
with	O
traverse	O
lines	O
spaced	O
100m-400m	O
apart.	O

broad	O
meaning	O
of	O
sampling.	O

Sampling	O
is	O
undertaken	O
using	O
standard	O
industry	O
practices	O
including	O
the	O
use	O
of	O
duplicates	O
and	O
standards	O
at	O
regular	O
30m	O
intervals.	O

One	O
metre	O
aircore	O
samples	O
are	O
laid	O
out	O
in	O
rows	O
of	O
20	O
on	O
the	O
ground	O
and	O
composite	O
4m	O
samples	O
collected	O
by	O
scoop	O
sampling	O
the	O
one	O
metre	O
piles	O
to	O
produce	O
a	O
2-3kg	O
composite	O
sample	O
which	O
is	O
sent	O
to	O
the	O
Genalysis	O
laboratory	O
in	O
Maddington	O
,	O
Perth	O
for	O
analysis.	O

Resampling	O
of	O
anomalous	O
aircore	O
samples	O
(	O
>100ppb	O
Au	O
)	O
is	O
undertaken	O
at	O
1m	O
intervals	O
by	O
scoop.	O

A	O
Thermo	O
Scientific	O
Niton	O
GoldD	O
XL3+	O
950	O
Analyser	O
is	O
available	O
on	O
site	O
to	O
aid	O
geological	O
interpretation.	O

No	O
XRF	O
results	O
are	O
reported.	O

Include	O
reference	O
to	O
measures	O
taken	O
to	O
ensure	O
All	O
co-ordinates	O
are	O
in	O
UTM	O
grid	O
(	O
GDA94	O
Z50	O
)	O
and	O
drill	O
hole	O
collars	O
have	O
sample	O
representivity	O
and	O
the	O
appropriate	O
calibration	O
been	O
surveyed	O
by	O
handheld	O
GPS	O
to	O
an	O
accuracy	O
of	O
~1.0m.	O

The	O
accuracy	O
of	O
of	O
any	O
measurement	O
tools	O
or	O
systems	O
used.	O

historical	O
drill	O
collars	O
pre-2009	O
is	O
unknown.	O

Gold	O
mineralisation	O
at	O
Howards	O
is	O
hosted	O
within	O
a	O
broad	O
,	O
north-south	O
trending	O
,	O
vertical	O
to	O
steep	O
west-	O
dipping	O
shear	O
zone	O
,	O
approximately	O
150m	O
from	O
,	O
and	O
sub-parallel	O
to	O
the	O
east-dipping	O
eastern	O
contact	O
of	O
the	O
Montague	O
granodiorite.	O

Mineralisation	O
is	O
associated	O
with	O
strong	O
quartz	O
veining	O
and	O
intense	O
silica-	O
albite-biotite	O
alteration	O
within	O
a	O
sheared	O
basalt	O
above	O
a	O
footwall	O
dolerite	O
unit.	O

Two	O
sinistral	O
northwest-	O
trending	O
faults	O
offset	O
the	O
northern	O
(	O
northern	O
lode	O
)	O
and	O
southern	O
(	O
southern	O
lode	O
)	O
extensions	O
of	O
the	O
main	O
Howards	O
lode	O
by	O
30m	O
and	O
150m	O
respectively	O
(	O
Figure	O
2	O
)	O
.	O

Drilling	O
has	O
confirmed	O
the	O
presence	O
of	O
broad	O
zones	O
of	O
potentially	O
open	O
pit	O
gold	O
mineralisation	O
that	O
has	O
now	O
been	O
defined	O
over	O
a	O
continuous	O
strike	O
of	O
over	O
1.3km	O
,	O
with	O
mineralisation	O
remaining	O
open	O
to	O
the	O
north	O
,	O
south	O
and	O
at	O
depth	O
within	O
the	O

lodes.	O

3	O
HWRC237	O
and	O
HWRC245	O
are	O
RC	O
pre-collars	O
for	O
planned	O
diamond	O
drill	O
hole	O
tails	O
,	O
designed	O
to	O
intercept	O
gold	O
mineralisation	O
towards	O
the	O

of	O
the	O
central	O

and	O
provide	O

information	O
to	O

the	O
controls	O
on	O
mineralisation	O
(	O

2	O
)	O
.	O

of	O
future	O
depth	O

is	O

to	O

the	O

at	O
~200m	O
below	O
surface.	O

and	O

of	O

item	O
8.7	O
is	O
less	O
than	O
2	O
quarters	O
,	O
please	O
provide	O

to	O
the	O
following	O

:	O
8.8.1	O
Does	O
the	O
entity	O
expect	O
that	O
it	O
will	O

to	O

time	O

and	O
,	O
if	O
not	O
,	O
why	O
not?	O
Answer	O
:	O
N/A	O
8.8.2	O
Has	O
the	O
entity	O
taken	O
any	O
steps	O
,	O
or	O
does	O
it	O

to	O

steps	O

how	O
likely	O
does	O
it	O
believe	O
that	O
they	O
will	O
be	O
successful?	O
Answer	O
:	O
N/A	O
8.8.3	O
Does	O
the	O
entity	O
expect	O
to	O
be	O
able	O
to	O
continue	O
its	O

and	O
to	O
meet	O

and	O
,	O

,	O
on	O
what	O

Answer	O
:	O
N/A	O
Note	O
:	O
where	O
item	O
8.7	O
is	O
less	O
than	O
2	O
quarters	O
,	O

Notes	O
1.	O

This	O
quarterly	O

flow	O
report	O
and	O
the	O

activity	O
report	O
provide	O
a	O

the	O
market	O
about	O
the	O
entity	O
’	O
s	O

past	O
quarter	O
,	O

has	O

on	O
its	O
cash	O
position.	O

An	O
entity	O
that	O

to	O

information	O

and	O
above	O
the	O
minimum	O

under	O

to	O

so.	O

2.	O

If	O
this	O

Dividends	O

may	O

41	O
Responsibility	O
of	O
the	O
directors	O
for	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
The	O
directors	O
of	O
the	O
Company	O
are	O
responsible	O
for	O
the	O
preparation	O
of	O
the	O
half-year	O
financial	O
report	O
that	O
gives	O
a	O
true	O
and	O
fair	O
view	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
Australian	O
Accounting	O
Standards	O
and	O
the	O
Corporations	O
Act	O
2001	O
and	O
for	O
such	O
internal	O
control	O
as	O
the	O
directors	O
determine	O
is	O
necessary	O
to	O
enable	O
the	O
preparation	O
of	O
the	O
half-year	O
financial	O
report	O
that	O
gives	O
a	O
true	O
and	O
fair	O
view	O
and	O
is	O
free	O
from	O
material	O
misstatement	O
,	O
whether	O
due	O
to	O
fraud	O
or	O
error.	O

Our	O
responsibility	O
is	O
to	O
express	O
a	O
conclusion	O
on	O
the	O
half-year	O
financial	O
report	O
based	O
on	O
our	O
review.	O

ASRE	O
2410	O
requires	O
us	O
to	O
conclude	O
whether	O
we	O
have	O
become	O
aware	O
of	O
any	O
matter	O
that	O
makes	O
us	O
believe	O
that	O
the	O
half-year	O
financial	O
report	O
is	O
not	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
the	O
Corporations	O
Act	O
2001	O
including	O
giving	O
a	O
31	O
December	O
2021	O
and	O
its	O
financial	O
performance	O
for	O
the	O
half-year	O
ended	O
on	O
that	O
date	O
and	O
complying	O
with	O
Accounting	O
Standard	O
AASB	O
134	O
Interim	O
Financial	O
Reporting	O
and	O
the	O
Corporations	O
Regulations	O
2001.	O

A	O
review	O
of	O
a	O
half-year	O
financial	O
report	O
consists	O
of	O
making	O
enquiries	O
,	O
primarily	O
of	O
persons	O
responsible	O
for	O
financial	O
and	O
accounting	O
matters	O
,	O
and	O
applying	O
analytical	O
and	O
other	O
review	O
procedures.	O

A	O
review	O
is	O
substantially	O
less	O
in	O
scope	O
than	O
an	O
audit	O
conducted	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
Australian	O
Auditing	O
Standards	O
and	O
consequently	O
does	O
not	O
enable	O
us	O
to	O
obtain	O
assurance	O
that	O
we	O
would	O
become	O
aware	O
of	O
all	O
significant	O
matters	O
that	O
might	O
be	O
identified	O
in	O
an	O
audit.	O

Accordingly	O
,	O
we	O
do	O
not	O
express	O
an	O
audit	O
opinion.	O

BDO	O
Audit	O
(	O
WA	O
)	O
Pty	O
Ltd	O
Jarrad	O
Prue	O
Director	O
Perth	O
,	O
16	O

33	O
Risks	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
’	O
operating	O
results	O
,	O
financial	O
results	O
and	O
performance	O
are	O
subject	O
to	O
a	O
wide	O
range	O
of	O
risks	O
and	O
uncertainties	O
(	O
both	O
opportunities	O
and	O
threats	O
)	O
that	O
can	O
be	O
financial	O
,	O
political	O
,	O
operational	O
and	O
environmental.	O

The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
manages	O
and	O
mitigates	O
these	O
risks	O
,	O
where	O
appropriate	O
,	O
to	O
minimise	O
adverse	O
impacts	O
from	O
threats	O
and	O
maximise	O
beneficial	O
outcomes	O
from	O
opportunities.	O

OZ	O
Minerals	O
’	O
flat	O
corporate	O
governance	O
structure	O
and	O
direct	O
communication	O
channels	O
ensures	O
timely	O
responses	O
to	O
emerging	O
risks.	O

Our	O
risk	O
management	O
framework	O
emphasises	O
risk	O
aware	O
decision-making	O
to	O
achieve	O
enhanced	O
business	O
outcomes.	O

The	O
Board	O
has	O
oversight	O
responsibility	O
and	O
determines	O
the	O
overall	O
risk	O
appetite	O
for	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity.	O

OZ	O
Minerals	O
operates	O
a	O
risk	O
management	O
system	O
with	O
multiple	O
lines	O
of	O
defence.	O

Line	O
managers	O
,	O
operational	O
staff	O
and	O
corporate	O
functions	O
establish	O
standards	O
for	O
managing	O
risk	O
and	O
the	O
Board	O
and	O
its	O
committees	O
review	O
risk	O
management	O
as	O
a	O
part	O
of	O
their	O
oversight	O
and	O
inspection	O
role.	O

The	O
Company	O
identified	O
risks	O
and	O
mitigating	O
factors	O
that	O
have	O
the	O
potential	O
to	O
affect	O
future	O
operating	O
and	O
financial	O
performance	O
(	O
provided	O
in	O
the	O
table	O
below	O
)	O
.	O

controls	O
for	O
threats	O

the	O
adverse	O
impact	O
on	O
the	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
performance	O
,	O
but	O

oZ	O

’	O

Risk	O

Strategic	O
risks	O
One	O
operating	O
asset	O
The	O
Prominent	O
Hill	O
mine	O
generates	O
most	O
of	O
the	O
Prominent	O
Hill	O
now	O
operates	O
an	O
integrated	O
underground	O
mine	O
with	O
multiple	O
Operating	O
only	O
one	O
producing	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
income	O
and	O
cash	O
flow.	O

areas.	O

This	O
mitigates	O
sole	O
dependence	O
on	O
the	O
open	O
pit.	O

asset	O
exposes	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
The	O
Company	O
has	O
an	O
active	O
program	O
which	O
focuses	O
on	O
using	O
trigger	O
action	O
Entity	O
to	O
concentration	O

response	O
plans	O
to	O

the	O
ongoing	O

of	O

open	O
pit	O
walls.	O

The	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
maintenance	O
and	O
engineering	O
team	O
have	O
developed	O
robust	O
procedures	O
and	O
practices	O
to	O
ensure	O
they	O
are	O

the	O
processing	O
plant	O
with	O
minimal	O

and	O
at	O
high	O
throughput	O
levels.	O

Concentrate	O
is	O

to	O
Australian	O
destinations	O
using	O
road	O
and	O
rail	O
and	O
it	O
is	O
shipped	O
to	O
overseas	O
destinations	O
from	O
the	O
port	O
of	O
Adelaide.	O

Spillage	O
risks	O
(	O
and	O
environmental	O
impact	O
)	O
are	O

by	O
using	O
customised	O
containers	O

and	O
rotainers	O
to	O
load	O
concentrate	O
onto	O
ships.	O

of	O
power	O
supply	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
competes	O
with	O
other	O
power	O
users	O
for	O

Company	O
is	O

a	O
power	O
strategy	O
to	O

with	O
its	O
business	O

Prominent	O

mine	O
and	O
competitively-priced	O
uninterrupted	O
power	O
supply	O
within	O
strategy	O
,	O

in	O
the	O
Gawler	O
Craton.	O

Carrapateena	O
project	O
are	O
both	O
the	O

,	O

and	O

supply	O

Carrapateena	O

Growth	O
strategy	O
The	O
existence	O
of	O
a	O
large	O
resource	O
at	O
the	O
Prominent	O
Hill	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
has	O
a	O

of	O
projects	O
and	O
gated	O
plans	O
which	O
ensure	O
a	O
A	O
key	O
element	O
of	O

Company	O
’	O
s	O
operation	O
,	O
Carrapateena	O
,	O
Khamsin	O
,	O
Fremantle	O

2.1	O
Overview	O
of	O
remuneration	O
Business	O
needs	O
and	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
remuneration	O
policy	O
is	O
focused	O
on	O
achieving	O
our	O
corporate	O
objectives.	O

policy	O
and	O
practices	O
market	O
alignment	O
Remuneration	O
is	O
set	O
having	O
regard	O
to	O
market	O
practices	O
and	O
aligned	O
with	O
achieving	O
shareholder	O
returns.	O

The	O
remuneration	O
principles	O
outlined	O
in	O
Table	O
2	O
demonstrate	O
the	O
links	O
between	O
Simplicity	O
and	O
equity	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
remuneration	O
philosophy	O
,	O
policy	O
,	O
principles	O
and	O
structures	O
are	O
simple	O
to	O
remuneration	O
and	O
business	O
strategies	O
understand	O
,	O
communicate	O
and	O
implement	O
,	O
and	O
are	O
equitable	O
across	O
the	O
Company	O
and	O
their	O
impact	O
on	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
actual	O
and	O
its	O
diverse	O
workforce.	O

remuneration	O
arrangements.	O

The	O
overriding	O
Performance	O
and	O
Well-designed	O
remuneration	O
policy	O
supports	O
and	O
drives	O
Company	O
and	O
team	O
business	O
objective	O
is	O
to	O
achieve	O
superior	O
reward	O
linkages	O
performance	O
and	O
encourages	O
the	O
demonstration	O
of	O
desired	O
behaviours.	O

Performance	O
returns	O
compared	O
to	O
the	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
peers	O
measures	O
and	O
targets	O
are	O
few	O
in	O
number	O
,	O
outcome-focused	O
and	O
customised	O
at	O
an	O
in	O
the	O
resources	O
sector.	O

individual	O
level	O
to	O
maximise	O
performance	O
,	O
accountability	O
and	O
reward	O
linkages.	O

Market	O
positioning	O
Fixed	O
remuneration	O
is	O
set	O
at	O
a	O
competitive	O
level	O
and	O
positioned	O
to	O
take	O
in	O
to	O
account	O
and	O
remuneration	O
mix	O
the	O
challenges	O
of	O
attracting	O
and	O
retaining	O
high	O
performers	O
in	O
business	O
critical	O
roles	O
,	O
particularly	O
in	O
the	O
mining	O
industry.	O

‘	O
at-risk	O
’	O
components	O
of	O

depend	O
on	O
challenging	O
goals	O
and	O

on	O

executive	O
KMP	O
to	O

objectives	O
and	O
shareholder	O
returns.	O

OZ	O
Minerals	O

and	O

2.2	O
Remuneration	O

executive	O
KMP	O

/	O

the	O

,	O

to	O

may	O

(	O

)	O
The	O

that	O

the	O
job	O
size	O
,	O
role	O
,	O

,	O
performance	O

,	O
annual	O

incentive	O
The	O

of	O

at-risk	O

and	O

of	O

to	O

against	O
which	O

to	O
the	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
medium	O
to	O

executive	O
,	O

to	O
their	O

,	O

,	O
clearly	O

and	O

objectives.	O

term	O
TSR	O
and	O
share	O
price	O
performance.	O

A	O
three-year	O
and	O
accountabilities	O
and	O
considering	O
external	O
market	O
These	O
are	O
based	O
on	O
a	O

of	O
targets	O
and	O
are	O
set	O
to	O
performance	O
period	O
applies.	O

relativities.	O

incentivise	O
superior	O
performance	O

specific	O
targets	O
or	O
metrics	O
in	O
each	O
category.	O

The	O
mix	O
of	O

and	O

on	O
the	O

well	O
as	O

and	O
individual	O
executives.	O

More	O

a	O

t	O
43	O
table	O
4	O
–	O

Questions	O
and	O
answers	O
about	O
executive	O
KMP	O
remuneration	O
Total	O
fixed	O
remuneration	O
(	O
TFR	O
)	O
What	O
is	O
included	O
in	O
total	O
fixed	O
remuneration?	O
An	O
executive	O
KMP	O
’	O
s	O
total	O
fixed	O
remuneration	O
comprises	O
salary	O
and	O
certain	O
other	O
benefits	O
(	O
including	O
statutory	O
superannuation	O
contributions	O
)	O
that	O
may	O
be	O
taken	O
in	O
an	O
agreed	O
form	O
,	O
such	O
as	O
cash	O
,	O
leased	O
motor	O
vehicles	O
and	O
additional	O
superannuation	O
,	O
provided	O
that	O
no	O
extra	O
cost	O
is	O
incurred	O
by	O
the	O
Company	O
for	O
these	O
benefits.	O

When	O
and	O
how	O
is	O
fixed	O
remuneration	O
reviewed?	O
Fixed	O
remuneration	O
is	O
reviewed	O
annually.	O

Any	O
adjustments	O
to	O
the	O
fixed	O
remuneration	O
for	O
the	O
Managing	O
Director	O
and	O
CEO	O
and	O
other	O
executive	O
KMP	O
must	O
be	O
approved	O
by	O
the	O
Board	O
after	O
recommendations	O
by	O
the	O
Human	O
Resources	O
and	O
Remuneration	O
Committee.	O

The	O
Company	O
seeks	O
to	O
position	O
the	O
fixed	O
remuneration	O
between	O
the	O
50th	O
and	O
75th	O
percentile	O
(	O
or	O
higher	O
)	O
of	O

)	O

Variable	O
performance	O
based	O
remuneration	O
strengthens	O
the	O
link	O
between	O
pay	O
and	O
performance.	O

programmes	O
is	O
to	O
make	O
a	O
large	O

of	O
the	O
total	O
market	O

to	O

various	O

to	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
’	O

plan	O

1.	O

Total	O
shareholder	O
return	O
(	O
TSR	O
)	O
Relative	O
TSR	O
is	O
the	O
primary	O
LTI	O
performance	O
hurdle	O
measured	O
against	O
a	O
comparator	O
group.	O

The	O
Board	O
considers	O
TSR	O
to	O
be	O
an	O
appropriate	O
performance	O
hurdle	O
because	O
it	O
ensures	O
that	O
a	O
proportion	O
of	O
each	O
participant	O
’	O
s	O
remuneration	O
is	O
linked	O
to	O
shareholder	O
value	O
and	O
that	O
participants	O
only	O
receive	O
a	O
benefit	O
where	O
there	O
is	O
a	O
corresponding	O
direct	O
benefit	O
to	O
shareholders.	O

TSR	O
reflects	O
benefits	O
received	O
by	O
shareholders	O
through	O
share	O
price	O
growth	O
and	O
dividend	O
yield	O
and	O
it	O
is	O
the	O
most	O
widely	O
used	O
long	O
term	O
incentive	O
hurdle	O
in	O
Australia.	O

The	O
Company	O
employs	O
an	O
independent	O
organisation	O
to	O
calculate	O
the	O
TSR	O
ranking	O
to	O
ensure	O
an	O
objective	O
assessment	O
of	O
the	O
relative	O
TSR	O
comparison.	O

Performance	O
rights	O
in	O
respect	O
to	O
this	O
hurdle	O
will	O
vest	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
the	O
following	O
table.	O

table	O
4.4	O
–	O

Performance	O
rights	O
vested	O
according	O
to	O
total	O
shareholder	O
return	O
TSR	O
of	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
relative	O
to	O
TSRs	O
Proportion	O
of	O
performance	O
rights	O
that	O
vest	O
of	O
constituents	O
of	O
the	O
nominated	O
peer	O
group	O
Below	O
50th	O
percentile	O
0%	O
50th	O
percentile	O
50%	O
Between	O
50th	O
percentile	O
and	O
75th	O
percentile	O
(	O
not	O
inclusive	O
)	O
Straight	O
line	O
vesting	O
between	O
50%	O
and	O
100%	O
75th	O
percentile	O
or	O
above	O
100%	O
The	O
TSR	O
performance	O
hurdle	O
accounts	O
for	O
70%	O
of	O
the	O
LTI	O
award.	O

2.	O

Absolute	O
share	O
price	O
growth	O
Absolute	O
share	O
price	O
growth	O
is	O
the	O
second	O
LTI	O
performance	O
hurdle.	O

This	O
hurdle	O
will	O
be	O
satisfied	O
if	O
the	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
share	O
price	O
has	O
increased	O
by	O
at	O
least	O

3.3	O
LTI	O
performance	O
and	O
outcomes	O
Performance	O
rights	O
granted	O
under	O
the	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
LTI	O
Plan	O
are	O
granted	O
for	O
no	O
consideration.	O

Performance	O
rights	O
carry	O
no	O
dividend	O
or	O
voting	O
rights.	O

One	O
ordinary	O
share	O
in	O
the	O
Company	O
will	O
be	O
allocated	O
on	O
vesting	O
of	O
a	O
performance	O
right.	O

The	O
vesting	O
condition	O
for	O
each	O
grant	O
is	O
the	O
relative	O
TSR	O
performance	O
and	O
absolute	O
share	O
price	O
growth	O
of	O
the	O
Company	O
over	O
the	O
relevant	O
performance	O
period.	O

In	O
general	O
,	O
the	O
executive	O
must	O
also	O
remain	O
employed	O
with	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
for	O
a	O
continuous	O
period	O
of	O
three	O
years	O
from	O
the	O
grant	O
date.	O

Details	O
of	O
the	O
prior	O
awards	O
for	O
relevant	O
executive	O
KMP	O
are	O
set	O
out	O
in	O
the	O
Remuneration	O
Report	O
for	O
the	O
year	O
in	O
which	O
they	O
were	O
granted.	O

Details	O
of	O
the	O
performance	O
rights	O
held	O
by	O
executive	O
KMP	O
that	O
lapsed	O
during	O
the	O
year	O
are	O
set	O
out	O
in	O
Table	O
15.	O

details	O
are	O
set	O
out	O

to	O

The	O
maximum	O
value	O
of	O
the	O
grants	O
has	O
been	O
estimated	O
based	O
on	O
a	O
52-week	O
high	O
closing	O
share	O
price	O
in	O
the	O
calendar	O
year	O
of	O
the	O
grant.	O

For	O
the	O
2017	O
grant	O
,	O
this	O
was	O
$9.99	O
per	O
instrument.	O

The	O
minimum	O
total	O
value	O
of	O
each	O
grant	O
,	O
if	O
the	O
applicable	O
performance	O
conditions	O
are	O
not	O
met	O
,	O
is	O
nil.	O

(	O
b	O
)	O
The	O
fair	O
values	O
were	O
calculated	O
as	O
at	O
the	O
grant	O
dates.	O

In	O
accordance	O
with	O
the	O
requirements	O
of	O
applicable	O
accounting	O
standards	O
,	O
remuneration	O
includes	O
a	O
proportion	O
of	O
the	O
notional	O
value	O
of	O
performance	O
rights	O
as	O
compensation	O
granted	O
or	O
outstanding	O
during	O
the	O
year.	O

The	O
notional	O
value	O
of	O
performance	O
rights	O
granted	O
as	O
compensation	O
is	O
determined	O
as	O
at	O
the	O
grant	O
date	O
and	O
progressively	O
allocated	O
over	O
the	O
vesting	O
period.	O

The	O
amount	O
included	O
as	O
remuneration	O
is	O
not	O
related	O
to	O
or	O
indicative	O
of	O
the	O
benefit	O
(	O
if	O
any	O
)	O
that	O
individual	O
executives	O
may	O
in	O
fact	O
receive.	O

The	O
values	O
were	O
calculated	O
by	O
an	O
external	O
third	O
party	O
based	O
on	O
a	O
Monte-Carlo	O
simulation	O
model.	O

accrued	O
annual	O
leave	O
reflects	O
more	O
leave	O
taken/cashed	O
out	O
than	O
that	O
which	O
accrued	O
in	O
the	O
period.	O

(	O

)	O

direct	O
contributions	O
to	O
superannuation	O
funds	O

level	O

(	O

)	O

(	O
e	O
)	O
The	O
fair	O
values	O
were	O
calculated	O
as	O
at	O
the	O
grant	O
dates.	O

In	O
accordance	O
with	O
the	O
requirements	O
of	O
applicable	O
accounting	O
standards	O
,	O
remuneration	O
includes	O
a	O
proportion	O
of	O
the	O
notional	O
value	O
of	O
equity	O
rights	O
compensation	O
granted	O
or	O
outstanding	O
during	O
the	O
year.	O

The	O
notional	O
value	O
of	O
equity	O
rights	O
granted	O
as	O
compensation	O
which	O
do	O
not	O
vest	O
during	O
the	O
reporting	O
period	O
is	O
determined	O
as	O
at	O
the	O
grant	O
date	O
and	O
progressively	O
allocated	O
over	O
the	O
vesting	O
period.	O

The	O
amount	O
included	O
as	O
remuneration	O
is	O
not	O
related	O
to	O
or	O
indicative	O
of	O
the	O
benefit	O
(	O
if	O
any	O
)	O
that	O
individual	O
executives	O
may	O
in	O
fact	O
receive.	O

values	O
were	O
calculated	O
by	O

on	O
a	O

simulation	O
model.	O

(	O
a	O
)	O
Scope	O
1	O
refers	O
to	O

by	O
operations	O
,	O

of	O

such	O

79	O
How	O
the	O
Standard	O
Defines	O
Limited	O
Assurance	O
and	O
Material	O
Misstatement	O
The	O
procedures	O
performed	O
in	O
a	O
limited	O
assurance	O
engagement	O
vary	O
in	O
nature	O
and	O
timing	O
from	O
,	O
and	O
are	O
less	O
in	O
extent	O
than	O
for	O
a	O
reasonable	O
assurance	O
engagement.	O

Consequently	O
the	O
level	O
of	O
assurance	O
obtained	O
in	O
a	O
limited	O
assurance	O
engagement	O
is	O
substantially	O
lower	O
than	O
the	O
assurance	O
that	O
would	O
have	O
been	O
obtained	O
had	O
a	O
reasonable	O
assurance	O
engagement	O
been	O
performed.	O

Misstatements	O
,	O
including	O
omissions	O
,	O
are	O
considered	O
material	O
if	O
,	O
individually	O
or	O
in	O
the	O
aggregate	O
,	O
they	O
could	O
reasonably	O
be	O
expected	O
to	O
influence	O
relevant	O
decisions	O
of	O
the	O
Directors	O
of	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
Limited.	O

Use	O
of	O
this	O
Assurance	O
Report	O
This	O
report	O
has	O
been	O
prepared	O
for	O
the	O
Directors	O
of	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
Limited	O
for	O
the	O
purpose	O
of	O
providing	O
an	O
assurance	O
conclusion	O
on	O
the	O
Selected	O
Sustainability	O
Information	O
and	O
may	O
not	O
be	O
suitable	O
for	O
another	O
purpose.	O

We	O
disclaim	O
any	O

of	O

any	O

this	O

2017	O
Recognition	O
and	O
measurement	O
of	O
income	O
taxes	O
Current	O
tax	O
The	O
tax	O
currently	O
payable	O
is	O
based	O
on	O
taxable	O
profit	O
for	O
the	O
year	O
,	O
using	O
rates	O
enacted	O
or	O
substantively	O
enacted	O
at	O
reporting	O
date	O
,	O
and	O
any	O
adjustments	O
to	O
tax	O
payable	O
in	O
respect	O
of	O
previous	O
years.	O

Deferred	O
tax	O
Deferred	O
tax	O
assets	O
and	O
liabilities	O
are	O
determined	O
using	O
the	O
balance	O
sheet	O
method	O
which	O
calculates	O
temporary	O
differences	O
based	O
on	O
the	O
difference	O
between	O
the	O
carrying	O
amount	O
of	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
’	O
s	O
assets	O
and	O
liabilities	O
in	O
the	O
balance	O
sheet	O
and	O
their	O
associated	O
tax	O
bases.	O

Deferred	O
tax	O
assets	O
and	O
liabilities	O
are	O
not	O
recognised	O
for	O
temporary	O
differences	O
arising	O
from	O
investments	O
in	O
subsidiaries	O
where	O
the	O
consolidated	O
entity	O
is	O
able	O
to	O
control	O
the	O
reversal	O
of	O
the	O
temporary	O
differences	O
,	O
and	O
it	O
is	O
probable	O
they	O
will	O
not	O
reverse	O
in	O
the	O
foreseeable	O
future.	O

Deferred	O
tax	O
assets	O
are	O
recognised	O
to	O
the	O
extent	O
that	O
it	O
is	O
probable	O
that	O
future	O
taxable	O
income	O
will	O
be	O
available	O
to	O
utilise	O
them.	O

The	O
carrying	O
amount	O
of	O
deferred	O
tax	O
assets	O
is	O
reviewed	O
at	O
the	O
end	O
of	O
each	O
reporting	O
date	O
and	O
adjusted	O
based	O
on	O
estimates	O
of	O
future	O
taxable	O
income	O
and	O
or	O
capital	O
gains	O
against	O
which	O
the	O
deferred	O
tax	O
asset	O
could	O
be	O
utilised.	O

Deferred	O
tax	O
assets	O
and	O
liabilities	O
are	O
measured	O
at	O
the	O
tax	O
rates	O
applicable	O
to	O
each	O
jurisdiction	O
which	O
are	O
expected	O
to	O
apply	O
in	O
the	O
period	O
when	O
the	O
assets	O
are	O
realised	O
or	O
liabilities	O
discharged	O
and	O
are	O
offset	O
where	O
they	O
relate	O
to	O
the	O
same	O
tax	O
authority	O
and	O
there	O
is	O
a	O
legally	O

right	O
to	O
offset.	O

Recognition	O

of	O

the	O

of	O

8.	O

Lease	O
receivable	O
Recognition	O
and	O
measurement	O
of	O
finance	O
lease	O
receivable	O
Leases	O
which	O
transfer	O
substantially	O
all	O
the	O
risk	O
and	O
rewards	O
of	O
ownership	O
of	O
an	O
asset	O
are	O
classified	O
as	O
finance	O
leases.	O

Where	O
a	O
finance	O
lease	O
is	O
provided	O
,	O
the	O
item	O
of	O
equipment	O
is	O
derecognised	O
and	O
the	O
present	O

of	O
the	O
minimum	O
lease	O
payments	O
receivable	O
are	O
recognised	O
as	O
a	O
lease	O
receivable.	O

Contingent	O
rents	O
are	O
recognised	O
as	O
revenue	O
in	O
the	O
period	O
in	O
which	O
they	O
are	O
earned.	O

The	O
finance	O
lease	O
receivable	O
represents	O
the	O

paid	O
by	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
to	O

mining	O

which	O
was	O

back	O
to	O
Thiess	O
on	O
an	O
interest	O
free	O
basis.	O

OZ	O
Minerals	O

progressively	O
over	O
the	O
mining	O
services	O
contract	O
from	O
reduced	O
mining	O
services	O
charges	O
by	O
Thiess.	O

Upon	O

of	O

services	O
contract	O

of	O
lease	O

9.	O

Provisions	O
MINE	O
REHABILITATION	O
,	O
RESTORATION	O
AND	O
DISMANTLING	O
OBLIGATIONS	O
The	O
provision	O
for	O
mine	O
rehabilitation	O
includes	O
future	O
cost	O
estimates	O
associated	O
with	O
reclamation	O
,	O
plant	O
closures	O
,	O
waste	O
site	O
closures	O
,	O
monitoring	O
,	O
demobilisation	O
of	O
equipment	O
,	O
decontamination	O
,	O
water	O
purification	O
and	O
permanent	O
storage	O
of	O
historical	O
residues.	O

Uncertainty	O
exists	O
as	O
to	O
the	O
amount	O
of	O
rehabilitation	O
obligations	O
which	O
will	O
be	O
incurred	O
due	O
to	O
the	O
impact	O
of	O
changes	O
in	O
environmental	O
legislation	O
,	O
and	O
many	O
other	O
factors	O
,	O
including	O
future	O
changes	O
in	O
technology	O
,	O
price	O
increases	O
and	O
changes	O
in	O
interest	O
rates.	O

The	O
calculation	O
of	O
these	O
provision	O
estimates	O
requires	O
assumptions	O
such	O
as	O
application	O
of	O
environmental	O
legislation	O
,	O
plant	O
closure	O
dates	O
,	O
available	O
technologies	O
,	O
engineering	O
cost	O
estimates	O
and	O
discount	O
rates.	O

A	O
change	O
in	O
any	O
of	O
the	O
assumptions	O
used	O
may	O
have	O
a	O
material	O
impact	O
on	O
the	O
carrying	O
value	O
of	O
mine	O
rehabilitation	O
,	O
restoration	O
and	O
dismantling	O
provisions.	O

Recognition	O
and	O
measurement	O
of	O
provisions	O
Provisions	O
are	O
measured	O
at	O
the	O
present	O
value	O
of	O
the	O
best	O
estimate	O
of	O
the	O
expenditure	O
required	O
to	O
settle	O
the	O
present	O
obligation	O
at	O
balance	O
sheet	O
date.	O

The	O
discount	O
rate	O
used	O
to	O
determine	O
the	O
present	O
value	O
reflects	O
current	O
market	O
assessments	O
of	O
the	O
time	O
value	O
of	O
money	O
and	O
the	O
risks	O
specific	O
to	O
the	O
liability.	O

The	O
increase	O
in	O
provisions	O
due	O
to	O
the	O
passage	O
of	O
time	O
is	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
Income	O
Statement	O
as	O
financing	O
expenses.	O

Provisions	O
are	O
made	O
for	O
the	O
estimated	O
cost	O
of	O
rehabilitation	O
,	O
decommissioning	O
and	O
restoration	O
relating	O
to	O
areas	O
disturbed	O
during	O
mining	O
and	O
exploration	O
operations	O
up	O
to	O
the	O
reporting	O
date	O
but	O
not	O
yet	O
rehabilitated.	O

Provisions	O
for	O
mine	O
rehabilitation	O
are	O
based	O
on	O
current	O
estimates	O
of	O
costs	O
to	O
rehabilitate	O
such	O
areas	O
,	O
discounted	O
to	O
their	O
present	O
value	O
based	O
on	O
expected	O
future	O
cash	O
flows.	O

The	O

costs	O
include	O

current	O
cost	O
of	O

to	O

basis	O
as	O
they	O
arise.	O

provision	O

as	O

,	O

into	O

(	O

and	O

components	O

on	O
the	O

of	O
these	O
cash	O
flows.	O

Recognition	O
and	O
measurement	O
of	O
share-based	O
payments	O
The	O
fair	O
value	O
of	O
share-based	O
payment	O
transactions	O
measured	O
at	O
grant	O
date	O
are	O
recognised	O
as	O
an	O
employee	O
benefit	O
expense	O
with	O
a	O
corresponding	O
increase	O
in	O
equity	O
over	O
the	O
period	O
during	O
which	O
the	O
employees	O
become	O
unconditionally	O
entitled	O
to	O
the	O
instruments.	O

If	O
the	O
employee	O
does	O
not	O
meet	O
a	O
non-market	O
condition	O
,	O
such	O
as	O
a	O
service	O
condition	O
or	O
internal	O
KPI	O
’	O
s	O
,	O
any	O
cumulative	O
previously	O
recognised	O
expense	O
is	O
reversed.	O

The	O
fair	O
value	O
of	O
the	O
share-based	O
payment	O
transactions	O
granted	O
are	O
adjusted	O
to	O
reflect	O
market	O
vesting	O
conditions	O
at	O
the	O
time	O
of	O
grant	O
,	O
and	O
are	O
not	O
subsequently	O
adjusted.	O

Non-market	O
vesting	O
conditions	O
are	O
included	O
in	O
assumptions	O
about	O
the	O
number	O
of	O
instruments	O
that	O
are	O
expected	O
to	O
become	O
exercisable	O
and	O
are	O
updated	O
at	O
each	O
balance	O
sheet	O
date.	O

The	O
impact	O
of	O
the	O
revision	O
to	O
original	O
estimates	O
for	O
non-market	O
conditions	O
,	O
if	O
any	O
,	O
is	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
Income	O
Statement	O
with	O
a	O
corresponding	O
adjustment	O
to	O
equity.	O

Changes	O
as	O
a	O
result	O
of	O
market	O
conditions	O
are	O
not	O
adjusted	O
after	O
the	O
initial	O
grant	O
date.	O

AND	O

risk	O

OZ	O

’	O

(	O
‘	O

’	O
)	O

The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O

a	O
financial	O
asset	O
or	O
part	O
of	O
it	O
when	O

and	O

asset	O

or	O

financial	O
asset	O
is	O

to	O
another	O
party	O
without	O
retaining	O
control	O
or	O
substantially	O
all	O
risks	O
and	O
rewards	O
of	O
the	O
asset.	O

On	O

of	O
a	O

between	O

)	O
and	O

received	O
(	O

any	O
new	O
asset	O
obtained	O
less	O
any	O
new	O
liability	O
assumed	O
)	O
and	O
any	O

gain	O
or	O
loss	O
that	O
had	O
been	O
recognised	O
in	O
equity	O
is	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
Income	O
Statement.	O

A	O
financial	O
asset	O
measured	O
at	O
amortised	O
cost	O
is	O
assessed	O
at	O
each	O
reporting	O
date	O
as	O
to	O
whether	O
there	O
is	O
any	O
objective	O
evidence	O
of	O
impairment	O
as	O
a	O
result	O
of	O
one	O
or	O
more	O
events	O
having	O
an	O
impact	O
on	O
the	O
estimated	O
future	O
cash	O
flows	O
of	O
the	O
asset.	O

An	O
impairment	O
loss	O
in	O
respect	O
of	O
financial	O
assets	O
measured	O
at	O
amortised	O
cost	O
is	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
Income	O
Statement	O
and	O
is	O
measured	O
as	O
the	O
difference	O
between	O
the	O
asset	O
’	O
s	O
carrying	O
amount	O
and	O
the	O
present	O
value	O
of	O
estimated	O
future	O
cash	O
flows	O
discounted	O
at	O
the	O
asset	O
’	O
s	O
original	O
effective	O
interest	O
rate.	O

The	O
carrying	O
amount	O
of	O
the	O
asset	O
is	O
reduced	O
through	O
the	O
use	O
of	O
an	O
allowance	O
account.	O

In	O
the	O
event	O
that	O
an	O
impairment	O
loss	O
is	O
reversed	O
,	O
the	O
asset	O
’	O
s	O
carrying	O
amount	O
can	O
not	O
exceed	O
what	O
the	O
carrying	O
amount	O
would	O
have	O
been	O
had	O
the	O

not	O
been	O
recognised.	O

The	O
amount	O
of	O
the	O
reversal	O
is	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
Income	O
Statement.	O

and	O
other	O

and	O

to	O

Entity	O

,	O

and	O
are	O
usually	O

within	O
30	O
days	O
of	O
recognition.	O

or	O

EFFECTIVENESS	O

Foreign	O

The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
is	O
exposed	O
to	O
foreign	O
currency	O
risk	O
arising	O
from	O
assets	O
and	O
liabilities	O
that	O
are	O
held	O
in	O
currencies	O
other	O
than	O
the	O
Australian	O
dollar.	O

All	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
operations	O
have	O
a	O
functional	O
currency	O
of	O
Australian	O
dollars.	O

An	O
entity	O
’	O
s	O
functional	O
currency	O
is	O
the	O
currency	O
of	O
the	O
primary	O
economic	O
environment	O
in	O
which	O
the	O
entity	O
operates.	O

Determination	O
of	O
an	O
entity	O
’	O
s	O
functional	O
currency	O
requires	O
management	O
’	O
s	O
judgement	O
when	O
considering	O
a	O
number	O
of	O
factors	O
including	O
the	O
currency	O
that	O
mainly	O
influences	O
revenue	O
,	O
costs	O
of	O
production	O
,	O
and	O
competitive	O
forces	O
and	O
regulations	O
which	O
impact	O
revenue.	O

In	O
addition	O
,	O
consideration	O
must	O
be	O
given	O
to	O
the	O
currency	O
in	O
which	O
financing	O
and	O
operating	O
activities	O
are	O
undertaken.	O

Foreign	O
currency	O
transactions	O
are	O
translated	O
into	O
the	O
functional	O
currency	O
using	O
exchange	O
rates	O
prevailing	O
at	O
the	O
date	O
of	O
the	O
transaction.	O

and	O

from	O

settlement	O
of	O
such	O
transactions	O
and	O
from	O
the	O
translation	O
at	O
year	O

exchange	O
rates	O
of	O
financial	O
assets	O
and	O

denominated	O

foreign	O
currencies	O
are	O

Credit	O
risk	O
management	O
Credit	O

to	O
the	O

any	O

credit	O
risk	O
arises	O
through	O
sales	O
of	O
metal	O
in	O
concentrate	O
on	O
normal	O

trade	O

trade	O
receivables	O
,	O

receivables	O
,	O
derivative	O
assets	O
and	O
lease	O
receivables.	O

credit	O

and	O
cash	O
equivalents	O
is	O
managed	O
by	O
restricting	O
financial	O
transactions	O
to	O
banks	O
which	O
are	O
assigned	O
S&P	O
equivalent	O
of	O
A-1	O

Risk	O
Management	O
Policy.	O

Credit	O
risk	O
in	O
trade	O
receivables	O
is	O
managed	O
by	O
undertaking	O
regular	O
risk	O
assessment	O
and	O

credit	O
limits	O
of	O
customers.	O

As	O
there	O
are	O
a	O
relatively	O
small	O
number	O
of	O
transactions	O
,	O
they	O
are	O
closely	O
monitored	O
to	O
ensure	O
risk	O
of	O
default	O
is	O
kept	O
to	O
an	O
acceptably	O
low	O
level.	O

per	O
cent	O
of	O

vessel	O

vessel	O

the	O
discharge	O
port.	O

Where	O
applicable	O
,	O

are	O

of	O

ANNUAL	O

2017	O
Liquidity	O
risk	O
management	O
Liquidity	O
risk	O
is	O
the	O
risk	O
of	O
encountering	O
difficulty	O
in	O
meeting	O
obligations	O
associated	O
with	O
financial	O
liabilities.	O

OZ	O
Minerals	O
manages	O
liquidity	O
risk	O
by	O
conducting	O
regular	O
reviews	O
of	O
the	O
timing	O
of	O
cash	O
outflows	O
and	O
the	O
maturity	O
profiles	O
of	O
term	O
deposits	O
in	O
order	O
to	O
ensure	O
sufficient	O
funds	O
are	O
available	O
to	O
meet	O
its	O
obligations.	O

The	O
following	O
table	O
reflects	O
all	O
contractual	O
repayments	O
from	O
recognised	O
financial	O
assets	O
and	O

121	O
Basis	O
of	O
consolidation	O
Investments	O
in	O
subsidiaries	O
Subsidiaries	O
are	O
those	O
entities	O
over	O
which	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
is	O
capable	O
of	O
exerting	O
control.	O

The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
controls	O
an	O
entity	O
when	O
it	O
is	O
exposed	O
to	O
,	O
or	O
has	O
rights	O
to	O
,	O
variable	O
returns	O
from	O
its	O
involvement	O
with	O
the	O
entity	O
and	O
has	O
the	O
ability	O
to	O
affect	O
those	O
returns	O
through	O
its	O
power	O
over	O
the	O
entity.	O

Where	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
holds	O
less	O
than	O
a	O
majority	O
of	O
the	O
voting	O
rights	O
,	O
other	O
relevant	O
factors	O
are	O
considered	O
in	O
assessing	O
whether	O
power	O
over	O
the	O
entity	O
exists.	O

Factors	O
considered	O
include	O
rights	O
arising	O
from	O
other	O
contractual	O
arrangements	O
,	O
any	O
contractual	O
arrangements	O
with	O
other	O
vote	O
holders	O
as	O
well	O
as	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
’	O
s	O
voting	O
and	O
potential	O
voting	O
rights.	O

The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
reassesses	O
whether	O
it	O
controls	O
an	O
entity	O
if	O
facts	O
and	O
circumstances	O
indicate	O
that	O
there	O
has	O
been	O
a	O
change	O
in	O
one	O
of	O
the	O
factors	O
which	O
indicate	O
control.	O

Subsidiaries	O
are	O
consolidated	O
from	O
the	O
date	O
on	O
which	O
control	O
is	O
assessed	O
to	O
exist	O
until	O
the	O
date	O
that	O
control	O
ceases.	O

The	O
purchase	O
method	O
of	O
accounting	O
is	O
used	O
to	O
account	O
for	O
the	O
acquisition	O
of	O
subsidiaries	O
by	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity.	O

Intercompany	O
transactions	O
,	O
balances	O
and	O
unrealised	O
gains	O
and	O
losses	O
on	O
transactions	O
between	O
companies	O
controlled	O
by	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
are	O
eliminated	O
on	O
consolidation.	O

)	O

31	O
December	O
2016.	O

The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
has	O

all	O
of	O
the	O

,	O

or	O

has	O

’	O
s	O

year.	O

(	O
ii	O
)	O

of	O
Standards	O
The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
has	O
not	O

any	O

to	O
early	O

AASB9	O
Financial	O
Instruments.	O

(	O
iii	O
)	O
Issued	O
Standards	O
and	O
pronouncements	O
not	O
early	O
adopted	O
At	O
the	O

of	O

the	O
following	O
has	O
been	O

were	O
not	O
yet	O
effective.	O

AASB	O
15	O
Revenue	O
from	O
Contracts	O
with	O
Customers	O
AASB	O
15	O
changes	O
the	O
timing	O
(	O
and	O
in	O
some	O
case	O
,	O
the	O
quantum	O
)	O
of	O
revenue	O
recognised	O
from	O
customers.	O

Currently	O
revenue	O
for	O
domestic	O
sales	O
is	O
recognised	O
when	O
the	O
concentrates	O
are	O
delivered	O
to	O
the	O
customers	O
’	O
premises	O
,	O
which	O
is	O
the	O
point	O
when	O
the	O
customer	O
takes	O
over	O
the	O
risk	O
and	O
rewards	O
of	O
ownership	O
transfer.	O

The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
’	O
s	O
assessment	O
indicates	O
that	O
under	O
AASB	O
15	O
,	O
revenue	O
will	O
continued	O
to	O
be	O
recognised	O
on	O
the	O
same	O
basis	O
when	O
the	O
customer	O
obtains	O
control	O
of	O
the	O
concentrates.	O

Revenue	O
for	O
export	O
sales	O
is	O
currently	O
recognised	O
when	O
shipments	O
of	O
concentrates	O
are	O
loaded	O
on	O
to	O
the	O
vessel	O
as	O
the	O
risk	O
and	O
reward	O
of	O
ownership	O
is	O
transferred	O
to	O
the	O
customer	O
at	O
that	O
point.	O

The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
’	O
s	O
assessment	O
under	O
AASB	O
15	O
indicates	O
that	O
the	O
export	O
contracts	O
are	O
made	O
up	O
of	O
two	O
performance	O
obligations.	O

The	O
first	O
obligation	O
to	O
deliver	O
the	O
concentrates	O
to	O
the	O
port	O
of	O
shipment	O
and	O
the	O
second	O
obligation	O
is	O
to	O
organise	O
shipping	O
of	O
the	O
concentrate	O
,	O
which	O
will	O
be	O
satisfied	O
when	O
concentrates	O
are	O
delivered	O
to	O
the	O
destination	O
port.	O

The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
assessed	O
that	O
revenue	O
relating	O
to	O
the	O
first	O
obligation	O
of	O
delivery	O
of	O
the	O
concentrates	O
to	O
the	O
port	O
of	O
shipping	O
will	O
be	O
recognised	O
at	O
that	O
point	O
and	O
revenue	O
relating	O
to	O
the	O
shipping	O
obligation	O
will	O
be	O
recognised	O
in	O
future	O
periods	O
upon	O
delivery	O
of	O
concentrates.	O

135	O
Glossary	O
Acid	O
rock	O
drainage	O
IUCN	O
Red	O
List	O
Tailings	O
When	O
rock	O
surfaces	O
are	O
exposed	O
to	O
air	O
and	O
The	O
International	O
Union	O
for	O
Conservation	O
of	O
Finely	O
ground	O
materials	O
from	O
which	O
valuable	O
rain	O
,	O
a	O
reaction	O
can	O
occur	O
with	O
the	O
elements	O
Nature	O
and	O
Natural	O
Resources	O
(	O
IUCN	O
)	O
Red	O
List	O
minerals	O
have	O
been	O
largely	O
extracted.	O

in	O
the	O
rock	O
which	O
results	O
in	O
a	O
change	O
in	O
the	O
of	O
threatened	O
species	O
provides	O
information	O
characteristics	O
of	O
the	O
water	O
that	O
runs	O
off.	O

about	O
the	O
characteristics	O
,	O
conservation	O
status	O
Tailings	O
storage	O
facility	O
(	O
TSF	O
)	O
If	O
the	O
rock	O
contains	O
sulphides	O
,	O
oxidation	O
and	O
distribution	O
of	O
flora	O
and	O
fauna	O
species	O
Facility	O
designed	O
for	O
the	O
storage	O
of	O
tailings	O
processes	O
can	O
acidify	O
the	O
water.	O

This	O
process	O
facing	O
the	O
risk	O
of	O
extinction.	O

material	O
produced	O
during	O
ore	O
processing.	O

is	O
known	O
as	O
acid	O
rock	O
drainage.	O

Kilolitre	O
(	O
kL	O
)	O
Total	O
recordable	O
injury	O
Biodiversity	O
One	O
kilolitre	O
is	O
equal	O
to	O
one	O
thousand	O
litres.	O

frequency	O
rate	O
(	O
TRIFR	O
)	O
Biodiversity	O
is	O
the	O
variety	O
of	O
plants	O
,	O
animals	O
TRIFR	O
is	O
the	O
total	O
number	O
of	O
recordable	O
and	O
micro-organisms	O
,	O
their	O
genetic	O
variation	O
Leading	O
my	O
career	O
injuries	O
per	O
million	O
working	O
hours.	O

and	O
the	O
different	O
ecosystems	O
of	O
which	O
A	O
training	O
and	O
mentoring	O
program	O
for	O
‘	O
Recordable	O
Injuries	O
’	O
include	O
those	O
that	O
they	O
inhabit.	O

highperforming	O
females	O
,	O
run	O
collaboratively	O
result	O
in	O
lost	O
time	O
,	O
medical	O
treatment	O
and	O
between	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
,	O
Beach	O
Energy	O
and	O
restricted	O
work	O
injuries.	O

First	O
aid	O
injuries	O
are	O
Carbon	O
dioxide	O
equivalent	O
(	O
CO2-e	O
)	O
Thiess	O
Mining	O
(	O
Prominent	O
Hill	O
)	O
.	O

not	O
included.	O

Carbon	O
dioxide	O
equivalent	O
is	O
a	O
standard	O
measurement	O
used	O
to	O
indicate	O
the	O
impact	O
Lost	O
time	O
injury	O
frequency	O
rate	O
(	O
LTIFR	O
)	O
Waste	O
rock	O
of	O
various	O
greenhouse	O
gas	O
emissions	O
on	O
A	O
Lost	O
Time	O
Injury	O
is	O
a	O
work-related	O
injury	O
or	O
Material	O
such	O
as	O
soils	O
,	O
barren	O
or	O
uneconomic	O
global	O
warming	O
relative	O
to	O
the	O
same	O
illness	O
resulting	O
in	O
an	O
absence	O
from	O
rostered	O
mineralised	O
rock	O
that	O
surrounds	O
a	O
mineral	O
amount	O
of	O
carbon	O
dioxide	O
(	O
CO2	O
)	O
.	O

work	O
of	O
at	O
least	O
one	O
full	O
day	O
or	O
shift	O
any	O
time	O
orebody	O
and	O
must	O
be	O
removed	O
in	O
order	O
to	O
after	O
the	O
day	O
or	O
shift	O
on	O
which	O
the	O
injury	O
mine	O
the	O
ore.	O

Copper	O
concentrate	O
occurred.	O

The	O
LTIFR	O
is	O
the	O
number	O
of	O
LTIs	O
per	O
million	O
hours	O
worked.	O

The	O
Prominent	O
Hill	O
operation	O
produces	O
copper	O
concentrate.	O

This	O
is	O
a	O
fine-grained	O
Megalitre	O
(	O
ML	O
)	O
material	O
that	O
contains	O
a	O
percentage	O
of	O
One	O
megalitre	O
is	O
equal	O
to	O
one	O
million	O
litres.	O

copper	O
,	O
gold	O
and	O
other	O
minerals	O
which	O
has	O
been	O
concentrated	O
to	O
increase	O
its	O
copper	O
Significant	O
community	O
issues	O
concentration	O
through	O
the	O
removal	O
of	O
waste	O
Key	O
concerns	O
raised	O
by	O
local	O
community	O
materials.	O

Copper	O
concentrate	O
is	O
used	O
by	O
stakeholders	O
that	O
are	O
a	O
result	O
of	O
or	O
strongly	O
smelters	O
to	O
produce	O
copper	O
in	O
its	O
metal	O
form.	O

influenced	O
by	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
’	O
activities	O
within	O
Footprint	O
operational	O
control.	O

The	O
area	O
disturbed	O
by	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
’	O
Significant	O
incidents	O
operations	O
and	O
activities.	O

Any	O
occurrence	O
that	O
has	O
actually	O
resulted	O
Global	O
Reporting	O
Initiative	O
(	O
GRI	O
)	O
in	O
or	O
had	O
the	O
potential	O
to	O
result	O
in	O
consequences	O

intersection	O
lies	O
to	O
the	O
south	O
of	O
the	O
Lady	O
Harriet	O

metre	O
split	O
assays	O
will	O

this	O
composite	O
assay	O
when	O
received.	O

4	O
:	O

of	O

current	O
resource	O
block	O

exploration	O

(	O

KWR131	O

Lady	O
Harriet	O
Systems.	O

no	O

Lady	O

Forward-Looking	O
Statements	O
This	O
document	O
may	O
include	O
forward-looking	O
statements.	O

Forward-looking	O
statements	O
include	O
,	O
but	O
are	O
not	O
limited	O
to	O
,	O
statements	O
concerning	O
Kingwest	O
Resources	O
Limited	O
’	O
s	O
planned	O
exploration	O
program	O
and	O
other	O
statements	O
that	O
are	O
not	O
historical	O
facts.	O

When	O
used	O
in	O
this	O
document	O
,	O
the	O
words	O
such	O
as	O
"could	O
,	O
"	O
"plan	O
,	O
"	O
"expect	O
,	O
"	O
"intend	O
,	O
"	O
"may	O
”	O
,	O
"potential	O
,	O
"	O
"should	O
,	O
"	O
and	O
similar	O
expressions	O
are	O
forward-looking	O
statements.	O

Although	O
Kingwest	O
believes	O
that	O
its	O
expectations	O
reflected	O
in	O
these	O
forward-	O
looking	O
statements	O
are	O
reasonable	O
,	O
such	O
statements	O
involve	O
risks	O
and	O
uncertainties	O
and	O
no	O
assurance	O
can	O
be	O
given	O
that	O
further	O
exploration	O
will	O
result	O
in	O
the	O
estimation	O
of	O
a	O
Mineral	O
Resource.	O

Competent	O
Person	O

information	O
in	O
this	O
report	O
that	O
relates	O
to	O
Exploration	O
results	O
is	O
based	O
on	O
information	O
compiled	O
by	O

ABOUT	O
THE	O
MGP	O
and	O
GGP	O
Menzies	O
is	O
one	O
of	O
Western	O
Australia	O
’	O
s	O
major	O
historic	O
gold	O
fields.	O

Located	O
130km	O
north	O
of	O
the	O
globally	O
significant	O
gold	O
deposits	O
of	O
Kalgoorlie	O
(	O
Figure	O
5	O
)	O
.	O

The	O
MGP	O
covers	O
a	O
contiguous	O
land	O
package	O
over	O
a	O
strike	O
length	O
in	O
excess	O
of	O
15km.	O

Within	O
the	O
MGP	O
a	O
series	O
of	O
structurally	O
controlled	O
high-grade	O
gold	O
deposits	O
have	O
been	O
historically	O
mined	O
and	O
display	O
extensive	O
exploration	O
potential	O
for	O
high-grade	O
extensions.	O

Modern	O
exploration	O
since	O
closure	O
over	O
20	O
years	O
ago	O
has	O
been	O
limited.	O

The	O
MGP	O
has	O
recorded	O
historical	O
production	O
of	O
643	O
,	O
200	O
oz	O
@	O
22.5g/t	O
Au1	O
from	O
underground	O
(	O
U/G	O
)	O
between	O
1895	O
and	O
1943	O
plus	O
145	O
,	O
000	O
oz	O
@	O
2.6g/t	O
Au1	O
open	O
cut	O
between	O
1995	O
and	O
1999	O
,	O
for	O
a	O
total	O
of	O
787	O
,	O
200	O
oz	O
@	O
18.9g/t1	O
Au.	O

The	O
MGP	O
is	O
hosted	O
along	O
the	O
Menzies	O
Shear	O
Zone.	O

All	O
deposits	O
lie	O
within	O
granted	O
Mining	O
Leases	O
and	O
are	O
100%	O
owned	O
by	O
KWR.	O

Current	O
mineral	O
resources	O
total	O
320	O
,	O
000	O
oz	O
@	O
2.1g/t	O
Au	O
(	O
Table	O
3	O
)	O
.	O

Importantly	O
the	O
MGP	O
lies	O
on	O
the	O
Goldfields	O
Highway	O
,	O
has	O
power	O
and	O
water	O
and	O
is	O
within	O
trucking	O
distance	O
of	O
numerous	O
Gold	O
Processing	O
Plants.	O

The	O
GGP	O
is	O
located	O
approximately	O
40km	O
south	O
of	O
KWR	O
’	O
s	O
Menzies	O
Gold	O
Project	O
(	O
MGP	O
)	O
and	O
90km	O
north	O
of	O
Kalgoorlie.	O

The	O
GGP	O
is	O
a	O
contiguous	O
land	O
package	O
covering	O
approximately	O
125	O
square	O
km	O
over	O
a	O
strike	O
length	O
in	O
excess	O
of	O
25km.	O

Within	O
the	O
GGP	O
a	O
series	O
of	O
structurally	O
controlled	O
high-grade	O
gold	O
deposits	O
have	O
been	O
historically	O
mined	O
and	O
these	O
display	O
extensive	O
exploration	O
potential	O
for	O
high-grade	O
extensions.	O

Modern	O
exploration	O
since	O
closure	O
of	O
the	O
mines	O
over	O
20	O
years	O
ago	O
has	O
been	O
limited.	O

The	O
GGP	O
sits	O
within	O
the	O
Bardoc	O
Tectonic	O
Zone	O
(	O
BTZ	O
)	O
which	O
extends	O
south	O
to	O
Kalgoorlie	O
and	O
north	O
to	O
Menzies.	O

All	O
resources	O
lie	O
within	O
granted	O
Mining	O
Leases	O
and	O
are	O
100%	O
owned	O
by	O
KWR.	O

Importantly	O
the	O
GGP	O
lies	O
only	O
75km	O
north	O
of	O
Kalgoorlie	O
on	O
the	O
Goldfields	O
Highway	O
and	O
is	O
within	O
trucking	O
distance	O
of	O
numerous	O
Gold	O
Processing	O
Plants.	O

Appendix	O
1	O
:	O
JORC	O

Table	O
1	O
Section	O
1	O
Sampling	O
Techniques	O
and	O
Data	O
Criteria	O
JORC	O
Code	O
explanation	O
Commentary	O
Sampling	O
•	O

Nature	O
and	O
quality	O
of	O
sampling	O
(	O
eg	O
cut	O
•	O

The	O
H2	O
2020	O
drilling	O
program	O
by	O
Kingwest	O
techniques	O
channels	O
,	O
random	O
chips	O
,	O
or	O
specific	O
specialised	O
Resources	O
(	O
KWR	O
)	O
includes	O
Reverse	O
Circulation	O
industry	O
standard	O
measurement	O
tools	O
(	O
RC	O
)	O
drilling.	O

The	O
majority	O
of	O
drill	O
holes	O
have	O
appropriate	O
to	O
the	O
minerals	O
under	O
a	O
dip	O
of	O
-60	O
°	O

towards	O
the	O
north	O
east.	O

investigation	O
,	O
such	O
as	O
down	O
hole	O
gamma	O
•	O

Industry	O
standard	O
RC	O
drilling	O
and	O
sampling	O
sondes	O
,	O
or	O
handheld	O
XRF	O
instruments	O
,	O
etc	O
)	O
.	O

protocols	O
for	O
lode	O
and	O
supergene	O
gold	O
These	O
examples	O
should	O
not	O
be	O
taken	O
as	O
deposits	O
have	O
been	O
utilised	O
throughout	O
the	O
limiting	O
the	O
broad	O
meaning	O
of	O
sampling.	O

campaign.	O

•	O

Include	O
reference	O
to	O
measures	O
taken	O
to	O
ensure	O
•	O

RC	O
holes	O
were	O
sampled	O
using	O
4m	O

CSIRO	O
research	O
project	O
progressed	O
during	O
FY21	O
involving	O
an	O
analysis	O
of	O
the	O
Weednanna	O
Au-Fe	O
deposit	O
and	O
characterisation	O
of	O
its	O
mineralogy	O
and	O
geochronology	O
from	O
selected	O
drill	O
samples.	O

Travel	O
restrictions	O
imposed	O
due	O
to	O
the	O
Covid-19	O
virus	O
continued	O
to	O
cause	O
disruptions	O
to	O
corporate	O
and	O
exploration	O
activities	O
during	O
FY21.	O

Personnel	O
continue	O
to	O
work	O
remotely	O
from	O
the	O
Corporate	O
office	O
and	O
access	O
to	O
South	O
Australian	O
exploration	O
locations	O
was	O
restricted	O
due	O
to	O
interstate	O
travel	O
restrictions	O
and	O
quarantine	O
requirements.	O

Thankfully	O
,	O
going	O
forward	O
,	O
it	O
looks	O
like	O
an	O
easing	O
of	O
such	O
restrictions	O
is	O
on	O
the	O
horizon	O
and	O
we	O
are	O
hoping	O
to	O
be	O
able	O
to	O
get	O
back	O
to	O
something	O
akin	O
to	O
business	O
as	O
usual.	O

like	O
to	O

1REVIEW	O

SOUTH	O
AUSTRALIAN	O
EXPLORATION	O
WILCHERRY	O
PROJECT	O
(	O
100%	O
)	O
The	O
Wilcherry	O
Project	O
is	O
located	O
within	O
the	O
southern	O
region	O
of	O
the	O
Gawler	O
Craton	O
(	O
Figure	O
1	O
)	O
on	O
the	O
northern	O
Eyre	O
Peninsula	O
,	O
40	O
km	O
north	O
of	O
Kimba	O
in	O
South	O
Australia.	O

Wilcherry	O
comprises	O
seven	O
exploration	O
licences	O
covering	O
1	O
,	O
484	O
km2	O
which	O
are	O
prospective	O
for	O
gold	O
and	O
base	O
metals.	O

Figure1.	O

Wilcherry	O
Project	O
location	O
Weednanna	O
gold-iron	O
Deposit	O
Weednanna	O
is	O
the	O
most	O
advanced	O
gold	O
and	O
iron	O
deposit	O
at	O
the	O
Wilcherry	O
Hill	O
project.	O

During	O
the	O
year	O
ending	O
June	O
2021	O
,	O
Metallurgical	O
testwork	O
was	O
completed	O
on	O
the	O
Weednanna	O
gold	O
deposit	O
and	O
used	O
to	O
complete	O
the	O
preliminary	O
design	O
of	O
a	O
250	O
,	O
000	O
tonne	O
per	O
annum	O
processing	O
plant.	O

Several	O
other	O
projects	O
continued	O
throughout	O
the	O
year	O
in	O
support	O
of	O
preparation	O
of	O
the	O
Mine	O
Lease	O
Proposal	O
(	O
MLP	O
)	O
document	O
for	O
submission	O
to	O
the	O
South	O
Australian	O
Department	O
for	O
Energy	O
and	O
Mines.	O

This	O
is	O
one	O
of	O
the	O
key	O
approvals	O
document	O
for	O
mining	O
and	O
processing	O
to	O
be	O
undertaken	O
at	O
Weednanna.	O

of	O
baseline	O
data	O
continued	O
throughout	O
the	O
year	O
including	O
flora	O
and	O
fauna	O
surveys	O
,	O
surface	O

underground	O
water	O

be	O
incorporated	O
into	O
the	O
Mine	O

Application.	O

Reverse	O
Circulation	O
(	O
RC	O
)	O
drilling	O
continued	O
to	O
increase	O
the	O
geological	O
confidence	O
in	O
the	O
Weednanna	O
deposit	O
and	O
increase	O
the	O

of	O
ore	O
in	O
the	O
measured	O
and	O
indicated	O
resource	O
categories.	O

Following	O
two	O
RC	O

programs	O
(	O
detailed	O
below	O
)	O
,	O
the	O
Weednanna	O
gold	O

estimate	O

and	O
a	O
maiden	O

Mineral	O

prepared.	O

g/t	O

of	O

Analysis	O
of	O
RC	O
drilling	O
Since	O
2017	O
,	O
Alliance	O
has	O
drilled	O
405	O

5	O

414	O

Weednanna	O

to	O
test	O
for	O
economic	O
concentrations	O
of	O
gold	O
and	O
Iron.	O

Gold	O
at	O
the	O
Weednanna	O
Deposit	O
is	O
located	O
adjacent	O
to	O
,	O
and	O
on	O
the	O
margins	O
of	O
,	O
ironstone	O
and	O
magnetite-rich	O
skarn.	O

In	O
late	O
2019	O
,	O
Alliance	O
reviewed	O
the	O
iron	O
ore	O
potential	O
of	O
Weednanna	O
and	O
commenced	O
selectively	O
analysing	O
Alliance	O
gold	O
drilling	O
sample	O
pulps	O
associated	O
with	O
ironstone	O
and	O
magnetite	O
skarn	O
for	O
an	O
extended	O
iron	O
ore	O
suite	O
of	O
elements	O
and	O
compounds	O
consisting	O
of	O
Fe	O
,	O
SiO	O
,	O
Al	O
O	O
,	O
CaO	O
,	O
MgO	O
,	O
MnO	O
,	O
P	O
,	O
2	O
2	O
3	O
S	O
,	O
K	O
O	O
,	O
Na	O
O	O
,	O
TiO	O
,	O
Cu	O
,	O
Ni	O
,	O
Co	O
,	O
Cr	O
,	O
Pb	O
,	O
Zn	O
,	O
As	O
,	O
Sn	O
,	O
Sr	O
,	O
Zr	O
,	O
Ba	O
,	O
V	O
,	O
Cl	O
and	O
LOI.	O

Where	O
possible	O
1m	O
split	O
2	O
2	O
2	O
samples	O
were	O
selected	O
,	O
but	O
in	O
some	O
cases	O
where	O
1m	O
samples	O
were	O
not	O
available	O
,	O
4m	O
composite	O
scoop	O
samples	O
were	O
re-analysed.	O

5All	O
significant	O
iron	O
assay	O
results	O
were	O
reported	O
to	O
the	O
ASX	O
in	O
an	O
announcement	O
dated	O
31	O
August	O
2020	O
in	O
preparation	O
for	O
estimation	O
of	O
an	O
iron	O
mineral	O
resource.	O

Alliance	O
has	O
focussed	O
on	O
producing	O
a	O
Direct	O
Shipping	O
Ore	O
(	O
DSO	O
)	O
without	O
the	O
need	O
for	O
onsite	O
beneficiation.	O

Project	O
Work	O
A	O
small	O
weather	O
station	O
and	O
four	O
dust	O
monitoring	O
stations	O
were	O
installed	O
at	O
Weednanna	O
during	O
the	O
year	O
to	O
collect	O
baseline	O
environmental	O
data	O
to	O
build	O
the	O
pre-mining	O
environmental	O
model	O
for	O
the	O
planned	O
mining	O
area.	O

Data	O
collection	O
and	O
analysis	O
continued	O
throughout	O
the	O
year	O
building	O
our	O
baseline	O
model	O
and	O
shall	O
continue	O
throughout	O
the	O
life	O
of	O
the	O
project	O
with	O
data	O
recorded	O
used	O
to	O
manage	O
mine	O
outputs	O
against	O
the	O
stated	O
performance.	O

Alliance	O
has	O
commenced	O
a	O
two-stage	O
research	O
project	O
with	O
the	O
CSIRO	O
to	O
better	O
understand	O
the	O
paragenesis	O
of	O
the	O
Weednanna	O
Au-Fe	O
deposit	O
and	O
develop	O
mineralogical	O
or	O
geochemical	O
tools	O
to	O
assist	O
with	O
targeting	O
future	O
exploration.	O

Stage	O
1	O
of	O
the	O
project	O
consists	O
of	O
mapping	O
the	O
distribution	O
of	O
alteration	O
mineralogy	O
around	O
the	O
deposit	O
and	O
linking	O
this	O
to	O
geochemistry	O
and	O
age	O
dating	O
granitic	O
rocks.	O

This	O
phase	O
of	O
research	O
will	O
be	O
complete	O
before	O
the	O
end	O
of	O
2021.	O

Stage	O
2	O
will	O
analyse	O
core	O
collected	O
from	O
6	O
diamond	O
holes	O
to	O
link	O
the	O
mineralogy	O
and	O
geochemistry	O
to	O
the	O
gold	O
and	O
iron	O
mineralising	O
events	O
and	O
determine	O
the	O
age	O
of	O
mineralisation.	O

This	O
work	O
will	O
continue	O
through	O
2022.	O

Evaluation	O
of	O
alternative	O
/	O
Green	O
energy	O
solutions	O
for	O
the	O
Weednanna	O
project	O
commenced	O
with	O
an	O
assessment	O
of	O
the	O
calculated	O
site	O
power	O
draw	O
,	O
power	O
generation	O
options	O
and	O
indicative	O
costs	O
for	O
each	O
option.	O

Options	O
assessed	O
include	O
PV	O
(	O
solar	O
)	O
with	O
Battery	O
storage	O
,	O
Wind	O
generation	O
,	O
conventional	O
diesel	O
generation	O
and	O
combinations	O
of	O
all	O
three	O
options.	O

The	O
selected	O
consultant	O
has	O
completed	O
phase	O
one	O
assessment	O
of	O
options	O
and	O
is	O
progressing	O
more	O
detailed	O
analysis	O
of	O
each	O
combination	O
to	O
reduce	O
power	O
generation	O
costs	O
for	O
the	O
project	O
,	O
in	O
addition	O
to	O
reducing	O
our	O
greenhouse	O
gas	O
emissions	O
from	O
site.	O

Ounces	O
)	O
Measured	O
-	O

-	O

-	O

Indicated	O
590	O
,	O
000	O
4.6	O
88	O
,	O
000	O
Inferred	O
507	O
,	O
000	O
5.7	O
93	O
,	O
000	O
Total	O
1	O
,	O
097	O
,	O
000	O
5.1	O
181	O
,	O
000	O
The	O
reported	O
Mineral	O
Resource	O
is	O
that	O
proportion	O
of	O
gold	O
contained	O
within	O
$2	O
,	O
000	O
AUD	O
pit	O
shells	O
(	O
>0.5	O
g/t	O
gold	O
)	O
and	O
>2.0	O
g/t	O
gold	O
underground	O
potential.	O

The	O
gold	O
mineral	O
resource	O
reported	O
at	O
30	O
June	O
2021	O
contains	O
data	O
from	O
275	O
new	O
drill	O
holes	O
and	O
is	O
calculated	O
with	O
a	O
higher	O
level	O
of	O
geological	O
confidence	O
,	O
represented	O
by	O
a	O
24	O
%	O
increase	O
in	O
the	O
Measured	O
and	O
Indicated	O
resource	O
categories	O
compared	O
to	O
the	O
previous	O
year.	O

A	O
16%	O
decrease	O
in	O
total	O
contained	O
ounces	O
from	O
the	O
previous	O
year	O
is	O
largely	O
attributed	O
to	O
an	O
18	O
%	O
decrease	O
in	O
the	O
average	O
density	O
of	O
the	O
deposit.	O

The	O
previous	O
mineral	O
resource	O
,	O
completed	O
in	O
2018	O
,	O
estimated	O
average	O
density	O
values	O
for	O
each	O
gold	O
domain	O
using	O
a	O
database	O
consisting	O
of	O
1	O
,	O
123	O
specific	O
gravity	O
measurements.	O

However	O
,	O
recognising	O
the	O
heterogeneous	O
nature	O
of	O
the	O
skarn-altered	O
meta-	O
sediments	O
that	O
host	O
much	O
of	O
the	O
gold	O
at	O
Weednanna	O
,	O
Alliance	O
continued	O
to	O
collect	O
density	O
measurements	O
and	O
increased	O
the	O
size	O
of	O
the	O
density	O
database	O
to	O
9	O
,	O
715	O
specific	O
gravity	O
measurements.	O

The	O
outcome	O
of	O
this	O
work	O
resulted	O
in	O
a	O
material	O
decrease	O
in	O
the	O
average	O
density	O
of	O
the	O
deposit	O
from	O
3.58	O
SG	O
to	O
2.95	O
SG.	O

The	O
net	O
outcome	O
is	O
a	O
21	O
,	O
000	O
ounce	O
gain	O
in	O
high	O
geological	O
confidence	O
Measured	O
and	O
Indicated	O
Resources	O
and	O
a	O
49	O
,	O
500	O
ounce	O
reduction	O
in	O
low	O
geological	O
confidence	O
Inferred	O
Resources.	O

The	O
Company	O
had	O
not	O
completed	O
an	O
Iron	O
Mineral	O
Resource	O
Estimate	O
for	O
the	O
Weednanna	O
Deposit	O
as	O
at	O
30	O
June	O
2020.	O

Ore	O
Reserves	O
The	O
Company	O
did	O
not	O
hold	O
any	O
Ore	O
Reserves	O
at	O
30	O
June	O
2020.	O

9COMPLIANCE	O
STATEMENT	O

to	O

ended	O
30	O
June	O
2021	O
,	O
but	O
does	O
not	O
include	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
and	O
the	O
auditor	O
’	O
s	O
report	O
thereon	O
,	O
which	O
we	O
obtained	O
prior	O
to	O
the	O
date	O
of	O
this	O
auditor	O
’	O
s	O
report	O
,	O
and	O
the	O
Chairman	O
’	O
s	O
address	O
,	O
review	O
of	O
operations	O
and	O
tenement	O
schedule	O
reports	O
,	O
which	O
are	O
expected	O
to	O
be	O
made	O
available	O
to	O
us	O
after	O
that	O
date.	O

Our	O
opinion	O
on	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
does	O
not	O
cover	O
the	O
other	O
information	O
and	O
we	O
do	O
not	O
express	O
any	O
form	O
of	O
assurance	O
conclusion	O
thereon.	O

In	O
connection	O
with	O
our	O
audit	O
of	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
,	O
our	O
responsibility	O
is	O
to	O
read	O
the	O
other	O
information	O
and	O
,	O
in	O
doing	O
so	O
,	O
consider	O
whether	O
the	O
other	O
information	O
is	O
materially	O
inconsistent	O
with	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
or	O
our	O
knowledge	O
obtained	O
in	O
the	O
audit	O
or	O
otherwise	O
appears	O
to	O
be	O
materially	O
misstated.	O

If	O
,	O
based	O
on	O
the	O
work	O
we	O
have	O
performed	O
,	O
we	O
conclude	O
that	O
there	O
is	O
a	O
material	O
misstatement	O
of	O
this	O
other	O
information	O
,	O
we	O
are	O
required	O
to	O
report	O
that	O
fact.	O

We	O
have	O
nothing	O
to	O
report	O
in	O
this	O
regard.	O

When	O
we	O
read	O
the	O
Chairman	O
’	O
s	O
address	O
,	O
review	O
of	O
operations	O
and	O
tenement	O
schedule	O
reports	O
,	O
if	O
we	O
conclude	O
that	O
there	O
is	O
a	O
material	O
misstatement	O
therein	O
,	O
we	O
are	O
required	O
to	O
communicate	O
the	O
matter	O
to	O
the	O
directors	O
and	O
will	O
request	O
that	O
it	O
is	O
corrected.	O

If	O
it	O
is	O
not	O
corrected	O
,	O
we	O
will	O
seek	O
to	O
have	O
the	O
matter	O
appropriately	O
brought	O
to	O
the	O
attention	O
of	O
users	O
for	O
whom	O
our	O
report	O
is	O
prepared.	O

Responsibilities	O
of	O
the	O
directors	O
for	O
the	O
Financial	O
Report	O
The	O
directors	O
of	O
the	O
Company	O
are	O
responsible	O
for	O
the	O
preparation	O
of	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
that	O
gives	O
a	O
TRUE	O
and	O
fair	O
view	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
Australian	O
Accounting	O
Standards	O
and	O
the	O
Corporations	O
Act	O
2001	O
and	O
for	O
such	O
internal	O
control	O
as	O
the	O
directors	O
determine	O
is	O
necessary	O
to	O
enable	O
the	O
preparation	O
of	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
that	O
gives	O
a	O
TRUE	O
and	O
fair	O
view	O
and	O
is	O
free	O
from	O
material	O
misstatement	O
,	O
whether	O
due	O
to	O
fraud	O
or	O
error.	O

In	O
preparing	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
,	O
the	O
directors	O
are	O
responsible	O
for	O
assessing	O
the	O
ability	O
of	O
the	O
Group	O
to	O
continue	O
as	O
a	O
going	O
concern	O
,	O
disclosing	O
,	O
as	O
applicable	O
,	O
matters	O
related	O
to	O
going	O
concern	O
and	O
using	O
the	O
going	O
concern	O
basis	O
of	O
accounting	O
unless	O
the	O
directors	O
either	O
intend	O
to	O
liquidate	O
the	O
Group	O
or	O
to	O
cease	O
operations	O
,	O
or	O
has	O
no	O
realistic	O
alternative	O
but	O
to	O
do	O
so.	O

Auditor	O
’	O
s	O
responsibilities	O
for	O
the	O
audit	O
of	O
the	O
Financial	O
Report	O
Our	O
objectives	O
are	O
to	O
obtain	O
reasonable	O
assurance	O
about	O
whether	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
as	O
a	O
whole	O
is	O
free	O
from	O
material	O
misstatement	O
,	O
whether	O
due	O
to	O
fraud	O
or	O
error	O
,	O
and	O
to	O
issue	O
an	O
auditor	O
’	O
s	O
report	O
that	O
includes	O
our	O
opinion.	O

Reasonable	O
assurance	O
is	O
a	O
high	O
level	O
of	O
assurance	O
,	O
but	O
is	O
not	O
a	O
guarantee	O
that	O
an	O
audit	O
conducted	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
the	O
Australian	O
Auditing	O
Standards	O
will	O
always	O
detect	O
a	O
material	O
misstatement	O
when	O
it	O
exists.	O

Misstatements	O
can	O
arise	O
from	O
fraud	O
or	O
error	O
and	O
are	O
considered	O
material	O
if	O
,	O
individually	O
or	O
in	O
the	O
aggregate	O
,	O
they	O
could	O
reasonably	O
be	O
expected	O
to	O
influence	O
the	O
economic	O
decisions	O
of	O
users	O
taken	O
on	O
the	O
basis	O
of	O
this	O
financial	O
report.	O

A	O
further	O
description	O
of	O
our	O
responsibilities	O
for	O
the	O
audit	O
of	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
is	O
located	O
at	O

Auditing	O
and	O
Assurance	O
Standards	O
Board	O
website	O

The	O

gold	O
prospect	O
is	O
situated	O
on	O
the	O
eastern	O
margin	O
of	O
a	O

intrusion	O

Burns	O

The	O

does	O
not	O

but	O
features	O
a	O
distinctive	O
annular	O
aeromagnetic	O
and	O
gravity	O

signature	O
(	O
Figure	O
2	O
)	O
.	O

has	O
not	O

between	O

larger	O
Burns	O
intrusion	O

intersected	O
at	O
Burns	O

consider	O
there	O

between	O

high	O

to	O

that	O
defined	O
multiple	O
Burns	O
look	O
alike	O
magnetic	O
anomalies	O
over	O
a	O
3000m	O
trend	O
(	O
Figure	O
2	O
)	O
,	O
known	O
as	O
the	O
Burns	O
Corridor	O
triggered	O
the	O
Company	O
to	O
commence	O
a	O
staged	O
drilling	O
program	O
to	O
assess	O
the	O
limits	O
of	O
the	O
Burns	O
mineral	O
system.	O

Stage	O
1	O
of	O
the	O
program	O
involved	O
drilling	O
land-based	O
targets	O
using	O
an	O
RC	O
rig	O
,	O

stage	O
2	O

a	O

rig	O
to	O

targets	O
(	O

,	O
Lovejoy	O
)	O
in	O

Randall.	O

5	O
|	O
P	O
age	O
ASX	O
Announcement	O
3	O
November	O
2021	O
An	O
image	O
from	O
the	O
new	O
aeromagnetic	O
survey	O
(	O
Figure	O
2	O
)	O
provided	O
greater	O
clarity	O
and	O
detail	O
than	O
the	O
old	O
(	O
pre	O
2000	O
era	O
)	O
data.	O

This	O
highlights	O
the	O
annular	O
magnetic	O
anomaly	O
surrounding	O
the	O
interpreted	O
Burns	O
Intrusion	O
and	O
a	O
string	O
of	O
six	O
magnetic	O
anomalies	O
to	O
the	O
east	O
that	O
define	O
a	O
distinct	O
,	O
Burns-like	O
magnetic	O
corridor	O
(	O
Figure	O
2	O
)	O
.	O

These	O
anomalies	O
form	O
a	O
3000m	O
trend	O
,	O
that	O
includes	O
Burns	O
and	O
extends	O
out	O
beneath	O
Lake	O
Randall.	O

The	O
Company	O
interprets	O
that	O
the	O
anomalies	O
represent	O
magnetite	O
alteration	O
zones	O
within	O
and	O
surrounding	O
porphyry	O
dioritic	O
intrusions	O
that	O
are	O
additional	O
to	O
,	O
and	O
similar	O
in	O
style	O
to	O
,	O
Burns	O
The	O
largest	O
and	O
northernmost	O
magnetic	O
anomaly	O
,	O
designated	O
Lovejoy	O
,	O
lies	O
beneath	O
Lake	O
Randall	O
(	O
Figures	O
2	O
)	O
.	O

Lovejoy	O
has	O
a	O
coincident	O
,	O
positive	O
gravity	O
anomaly	O
(	O
refer	O
Figure	O
4	O
LEX	O
ASX	O
release	O
28	O
July	O
2021	O
)	O
is	O
of	O
a	O
similar	O
character	O
to	O
Burns.	O

In	O
October	O
the	O
stage	O
1	O
“	O
onshore	O
”	O
RC	O
drilling	O
program	O
was	O
completed.	O

A	O
total	O
of	O
17	O
angled	O
holes	O
(	O
Table	O
2	O
)	O
for	O
3336m	O
evaluated	O
6	O
magnetic	O
anomalies	O
,	O
including	O
six	O
holes	O
at	O
Burns	O
(	O
Figure	O
2	O
)	O
.	O

Hole	O
depths	O
ranged	O
from	O
120m	O
to	O
258m	O
,	O
with	O
an	O
average	O
depth	O
of	O
200m.	O

This	O
program	O
included	O
one	O
vertical	O
hole	O
(	O
LEFR307	O
)	O
drilled	O
into	O
the	O
main	O
Burns	O
Intrusion.	O

The	O
nine	O
RC	O
holes	O
evaluating	O
the	O
Smithers	O
,	O
Flanders	O
,	O
Skinner	O
and	O
Lovejoy	O
magnetic	O
anomalies	O
up	O
to	O
2000m	O
north	O
of	O
Burns	O
all	O
intersected	O
altered	O
diorite	O
and	O
basalt	O
similar	O
to	O
that	O
observed	O
at	O
Burns.	O

The	O
strongest	O
alteration	O
in	O
dioritic	O
porphyry	O
was	O
intersected	O
in	O
holes	O
at	O
Lovejoy	O
and	O
Skinnner.	O

Holes	O
LEFR296	O
and	O
297	O
are	O
on	O
the	O
western	O
margin	O
of	O
Lovejoy.	O

The	O
strong	O
magnetic	O
anomaly	O
beneath	O
Lake	O
Randall	O
is	O
yet	O
to	O
be	O
tested.	O

Samples	O
were	O

in	O
17	O
laboratory	O
jobs	O
(	O
one	O
for	O
each	O
drill	O

)	O
to	O

for	O
analysis	O
with	O
results	O
expected	O
in	O
December.	O

drill	O
holes	O
were	O
prioritised	O
for	O
analysis	O
and	O
results	O
for	O
hole	O
LEFR297	O
at	O
Lovejoy	O
have	O

and	O
validated	O
(	O
Table	O
4	O
)	O
.	O

Hole	O
LEFR297	O
(	O
Figure	O
5	O
)	O
intersected	O
significant	O
intervals	O
of	O
hematite	O
silica	O
altered	O
porphyry	O
and	O
associated	O
Cu-Au-Ag	O
mineralisation	O
(	O

4	O
)	O
.	O

fault	O

with	O
angular	O

250m	O
(	O

)	O

Geology	O
•	O

Deposit	O
type	O
,	O

and	O
style	O
•	O

The	O
Lefroy	O
Project	O
is	O
located	O
in	O
the	O
southern	O
part	O
of	O
the	O
of	O
mineralisation.	O

Norseman	O
Wiluna	O
Greenstone	O
Belt	O
and	O
straddles	O
the	O

junction	O
of	O
three	O
crustal	O
units	O

the	O

,	O

and	O

Domain.	O

The	O
Lefroy	O
project	O
tenements	O
are	O
mostly	O
covered	O
by	O
alluvial	O
,	O
colluvial	O
and	O
lacustrine	O
material	O
with	O
very	O

was	O

to	O

structure	O

approximately	O

to	O

Well	O
(	O
Wilber/Judy/Suzie	O
)	O

historical	O
intercept	O
was	O
located	O
approximately	O
105m	O
vertically	O
below	O
surface.	O

Latitude	O
’	O
s	O
two	O
drill	O
holes	O
were	O

to	O
test	O
both	O
the	O

of	O

a	O

of	O

ABOUT	O
LATITUDE	O
CONSOLIDATED	O
Latitude	O
Consolidated	O
(	O
ASX	O
:	O
LCD	O
)	O
is	O
a	O
junior	O
gold	O
explorer	O
with	O
a	O
portfolio	O
of	O
exploration	O
projects	O
across	O
Western	O
Australia	O
and	O
South	O
Australia.	O

Latitude	O
’	O
s	O
flagship	O
Murchison	O
Gold	O
Project	O
has	O
a	O
combined	O
343km	O
²	O

landholding	O
in	O
the	O
prolific	O
Murchison	O
Gold	O
Fields	O
of	O
Western	O
Australia	O
and	O
hosts	O
a	O
large	O
high	O
grade	O
1.1Moz	O
Mineral	O
Resource.	O

The	O
company	O
is	O
actively	O
exploring	O
on	O
this	O
tenure	O
while	O
also	O
progressing	O
mining	O
studies	O
to	O
determine	O
the	O
best	O
pathway	O
to	O
production.	O

The	O
Circle	O
Valley	O
project	O
in	O
southern	O
WA	O
sits	O
in	O
the	O
Albany	O
Fraser	O
mobile	O
belt.	O

This	O
belt	O
is	O
also	O
home	O
to	O
the	O
Tropicana	O
gold	O
mine	O
(	O
3Moz	O
past	O
production	O
)	O
.	O

Primary	O
gold	O
mineralisation	O
has	O
been	O
identified	O
in	O
two	O
separate	O
locations	O
at	O
Circle	O
Valley	O
and	O
presents	O
an	O
exciting	O
exploration	O
opportunity	O
for	O
Latitude.	O

The	O
Skye	O
Gold	O
Project	O
in	O
the	O
Gawler	O
Craton	O
in	O
South	O
Australia	O
is	O
located	O
in	O
a	O
region	O
known	O
for	O
plunge-continuous	O
high-grade	O
gold	O
mineralisation	O
such	O
as	O
that	O
seen	O
at	O
nearby	O
Challenger	O
Gold	O
Deposit	O
(	O
1.2Moz	O
past	O
production	O
)	O
.	O

exploration	O
prize	O
in	O
the	O
Gawler	O
Province	O
terrain	O
can	O
be	O
significant	O
,	O
with	O
high-value	O
,	O
high-grade	O
discoveries	O
in	O
the	O
district	O

a	O

for	O
excellent	O
down-plunge	O
continuity	O
of	O
mineralised	O
shoots.	O

Resource	O

to	O
+1.1	O

Ounces	O

.	O

is	O
not	O

of	O
any	O

or	O

that	O

to	O

FORWARD	O
LOOKING	O
STATEMENTS	O

in	O
this	O
report	O
relate	O
to	O
the	O

,	O

to	O
the	O

s	O
financial	O
position	O
,	O
strategy	O
and	O
expected	O
operating	O
results.	O

These	O
forward-looking	O
statements	O
involve	O
known	O
and	O
unknown	O
risks	O
,	O
uncertainties	O
,	O
assumptions	O
and	O
other	O
important	O
factors	O
that	O
could	O
cause	O
the	O
actual	O
results	O
,	O
performance	O
or	O
achievements	O
of	O
the	O

to	O

Actual	O

or	O
results	O
may	O
differ	O
materially	O
from	O
the	O
events	O
or	O

any	O

to	O

Other	O

Dividends	O
Since	O

of	O
the	O

per	O
share	O
on	O
26	O
March	O
2019.	O

record	O
date	O
for	O
entitlement	O
to	O
this	O
dividend	O
is	O
12	O
March	O
2019.	O

OZ	O
Minerals	O
Limited	O
(	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
Limited	O
or	O
the	O
‘	O
Company	O
’	O
)	O
is	O
a	O
company	O
limited	O
by	O
shares	O
that	O
is	O
incorporated	O
and	O
domiciled	O
in	O
Australia.	O

Principal	O
activities	O
The	O
principal	O
activities	O
of	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
during	O
the	O
year	O
were	O
the	O
mining	O
and	O
processing	O
of	O
ore	O
containing	O
copper	O
,	O
gold	O
and	O
silver	O
;	O
sales	O
of	O
concentrate	O
;	O
exploration	O
activities	O
;	O
and	O
the	O
development	O
of	O
mining	O
projects.	O

on	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O

activities	O
can	O

–	O

19	O

(	O
page	O
33	O
)	O
.	O

Significant	O
changes	O
in	O
state	O
of	O
affairs	O
The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
acquired	O
Avanco	O
Resources	O
Limited	O
and	O
its	O
wholly-owned	O
subsidiaries	O
during	O
the	O
year.	O

There	O
have	O
been	O
no	O
other	O
significant	O
changes	O
in	O
the	O
state	O
of	O
affairs	O
reported	O
since	O
prior	O
years	O
(	O
as	O
discussed	O
on	O
pages	O
6	O
–	O

19	O
)	O
.	O

Dividends	O
Since	O
the	O
end	O
of	O
the	O
financial	O
year	O
,	O
the	O
Board	O
of	O
Directors	O
has	O
resolved	O
to	O
pay	O
a	O
fully-franked	O
dividend	O
of	O
15	O
cents	O
per	O
share.	O

This	O
will	O
be	O
paid	O
on	O
26	O
March	O
2019	O
and	O
the	O
date	O
of	O
record	O
for	O
entitlement	O
to	O
this	O
dividend	O
will	O
be	O
12	O
March	O
2019.	O

The	O
financial	O
impact	O

29Environmental	O
regulation	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
and	O
its	O
activities	O
in	O
Australia	O
and	O
overseas	O
are	O
subject	O
to	O
environmental	O
regulations.	O

OZ	O
Minerals	O
’	O
Prominent	O
Hill	O
operations	O
,	O
Carrapateena	O
project	O
,	O
Australian	O
exploration	O
activities	O
and	O
concentrate	O
shipping	O
activities	O
operate	O
under	O
various	O
licences	O
and	O
permits	O
under	O
Commonwealth	O
,	O
state	O
and	O
territory	O
laws	O
,	O
in	O
addition	O
to	O
the	O
licensing	O
and	O
permit	O
arrangements	O
which	O
apply	O
to	O
its	O
overseas	O
activities.	O

OZ	O
Minerals	O
’	O
Antas	O
operations	O
are	O
also	O
subject	O
to	O
environmental	O
regulations	O
under	O
legislation	O
in	O
Brazil.	O

OZ	O
Minerals	O
regularly	O
monitors	O
its	O
compliance	O
with	O
licenses	O
and	O
permits	O
in	O
various	O
ways	O
,	O
including	O
through	O
its	O
own	O
environmental	O
audits	O
as	O
well	O
as	O
those	O
conducted	O
by	O
regulatory	O
authorities	O
and	O
other	O
third	O
parties.	O

OZ	O
Minerals	O
uses	O
a	O
documented	O
process	O
to	O
classify	O
and	O
report	O
any	O
exceedance	O
of	O
a	O
licence	O
or	O
permit	O
condition	O
as	O
well	O
as	O
any	O
incident	O
reportable	O
to	O
the	O
relevant	O
authorities.	O

All	O
instances	O
of	O
reportable	O
environmental	O
non-compliance	O
and	O
significant	O
incidents	O
are	O
reviewed	O
by	O
the	O
Executive	O
Committee	O
and	O
the	O
Sustainability	O
Committee	O
of	O
the	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
Board	O
of	O
Directors	O
as	O
a	O
part	O
of	O
this	O
process.	O

A	O
formal	O
report	O
is	O
also	O
prepared	O
to	O
identify	O
the	O
factors	O
that	O
contributed	O
to	O
the	O
incident	O
or	O
non-compliance	O
and	O
the	O
actions	O
taken	O
to	O
prevent	O
any	O
reoccurrence.	O

During	O
the	O
year	O
,	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
submitted	O
the	O
energy	O
and	O
emissions	O
report	O
to	O
the	O
Clean	O
Energy	O
Regulator	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
the	O
National	O
Greenhouse	O
and	O
Energy	O
Report	O
Act	O
2007	O
(	O
NGER	O
Act	O
)	O
.	O

A	O
limited	O
assurance	O
engagement	O
of	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
’	O
energy	O
and	O
emissions	O
report	O
was	O
conducted	O
by	O
an	O
independent	O
auditor	O
over	O
the	O
emissions	O

production	O
and	O

consumption	O

NGER	O
Act.	O

Insurance	O
and	O
indemnity	O
During	O
the	O
financial	O
year	O
,	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
Limited	O
paid	O
premiums	O
with	O
respect	O
to	O
a	O
contract	O
insuring	O
its	O
directors	O
,	O
officers	O
and	O
related	O
bodies	O
corporate	O
against	O
certain	O
liabilities	O
incurred	O
while	O
acting	O
in	O
that	O
capacity.	O

The	O
insurance	O
contract	O
prohibits	O
disclosure	O
of	O
the	O
liability	O
’	O
s	O
nature	O
and	O
the	O
amount	O
of	O
the	O
insurance	O

The	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
constitution	O
also	O
allows	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
to	O
provide	O

the	O
extent	O

by	O
law	O
,	O
to	O

of	O

its	O

bodies	O

in	O
that	O

of	O

a	O

body	O

work	O
,	O

in	O

Matters	O
subsequent	O
to	O
the	O
end	O
of	O
the	O
financial	O

of	O
15	O
cents	O
per	O
share	O
on	O
26	O
March	O
2019.	O

The	O
record	O
date	O
for	O
entitlement	O
to	O
this	O
dividend	O
is	O
12	O
March	O
2019.	O

$48.4	O
million	O

not	O

subsequent	O

,	O

risk	O

to	O

for	O
the	O

Entity.	O

OZ	O

,	O

of	O
their	O

has	O

.	O

2.2	O
Remuneration	O
consultants	O
The	O
Board	O
of	O
Directors	O
and	O
the	O
People	O
&	O
Remuneration	O
Committee	O
seek	O
and	O
consider	O
advice	O
from	O
independent	O
remuneration	O
consultants	O
to	O
ensure	O
that	O
they	O
have	O
all	O
of	O
the	O
relevant	O
information	O
at	O
their	O
disposal	O
to	O
determine	O
executive	O
KMP	O
remuneration.	O

Remuneration	O
consultant	O
engagement	O
is	O
governed	O
by	O
internal	O
protocols	O
that	O
set	O
the	O
parameters	O
around	O
the	O
interaction	O
between	O
management	O
and	O
consultants	O
to	O
minimise	O
the	O
risk	O
of	O
any	O
undue	O
influence	O
and	O
ensure	O
compliance	O
with	O
the	O
Corporations	O
Act	O
2001.	O

PROTOCOLS	O
Under	O
the	O
protocols	O
adopted	O
by	O
the	O
Board	O
and	O
the	O
People	O
&	O
Remuneration	O
Committee	O
:	O
/	O
remuneration	O
consultants	O
are	O
engaged	O
by	O
and	O
report	O
directly	O
to	O

Questions	O

about	O
executive	O

Total	O
fixed	O
remuneration	O
(	O
TFR	O
)	O
What	O
is	O
included	O
in	O
total	O
fixed	O
remuneration?	O
An	O
executive	O
KMP	O
total	O
fixed	O
remuneration	O
comprises	O
salary	O
and	O
certain	O
other	O
benefits	O
(	O
including	O
statutory	O
superannuation	O
contributions	O
)	O
that	O
may	O
be	O
taken	O
in	O
an	O
agreed	O
form	O
,	O
such	O
as	O
cash	O
,	O
leased	O
motor	O
vehicles	O
and	O
additional	O
superannuation	O
,	O
provided	O
that	O
no	O
extra	O
cost	O
is	O
incurred	O
by	O
the	O
Company	O
for	O
these	O
benefits.	O

When	O
and	O
how	O
is	O
fixed	O
remuneration	O
reviewed?	O
Fixed	O
remuneration	O
is	O
reviewed	O
annually.	O

Any	O
adjustments	O
to	O
the	O
fixed	O
remuneration	O
for	O
the	O
Managing	O
Director	O
and	O
CEO	O
and	O
other	O
executive	O
KMP	O
must	O
be	O

by	O
the	O
Board	O
after	O
recommendations	O
by	O
the	O
People	O
&	O
Remuneration	O
Committee.	O

the	O
year	O
,	O
we	O
also	O
conducted	O
market	O
benchmarking	O
of	O
executive	O
remuneration	O
,	O
mindful	O
of	O
the	O
need	O
to	O
continue	O

our	O

employees	O
in	O
a	O
competitive	O
market	O
as	O
the	O
Company	O
grows.	O

that	O
our	O

was	O

cases	O

our	O

toward	O
50th	O
percentile.	O

Short	O
term	O
incentive	O
(	O
STI	O
)	O
Why	O
does	O
the	O
Board	O
think	O
an	O
STI	O
plan	O
is	O
appropriate?	O
Variable	O
performance-based	O
remuneration	O
strengthens	O
the	O
link	O
between	O
pay	O
and	O
performance.	O

The	O
purpose	O
of	O
these	O
programmes	O
is	O
to	O
make	O
a	O
large	O
proportion	O
of	O
the	O
total	O
market	O
reward	O
package	O
subject	O
to	O
meeting	O
various	O
targets	O
linked	O
to	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
’	O
business	O
objectives.	O

The	O
use	O
of	O
variable	O
performance-based	O
remuneration	O
avoids	O
much	O
higher	O
levels	O
of	O
fixed	O
remuneration	O
and	O
is	O
designed	O
to	O
focus	O
and	O
motivate	O
employees	O
to	O
achieve	O
outcomes	O
beyond	O
the	O
standard	O
expected	O
in	O
the	O
normal	O
course	O
of	O
ongoing	O
employment.	O

reward	O

that	O

variable	O

remuneration	O
is	O
also	O
necessary	O
as	O

in	O
the	O
Australian	O

for	O
executives.	O

54	O
ANNUAL	O
AND	O

3.3	O
LTI	O
performance	O
and	O
outcomes	O
Performance	O
rights	O
granted	O
under	O
the	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
LTI	O
Plan	O
are	O
granted	O
for	O
no	O
consideration.	O

Performance	O
rights	O
carry	O
no	O
dividend	O
or	O
voting	O
rights.	O

One	O
ordinary	O
share	O
in	O
the	O
Company	O
will	O
be	O
allocated	O
on	O
vesting	O
of	O
a	O
performance	O
right.	O

The	O
vesting	O
condition	O
for	O
each	O
grant	O
is	O
the	O
relative	O
TSR	O
performance	O
and	O
absolute	O
share	O
price	O
growth	O
of	O
the	O
Company	O
over	O
the	O
relevant	O
performance	O
period.	O

In	O
general	O
,	O
the	O
executive	O
must	O
also	O
remain	O
employed	O
with	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
for	O
a	O
continuous	O
period	O
of	O
three	O
years	O
from	O
the	O
grant	O
date.	O

Details	O
of	O
the	O
prior	O
awards	O
for	O
relevant	O
executive	O
KMP	O
are	O
set	O
out	O
in	O
the	O
Remuneration	O
Report	O
for	O
the	O
year	O
in	O
which	O
they	O
were	O
granted.	O

Details	O
of	O
the	O
performance	O
rights	O
held	O
by	O
executive	O
KMP	O
that	O
vested	O
or	O
lapsed	O
during	O
the	O
year	O
are	O
set	O
out	O
in	O
Table	O
15.	O

Additional	O
details	O
are	O
set	O
out	O
in	O
Note	O
11	O
to	O
the	O
Financial	O
Statements.	O

3.4	O
2018	O
Alignment	O
plan	O
Performance	O
rights	O
granted	O
under	O
2018	O
Alignment	O
plan	O
are	O
a	O
one-off	O
allocation	O
for	O
retention	O
purposes.	O

Performance	O
rights	O
carry	O
no	O
dividend	O
or	O
voting	O
rights.	O

One	O
ordinary	O
share	O
in	O
the	O
Company	O
will	O
be	O

on	O
vesting	O
of	O
a	O

the	O

rights	O

during	O
the	O
year.	O

(	O
b	O
)	O
The	O
fair	O
values	O
were	O
calculated	O
as	O
at	O
the	O
grant	O
dates.	O

In	O

with	O
the	O
requirements	O
of	O
applicable	O
Accounting	O
Standards	O
,	O
remuneration	O
includes	O
a	O

of	O

notional	O
value	O
of	O
performance	O
rights	O
as	O
compensation	O
granted	O
or	O
outstanding	O
during	O
the	O
year.	O

notional	O
value	O
of	O
performance	O
rights	O
granted	O
as	O
compensation	O
is	O
determined	O
as	O
at	O
the	O
grant	O
date	O
and	O
progressively	O
allocated	O
over	O
the	O
vesting	O
period.	O

The	O
amount	O
included	O
as	O
remuneration	O
is	O
not	O
related	O
to	O
or	O
indicative	O
of	O
the	O
benefit	O
(	O
if	O
any	O
)	O
that	O
individual	O
executives	O
may	O
in	O
fact	O
receive.	O

values	O
were	O
calculated	O
by	O
an	O
external	O
third	O
party	O

on	O
a	O
Monte-Carlo	O
simulation	O
model.	O

6.0	O
Non-executive	O

6.1	O
Non-executive	O
Director	O
remuneration	O
policy	O
Non-executive	O
Director	O
(	O
NED	O
)	O
remuneration	O
is	O
reviewed	O
annually	O
by	O
the	O
Board.	O

NEDs	O
receive	O
a	O
fixed	O
fee	O
remuneration	O
consisting	O
of	O
a	O
base	O
fee	O
rate	O
and	O
additional	O
fees	O
for	O
committee	O
roles.	O

Consistent	O
with	O
best	O
practice	O
,	O
NEDs	O
do	O
not	O
receive	O
any	O
form	O
of	O
equity	O
incentive	O
entitlement	O
,	O
bonuses	O
,	O
options	O
,	O
other	O
incentive	O
payments	O
or	O
retirement	O
benefits.	O

As	O
approved	O
at	O
the	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O

on	O
18	O
July	O
2008	O
,	O
the	O
maximum	O
fees	O
payable	O
per	O
annum	O
is	O
$2	O
,	O
700	O
,	O
000	O
in	O
total.	O

in	O
the	O
2017	O
report	O

during	O
2018	O
the	O
Board	O
undertook	O

review	O
and	O
decided	O
to	O
increase	O
the	O
fees	O
paid	O
to	O
Non	O
Executive	O
Directors	O
and	O
address	O
anomalies	O
as	O
between	O
committees.	O

Fees	O
had	O
not	O
been	O
increased	O
in	O
six	O
years	O
during	O
which	O
the	O
Company	O
has	O
grown	O
in	O
scope	O
and	O

9.0	O
Executive	O
remuneration	O
framework	O
changes	O
The	O
Board	O
believes	O
that	O
executive	O
remuneration	O
is	O
a	O
key	O
enabler	O
of	O
the	O
delivery	O
of	O
the	O
group	O
’	O
s	O
strategy	O
for	O
the	O
benefit	O
of	O
shareholders	O
,	O
customers	O
,	O
employees	O
and	O
our	O
communities.	O

During	O
2018	O
,	O
we	O
undertook	O
a	O
review	O
of	O
executive	O
remuneration	O
,	O
to	O
ensure	O
that	O
the	O
framework	O
remains	O
fit-for-purpose	O
as	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
continues	O
to	O
grow.	O

The	O
result	O
of	O
that	O
review	O
suggested	O
that	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
had	O
an	O
opportunity	O
to	O
create	O
a	O
greater	O
alignment	O
of	O
executive	O
pay	O
outcomes	O
with	O
the	O
shareholder	O
experience	O
and	O
simplify	O
a	O
framework	O
that	O
executives	O
perceived	O
to	O
be	O
complicated	O
and	O
in	O
many	O
cases	O
something	O
they	O
had	O
limited	O
ability	O
to	O
influence.	O

As	O
a	O
result	O
,	O
we	O
have	O
proposed	O
some	O
refinements	O
to	O
the	O
framework	O
in	O
2019	O
that	O
better	O
address	O
our	O
objectives	O
of	O
greater	O
alignment	O
between	O
shareholder	O
and	O
executive.	O

These	O
changes	O
will	O
,	O
if	O
performance	O
targets	O
are	O
met	O
,	O
put	O
equity	O
into	O
the	O
hands	O
of	O
executives	O
earlier	O
and	O
require	O
them	O
to	O
hold	O
it	O
for	O
the	O
long	O
term	O
,	O
increasing	O
the	O
sense	O
of	O
ownership	O
of	O
the	O
Company	O
amongst	O
our	O
executives	O
and	O
encouraging	O
decision	O
making	O
aligned	O
to	O
creating	O
longer	O
term	O
shareholder	O
value.	O

This	O
framework	O
also	O
provides	O
a	O
simple	O
,	O
market-aligned	O
approach	O
which	O
builds	O
on	O
our	O
existing	O
framework	O
and	O
meets	O

of	O
driving	O
greater	O

between	O

AT	O
PROMINENT	O
HILL	O
Prominent	O
Hill	O
runs	O
an	O
extensive	O
recycling	O
program.	O

This	O

program	O
diverts	O
many	O
varying	O

streams	O
from	O
landfill	O

recycled	O
or	O
reused.	O

late	O

of	O
biobin	O
technology	O

to	O
further	O
this	O
philosophy.	O

The	O

food	O

Camp	O
kitchen	O
facilities	O
within	O

bin	O

off	O
site	O

to	O
Adelaide	O

is	O

compost	O
and	O
fertilisers.	O

for	O
feral	O
species.	O
