88	O
ANNUAL	O
AND	O
SUSTAINABILITY	O
REPORT	O
2018S	O
U	O
S	O
T	O
A	O
IN	O
A	O
B	O
IL	O
IT	O
Y	O
R	O
E	O
P	O
O	O
R	O
T	O
How	O
the	O
Standard	O
Defines	O
Limited	O
Assurance	O
and	O
Material	O
Misstatement	O
The	O
procedures	O
performed	O
in	O
a	O
limited	O
assurance	O
engagement	O
vary	O
in	O
nature	O
and	O
timing	O
from	O
,	O
and	O
are	O
less	O
in	O
extent	O
than	O
for	O
a	O
reasonable	O
assurance	O
engagement.	O

Consequently	O
the	O
level	O
of	O
assurance	O
obtained	O
in	O
a	O
limited	O
assurance	O
engagement	O
is	O
substantially	O
lower	O
than	O
the	O
assurance	O
that	O
would	O
have	O
been	O
obtained	O
had	O
a	O
reasonable	O
assurance	O
engagement	O
been	O
performed.	O

Misstatements	O
,	O
including	O
omissions	O
,	O
are	O
considered	O
material	O
if	O
,	O
individually	O
or	O
in	O
the	O
aggregate	O
,	O
they	O
could	O
reasonably	O
be	O
expected	O
to	O
influence	O
relevant	O
decisions	O
of	O
the	O
Directors	O
of	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
Ltd.	O

Use	O
of	O
this	O
Assurance	O
Report	O
This	O
report	O
has	O
been	O
prepared	O
for	O
the	O
Directors	O
of	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
Ltd	O
for	O
the	O
purpose	O
of	O
providing	O
an	O
assurance	O
conclusion	O
on	O
the	O
Selected	O
Sustainability	O
Information	O
and	O
may	O
not	O
be	O
suitable	O
for	O
another	O
purpose.	O

We	O
disclaim	O
any	O
assumption	O
of	O
responsibility	O
for	O
any	O
reliance	O
on	O
this	O
report	O
,	O
to	O
any	O
person	O
other	O
than	O
the	O
Directors	O
of	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
Ltd	O
,	O
or	O
for	O
any	O
other	O
purpose	O
than	O
that	O
for	O
which	O
it	O
was	O
prepared.	O

Management	O
’	O
s	O
responsibility	O
Management	O
are	O
responsible	O
for	O
:	O
/	O
determining	O
that	O
the	O
criteria	O
is	O
appropriate	O
to	O
meet	O
the	O
needs	O
of	O
intended	O
users	O
,	O
being	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
Ltd	O
and	O
their	O
stakeholders	O
;	O
/	O
preparing	O
and	O
presenting	O
the	O
information	O
subject	O
to	O
assurance	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
the	O
criteria.	O

This	O
includes	O
disclosing	O
the	O
criteria	O
,	O
including	O
any	O
significant	O
inherent	O
limitations	O
;	O
/	O
establishing	O
internal	O
controls	O
that	O
enable	O
the	O
preparation	O
and	O
presentation	O
of	O
the	O
information	O
subject	O
to	O
assurance	O
that	O
is	O
free	O
from	O
material	O
misstatement	O
,	O
whether	O
due	O
to	O
fraud	O
or	O
error	O
;	O
/	O
advising	O
us	O
of	O
any	O
known	O
and/or	O
contentious	O
issues	O
relating	O
to	O
the	O
information	O
subject	O
to	O
assurance	O
;	O
and	O
/	O
maintaining	O
integrity	O
of	O
the	O
website.	O

Our	O
Responsibility	O

102	O
ANNUAL	O
AND	O
SUSTAINABILITY	O
REPORT	O
2018F	O
IN	O
A	O
N	O
C	O
IA	O
Notes	O
to	O
the	O
consolidated	O
financial	O
statements	O

R	O
E	O
P	O
O	O
Group	O
performance	O
R	O
T	O
The	O
principal	O
business	O
activities	O
of	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
Limited	O
(	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
or	O
the	O
Company	O
)	O
and	O
its	O
controlled	O
entities	O
(	O
collectively	O
the	O
‘	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
’	O
or	O
the	O
‘	O
Group	O
’	O
)	O
were	O
the	O
mining	O
and	O
processing	O
of	O
ore	O
containing	O
copper	O
,	O
gold	O
and	O
silver	O
,	O
undertaking	O
exploration	O
activities	O
and	O
development	O
of	O
mining	O
projects.	O

The	O
Company	O
is	O
incorporated	O
and	O
domiciled	O
in	O
Australia	O
and	O
limited	O
by	O
shares	O
which	O
are	O
publicly	O
traded	O
on	O
the	O
Australian	O
Securities	O
Exchange.	O

OZ	O
Minerals	O
’	O
registered	O
office	O
relocated	O
to	O
2	O
Hamra	O
Drive	O
,	O
Adelaide	O
Airport	O
,	O
South	O
Australia	O
5950	O
,	O
Australia	O
,	O
effective	O
22	O
June	O
2018.	O

The	O
Consolidated	O
Financial	O
Statements	O
of	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
Limited	O
and	O
its	O
controlled	O
entities	O
for	O
the	O
year	O
ended	O
31	O
December	O
2018	O
:	O
/	O
include	O
general	O
purpose	O
financial	O
statements	O
prepared	O
by	O
a	O
for-profit	O
entity	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
Australian	O
Accounting	O
Standards	O
(	O
AASBs	O
)	O
and	O
the	O
Corporations	O
Act	O
2001	O
,	O
and	O
comply	O
with	O
International	O
Financial	O
Reporting	O
Standards	O
(	O
IFRS	O
)	O
/	O
are	O
presented	O
in	O
Australian	O
dollars	O
which	O
is	O
also	O
the	O
functional	O
currency	O
of	O
its	O
principal	O
operations.	O

The	O
financial	O
statements	O
of	O
the	O
Company	O
include	O
consolidation	O
of	O
its	O
subsidiaries	O
referred	O
to	O
in	O
Note	O
14	O
,	O
including	O
entities	O
acquired	O
on	O
acquisition	O
of	O
Avanco	O
Resources	O
Limited	O
(	O
Avanco	O
)	O
.	O

/	O
have	O
amounts	O
rounded	O
off	O
to	O
within	O
the	O
nearest	O
million	O
dollars	O
to	O
one	O
decimal	O
place	O
unless	O
otherwise	O
stated	O
,	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
Instrument	O
2016/191	O
,	O
issued	O
by	O
the	O
Australian	O
Securities	O
and	O
Investments	O
Commission.	O

The	O
Consolidated	O
Financial	O
Statements	O
have	O
been	O
prepared	O
on	O
a	O
going	O
concern	O
basis	O
and	O
under	O
the	O
historical	O
cost	O
convention	O
,	O
except	O
for	O
the	O
following	O
items	O
which	O
are	O
measured	O
at	O
fair	O
value	O
,	O
or	O
otherwise	O
,	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
the	O
provisions	O
of	O
applicable	O
accounting	O
standards	O
:	O
/	O
financial	O
instruments	O
,	O
including	O
trade	O
receivables	O
/	O
derivative	O
financial	O
instruments	O
/	O
items	O
of	O
inventory	O
and	O
property	O
,	O
plant	O
and	O
equipment	O
which	O
have	O
been	O
written	O
down	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
applicable	O
accounting	O
standards.	O

Other	O
than	O
the	O
final	O
dividend	O
for	O
the	O
year	O
ended	O
31	O
December	O
2018	O
as	O
discussed	O
in	O
Note	O
4	O
,	O
no	O
events	O
have	O
occurred	O
subsequent	O
to	O
the	O
reporting	O
date	O
which	O
have	O
significantly	O
affected	O
or	O
may	O
significantly	O
affect	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
’	O
s	O
operations	O
or	O
results	O
in	O
future	O
years.	O

The	O
presentation	O
of	O
the	O
Statement	O
of	O
Comprehensive	O
Income	O
has	O
been	O
changed	O
to	O
better	O
represent	O
how	O
the	O
business	O
is	O
managed.	O

This	O
change	O
has	O
no	O
impact	O
on	O
the	O
results.	O

Now	O
,	O
financial	O
information	O
is	O
aggregated	O
according	O
to	O
function	O
which	O
gives	O
a	O
better	O
representation	O
of	O
the	O
financial	O
performance	O
of	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Group	O
taking	O
into	O
account	O
the	O
acquisition	O
of	O
Avanco	O
,	O
the	O
advanced	O
stage	O
of	O
Carrapateena	O
and	O
an	O
increasing	O
operational	O
focus.	O

The	O
presentation	O
of	O
the	O
comparative	O
period	O
has	O
also	O
been	O
changed	O
to	O
align	O
with	O
the	O
new	O
presentation.	O

The	O
detail	O
of	O
the	O
reclassifications	O
has	O
not	O
been	O
disclosed	O
as	O
the	O
presentation	O
by	O
nature	O
cannot	O
be	O

Corporate	O
Other	O
corporate	O
activities	O
include	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
’	O
s	O
group	O
office	O
(	O

(	O

)	O

that	O
cannot	O

’	O

)	O
,	O

in	O

and	O

Recognition	O
and	O
measurement	O
of	O
revenue	O
The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
adopted	O
AASB	O
15	O
during	O
the	O
year.	O

The	O
revised	O
accounting	O
policy	O
in	O
respect	O
of	O
revenue	O
is	O
set	O
out	O
below.	O

The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
generates	O
sales	O
revenue	O
primarily	O
from	O
the	O
obligation	O
to	O
transfer	O
concentrate	O
to	O
the	O
buyer	O
and	O
in	O
some	O
cases	O
,	O
based	O
on	O
the	O
commercial	O
terms	O
of	O
the	O
contract	O
,	O
a	O
secondary	O
obligation	O
to	O
deliver	O
it	O
to	O
the	O
customer.	O

Revenue	O
is	O
allocated	O
between	O
the	O
performance	O
obligations	O
and	O
recognised	O
as	O
each	O
performance	O
obligation	O
is	O
met	O
,	O
which	O
for	O
the	O
primary	O
obligation	O
occurs	O
when	O
the	O
concentrate	O
is	O
delivered	O
to	O
a	O
vessel	O
or	O
location	O
and	O
for	O
the	O
secondary	O
obligation	O
,	O
if	O
applicable	O
,	O
when	O
the	O
concentrate	O
is	O
delivered	O
to	O
the	O
customer	O
’	O
s	O
location.	O

Revenue	O
arising	O
from	O
the	O
secondary	O
obligation	O
is	O
immaterial	O
to	O
the	O
Group	O
and	O
aggregated	O
with	O
the	O
primary	O
obligation	O
for	O
disclosure	O
purposes.	O

The	O
Group	O
’	O
s	O
sale	O
of	O
concentrate	O
incurs	O
customary	O
treatment	O
and	O
refining	O
charges	O
and	O
other	O
commercial	O
costs	O
consistent	O
with	O
industry	O
practice.	O

These	O
items	O
are	O
in	O
essence	O
a	O
deduction	O
from	O
the	O
value	O
of	O
metal	O
contained	O
within	O
the	O
concentrate.	O

These	O
items	O
are	O
variable	O
in	O
nature	O
and	O
are	O
accounted	O
for	O
as	O
a	O
deduction	O
to	O
revenue	O
when	O
they	O
are	O
recognised.	O

As	O
is	O
industry	O
practice	O
,	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
typically	O
makes	O
sales	O
whereby	O
the	O
final	O
sales	O
price	O
for	O
the	O
primary	O
performance	O
obligation	O
is	O
determined	O
based	O
on	O
the	O
market	O
price	O
prevailing	O
at	O
a	O
date	O
in	O
the	O
future.	O

Revenue	O
for	O
the	O
primary	O
performance	O
obligation	O
is	O
measured	O
based	O
on	O
the	O
fair	O
value	O
of	O
the	O
consideration	O
specified	O
in	O
a	O
contract	O
with	O
the	O
customer	O
at	O
the	O
time	O
of	O
settling	O
the	O
performance	O
obligation	O
and	O
is	O
determined	O
by	O
reference	O
to	O
forward	O
market	O
prices.	O

Provisional	O
pricing	O
adjustments	O
,	O
which	O
occur	O
between	O
the	O
fair	O
value	O
at	O
the	O
time	O
of	O
settling	O
the	O
primary	O
performance	O
obligation	O
and	O
the	O
final	O
price	O
,	O
are	O
also	O
recorded	O
within	O
revenue.	O

Gains	O
and	O
losses	O
on	O
hedge	O
instruments	O
related	O
to	O
sales	O
contracts	O
are	O
also	O
recorded	O
in	O
revenue	O
and	O
generally	O
offset	O
the	O
movement	O
as	O
a	O
result	O
of	O
provisional	O
pricing	O
adjustments.	O

Income	O

is	O
appropriate.	O

RECOvERABILITY	O
OF	O
DEFERRED	O
TAX	O
ASSETS	O
The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
is	O
subject	O
to	O
income	O
taxes	O
of	O
Australia	O
and	O
jurisdictions	O
where	O
it	O
has	O
foreign	O
operations.	O

Significant	O
judgement	O
is	O
required	O
in	O
the	O
application	O
of	O
income	O
tax	O
legislation	O
to	O
determine	O
the	O
provision	O
for	O
income	O
taxes.	O

There	O
are	O
many	O
transactions	O
and	O
calculations	O
undertaken	O
during	O
the	O
ordinary	O
course	O
of	O
business	O
for	O
which	O
the	O
ultimate	O
tax	O
determination	O
is	O
uncertain	O
,	O
and	O
for	O
which	O
provisions	O
are	O
based	O
on	O
estimated	O
amounts.	O

Where	O
the	O
final	O
tax	O
outcome	O
of	O
these	O
matters	O
is	O
different	O
from	O
the	O
amounts	O
that	O
were	O
initially	O
recorded	O
,	O
such	O
differences	O
will	O
impact	O
the	O
current	O
and	O
deferred	O
tax	O
provision	O
in	O
the	O
period	O
in	O
which	O
the	O
determination	O
is	O
made.	O

Assumptions	O
about	O
the	O
generation	O
of	O
future	O
taxable	O
profits	O
influence	O
the	O
ability	O
of	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
to	O
recognise	O
(	O
or	O
continue	O
to	O
recognise	O
)	O
deferred	O
tax	O
assets.	O

Taxable	O
profit	O
estimates	O
are	O
based	O
on	O
estimated	O
future	O
production	O
and	O
sales	O
volumes	O
,	O
commodity	O
prices	O
,	O
foreign	O
exchange	O
rates	O
,	O
operating	O
costs	O
,	O
restoration	O
costs	O
and	O
capital	O
expenditure.	O

A	O
change	O
in	O
these	O
assumptions	O
may	O
impact	O
the	O
amount	O
of	O
deferred	O
tax	O
assets	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
balance	O
sheet	O
in	O
future	O
periods.	O

Group	O
taxation	O

OZ	O
Minerals	O

principal	O
operations	O
are	O
located	O
in	O
Australia	O
and	O
Brazil.	O

Income	O
tax	O
expense	O
,	O
current	O
tax	O
and	O
deferred	O

balances	O
have	O
been	O
determined	O
based	O
on	O
the	O
tax	O
laws	O
and	O
tax	O
rates	O
applicable	O
in	O
the	O
relevant	O
jurisdiction.	O

Recognition	O
and	O
measurement	O
of	O
income	O
taxes	O
Current	O
tax	O
The	O
tax	O
currently	O
payable	O
is	O
based	O
on	O
taxable	O
profit	O
for	O
the	O
year	O
,	O
using	O
rates	O
enacted	O
or	O
substantively	O
enacted	O
at	O
the	O
reporting	O
date	O
,	O
and	O
any	O
adjustments	O
to	O
tax	O
payable	O
in	O
respect	O
of	O
previous	O
years.	O

Deferred	O
tax	O
Deferred	O
tax	O
assets	O
and	O
liabilities	O
are	O
determined	O
using	O
the	O
balance	O
sheet	O
method	O
which	O
calculates	O
temporary	O
differences	O
based	O
on	O
the	O
difference	O
between	O
the	O
carrying	O
amount	O
of	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
’	O
s	O
assets	O
and	O
liabilities	O
in	O
the	O
balance	O
sheet	O
and	O
their	O
associated	O
tax	O
bases.	O

Deferred	O
tax	O
assets	O
and	O
liabilities	O
are	O
not	O
recognised	O
for	O
temporary	O
differences	O
arising	O
from	O
investments	O
in	O
subsidiaries	O
where	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
is	O
able	O
to	O
control	O
the	O
reversal	O
of	O
the	O
temporary	O
differences	O
,	O
and	O
it	O
is	O
probable	O
that	O
they	O
will	O
not	O
reverse	O
in	O
the	O
foreseeable	O
future.	O

Deferred	O
tax	O
assets	O
are	O
recognised	O
to	O
the	O
extent	O
that	O
it	O
is	O
probable	O
that	O
future	O
taxable	O
income	O
will	O
be	O
available	O
to	O
utilise	O
them.	O

108	O
ANNUAL	O
AND	O
SUSTAINABILITY	O
REPORT	O
2018F	O
IN	O
A	O
N	O
C	O
IA	O
L	O
R	O
E	O
P	O
O	O
R	O
T	O
The	O
carrying	O
amount	O
of	O
deferred	O
tax	O
assets	O
is	O
reviewed	O
at	O
the	O
end	O
of	O
each	O
reporting	O
date	O
and	O
adjusted	O
based	O
on	O
estimates	O
of	O
future	O
taxable	O
income	O
and/or	O
capital	O
gains	O
against	O
which	O
the	O
deferred	O
tax	O
asset	O
could	O
be	O
utilised.	O

Deferred	O
tax	O
assets	O
and	O
liabilities	O
are	O
measured	O
at	O
the	O
tax	O
rates	O
applicable	O
to	O
each	O
jurisdiction	O
which	O
are	O
expected	O
to	O
apply	O
in	O
the	O
period	O
when	O
the	O
assets	O
are	O
realised	O
or	O
liabilities	O
discharged.	O

They	O
are	O
offset	O
where	O
they	O
relate	O
to	O
the	O
same	O
tax	O
authority	O
and	O
there	O
is	O
a	O
legally-enforceable	O
right	O
to	O
offset.	O

Inventories	O
NET	O
REALISABLE	O
vALUE	O
OF	O
INvENTORIES	O
Inventories	O
are	O
recognised	O
at	O
the	O
lower	O
of	O
cost	O
and	O
net	O
realisable	O
value	O
(	O
NRV	O
)	O
.	O

NRV	O
of	O
ore	O
is	O
based	O
on	O
the	O
estimated	O
amount	O
expected	O
to	O
be	O
received	O
when	O
the	O
ore	O
is	O
processed	O
and	O
sold	O
,	O
less	O
incremental	O
costs	O
to	O
convert	O
the	O
ore	O
to	O
concentrate	O
and	O
selling	O
costs.	O

The	O
computation	O
of	O
NRV	O
for	O
stockpiles	O
involves	O
significant	O
judgements	O
and	O
estimates	O
in	O
relation	O
to	O
future	O
ore	O
blend	O
rates	O
,	O
timing	O
of	O
processing	O
,	O
processing	O
costs	O
,	O
commodity	O
prices	O
,	O
foreign	O
exchange	O
rates	O
,	O
discount	O
rates	O
and	O
the	O
ultimate	O
timing	O
of	O
sale	O
of	O
concentrates	O
produced.	O

A	O
change	O
in	O
any	O
of	O
these	O
critical	O
assumptions	O
will	O
alter	O
the	O
estimated	O
NRV	O
and	O
may	O
therefore	O
impact	O
the	O
carrying	O
value	O
of	O
inventories.	O

An	O
assessment	O
of	O
the	O
NRV	O
of	O
non-current	O
ore	O

in	O
an	O

to	O

million	O

to	O
low	O
grade	O
gold	O
ore	O
stockpiles	O
being	O
recognised	O
in	O
2018	O
(	O
2017	O
:	O
$16.8	O
million	O
)	O
.	O

The	O
increase	O
is	O
a	O
reversal	O
of	O
a	O
previous	O
impairment.	O

Recognition	O
and	O
measurement	O
of	O
inventories	O
Inventory	O
is	O
valued	O
at	O
the	O
lower	O
of	O
cost	O
incurred	O
to	O
bring	O
product	O
to	O
its	O
present	O
location	O
and	O
condition	O
,	O
and	O
NRV.	O

Costs	O
are	O
assigned	O
to	O
individual	O
items	O
of	O
inventory	O
on	O
the	O
basis	O
of	O
weighted	O
average	O
costs.	O

Costs	O
comprise	O
direct	O
materials	O
and	O
labour	O
and	O
a	O
proportion	O
of	O
overhead	O
expenditure	O
directly	O
related	O
to	O
the	O
production	O
of	O
inventories.	O

Expenditure	O
directly	O
related	O
to	O
the	O
production	O
of	O
inventories	O
includes	O
processing	O
costs	O
;	O
transportation	O
costs	O
to	O
the	O
point	O
of	O
sale	O
;	O
and	O
depreciation	O
of	O
plant	O
,	O
equipment	O
,	O
mining	O
property	O
and	O
development	O
assets	O
,	O
the	O
latter	O
of	O
which	O
includes	O
deferred	O
stripping	O
assets	O
and	O
mine	O
rehabilitation	O
costs	O
incurred	O
in	O
the	O
mining	O
process.	O

NRV	O
is	O
calculated	O
by	O
estimating	O
the	O
value	O
that	O
is	O
expected	O
to	O
be	O
realised	O
upon	O
sale	O
of	O
concentrate	O
after	O
deducting	O
the	O
estimated	O
costs	O
of	O
processing	O
and	O
selling	O
costs.	O

This	O
estimation	O
is	O
based	O
on	O
assumptions	O
of	O
future	O
prices	O
and	O
costs	O
as	O
well	O
as	O
expected	O
future	O
ore	O
blend	O
rates	O
and	O
processing	O
timing.	O

Inventories	O
expected	O
to	O
be	O
processed	O
or	O
sold	O
within	O
12	O
months	O
after	O
the	O
balance	O
date	O
are	O
classified	O
as	O
current	O
assets	O
and	O
all	O
other	O
inventories	O
are	O
classified	O
as	O
non-current.	O

Capital	O

Carrapateena	O

$252.2	O

Carrapateena	O

million	O

,	O

US$75	O

is	O

required.	O

Recognition	O
and	O
measurement	O
of	O
property	O
,	O
plant	O
and	O
equipment	O
Items	O
of	O
property	O
,	O
plant	O
and	O
equipment	O
are	O
stated	O
at	O
cost	O
less	O
accumulated	O
depreciation	O
and	O
accumulated	O
impairment	O
losses.	O

Cost	O
includes	O
expenditure	O
that	O
is	O
directly	O
attributable	O
to	O
the	O
acquisition	O
of	O
the	O
items	O
and	O
costs	O
incurred	O
in	O
bringing	O
assets	O
into	O
use.	O

Expenditure	O
associated	O
with	O
mining	O
which	O
relates	O
to	O
developing	O
access	O
to	O
new	O
sections	O
of	O
an	O
ore	O
body	O
is	O
capitalised	O
as	O
a	O
mine	O
development	O
asset	O
and	O
depreciated	O
on	O
a	O
units	O
of	O
production	O
basis	O
as	O
ore	O
is	O
extracted.	O

When	O
ore	O
extraction	O
and	O
mine	O
development	O
occurs	O
concurrently	O
expenditure	O
is	O
allocated	O
between	O
the	O
cost	O
of	O
ore	O
extraction	O
(	O
inventory	O
)	O
and	O
mine	O
development	O
on	O
the	O
basis	O
of	O
the	O
proportion	O
of	O
underlying	O
activity	O
typically	O
meters	O
advanced	O
or	O
material	O
moved.	O

112	O
ANNUAL	O
AND	O
SUSTAINABILITY	O
REPORT	O
2018F	O
IN	O
A	O
N	O
C	O
IA	O
L	O
R	O
E	O
P	O
O	O
R	O
T	O
Mine	O
property	O
and	O
development	O
Mine	O
property	O
and	O
development	O
includes	O
mineral	O
rights	O
of	O
$546.7	O
million	O
(	O
net	O
of	O
amortisation	O
)	O
associated	O
with	O
the	O
acquisition	O
of	O
Avanco.	O

Mineral	O
rights	O
comprise	O
identifiable	O
exploration	O
and	O
evaluation	O
assets	O
,	O
mineral	O
resources	O
and	O
ore	O
reserves	O
which	O
are	O
acquired	O
as	O
part	O
of	O
a	O
business	O
combination	O
and	O
are	O
recognised	O
at	O
fair	O
value	O
at	O
date	O
of	O
acquisition.	O

Mine	O
property	O
and	O
development	O
assets	O
include	O
costs	O
transferred	O
from	O
exploration	O
and	O
evaluation	O
assets	O
once	O
technical	O
feasibility	O
and	O
commercial	O
viability	O
of	O
an	O
area	O
of	O
interest	O
are	O
demonstrable.	O

After	O
transfer	O
,	O
all	O
subsequent	O
expenditures	O
to	O
develop	O
the	O
mine	O
to	O
the	O
production	O
phase	O
which	O
are	O
considered	O
to	O
benefit	O
mining	O
operations	O
in	O
future	O
periods	O
are	O
capitalised.	O

The	O
proceeds	O
from	O
the	O
sale	O
of	O
any	O
concentrate	O
produced	O
from	O
ore	O
extracted	O
and	O
processed	O
as	O
part	O
of	O
development	O
of	O
the	O
asset	O
prior	O
to	O
being	O
deemed	O
ready	O
for	O
use	O
are	O
deducted	O
from	O
the	O
cost	O
of	O
the	O
asset	O
,	O
less	O
any	O
further	O
processing	O
and	O
selling	O
costs	O
incurred.	O

The	O
present	O
value	O
of	O
the	O
expected	O
cost	O
of	O
decommissioning	O
an	O
asset	O
after	O
its	O
use	O
is	O
included	O
in	O
the	O
cost	O
of	O
the	O
respective	O
asset	O
if	O
the	O
recognition	O
criteria	O
for	O
a	O
provision	O
are	O
met.	O

Property	O
,	O
plant	O
and	O
equipment	O
is	O
tested	O
for	O
impairment	O
when	O
there	O
is	O
an	O
indication	O
of	O
impairment.	O

For	O
the	O
purposes	O
of	O
assessing	O
impairment	O
,	O
assets	O
are	O
grouped	O
at	O
the	O
lowest	O
levels	O
for	O
which	O
there	O
are	O
separately	O
identifiable	O
cash	O
inflows.	O

An	O
impairment	O
loss	O
is	O
recognised	O
for	O
the	O
amount	O
by	O
which	O
the	O
asset	O
or	O
cash	O
generating	O
unit	O
(	O
CGU	O
)	O
carrying	O
amount	O
exceeds	O
its	O
recoverable	O
amount.	O

The	O
recoverable	O
amount	O
is	O
the	O
higher	O
of	O
an	O
asset	O
’	O
s	O
fair	O
value	O
,	O
less	O
costs	O
to	O
dispose	O
and	O
its	O
value	O
in	O
use.	O

Assets	O
that	O
have	O
been	O
impaired	O
are	O
reviewed	O
for	O
possible	O
reversal	O
of	O
impairment	O
at	O
each	O
reporting	O
date.	O

Value	O
in	O
use	O
is	O
the	O
net	O
amount	O
expected	O
to	O
be	O
recovered	O
through	O
cash	O
flows	O
arising	O
from	O
continued	O
use	O
and	O
subsequent	O
disposal	O
of	O
an	O
asset	O
(	O
or	O
group	O
of	O
assets	O
)	O
.	O

In	O
assessing	O
value	O
in	O
use	O
,	O
estimated	O
future	O
cash	O
flows	O
are	O
discounted	O
to	O
their	O
present	O
value	O
using	O
a	O
pre-tax	O
discount	O
rate	O
that	O
reflects	O
current	O
market	O
assessments	O
of	O
the	O
time	O
value	O
of	O
money	O
and	O
risks	O
specific	O
to	O
the	O
asset.	O

The	O
asset	O
’	O
s	O
fair	O
value	O
less	O
costs	O
to	O
dispose	O
is	O
the	O
amount	O
obtainable	O
from	O
the	O
sale	O
of	O
an	O
asset	O
or	O
cash-generating	O
unit	O
in	O
an	O
arm	O
’	O
s	O
length	O
transaction	O
between	O
knowledgeable	O
and	O
willing	O
parties	O
,	O
less	O
the	O
estimated	O
costs	O
of	O
disposal.	O

A	O
fair	O
value	O
measurement	O
of	O
a	O
non-financial	O
asset	O
takes	O
into	O
account	O
a	O
market	O
participant	O
’	O
s	O
ability	O
to	O
generate	O
economic	O
benefits	O
by	O
using	O
the	O
asset	O
in	O
its	O
highest	O
and	O
best	O
use	O
,	O
or	O
by	O
selling	O
it	O
to	O
another	O
market	O
participant	O
that	O
would	O
use	O
the	O
asset	O
in	O
its	O
highest	O
and	O
best	O
use.	O

RECOvERABILITY	O
OF	O
ASSETS	O
Cash	O
generating	O
units	O
are	O
tested	O
for	O
impairment	O
when	O
there	O
is	O
an	O
indication	O
that	O
the	O
CGU	O
may	O
be	O
impaired.	O

Examples	O
of	O
impairment	O
indicators	O
include	O
the	O
Group	O
’	O
s	O
net	O
assets	O
exceeding	O
its	O
market	O
capitalisation	O
,	O
unfavourable	O
fluctuations	O
in	O
commodity	O
prices	O
and	O
foreign	O
exchange	O
rates	O
,	O
or	O
a	O
decline	O
in	O
the	O
CGU	O
’	O
s	O
operating	O
performance.	O

The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
undertook	O
a	O
review	O
of	O
the	O
Prominent	O
Hill	O
,	O
Carrapateena	O
and	O
the	O
Carajas	O
CGU	O
’	O
s	O
to	O
determine	O
whether	O
there	O
was	O
any	O
indication	O
that	O
these	O
CGU	O
’	O
s	O
had	O
suffered	O
an	O
impairment	O
loss.	O

The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
concluded	O
that	O
there	O
were	O
no	O
such	O
indicators	O
that	O
the	O
CGUs	O
were	O
impaired	O
at	O
the	O
reporting	O
date	O
noting	O
also	O
that	O
the	O
Carajas	O
CGU	O
was	O
only	O
recently	O
acquired	O
in	O
an	O
arm	O
’	O
s	O
length	O
transaction.	O

When	O
the	O
Group	O
reviewed	O
impairment	O
indicators	O
,	O
consideration	O
was	O
given	O
for	O
negative	O
trends	O
in	O
the	O
significant	O
judgements	O
and	O
assumptions	O
that	O
may	O
impact	O
the	O
CGU	O
’	O
s	O
valuation	O
in	O
future	O
periods	O
,	O
including	O
:	O
/	O
expected	O
future	O
cash	O
flows	O
based	O
on	O
a	O
range	O
of	O
factors	O
including	O
Board-approved	O
internal	O
budgets	O
and	O
forecasts	O
which	O
reflect	O
expectations	O
of	O
resources	O
and	O
reserves	O
;	O
mine	O
plans	O
;	O
short	O
and	O
long	O
term	O
commodity	O
prices	O
and	O
foreign	O
exchange	O
rates	O
;	O
and	O
operating	O
and	O
capital	O
costs	O
/	O
the	O
value	O
of	O
mineral	O
resources	O
not	O
modelled	O
in	O
Board-approved	O
budgets	O
,	O
based	O
on	O
the	O
use	O
of	O
an	O
appropriate	O
resource	O
valuation	O
multiple	O
to	O
the	O
contained	O
copper	O
equivalent	O
within	O
the	O
resources	O
applicable	O
to	O
the	O
CGU	O
/	O
the	O
discount	O
rate	O
applied	O
to	O
the	O
cash	O
flows	O
which	O
reflects	O
current	O
market	O
conditions.	O

In	O
addition	O
,	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
monitors	O
for	O
impairment	O
indicators	O
by	O
considering	O
the	O
impact	O
of	O
the	O
above	O
judgements	O
and	O
assumptions	O
on	O
the	O
valuation	O
of	O
CGUs	O
through	O
periodic	O
updates	O
to	O
its	O
business	O
valuation	O
models.	O

Such	O
assumptions	O
are	O
subject	O
to	O
variation	O
as	O
a	O
result	O
of	O
changes	O
in	O
future	O
economic	O
and	O
operational	O
conditions.	O

Consequently	O
,	O
the	O
carrying	O
value	O
of	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
’	O
s	O
CGUs	O
may	O
differ	O
in	O
future	O
years	O
if	O
assumptions	O
made	O
do	O
not	O
eventuate	O
and	O
actual	O
outcomes	O
are	O
less	O
favourable	O
than	O
present	O
assumptions.	O

113Depreciation	O
methods	O
adopted	O
by	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
Category	O
Depreciation	O
method	O
Freehold	O
land	O
Not	O
depreciated	O
Buildings	O
and	O
other	O
infrastructure	O
Straight	O
line	O
over	O
life	O
of	O
mine	O
Short	O
term	O
plant	O
and	O
equipment	O
Straight	O
line	O
over	O
life	O
of	O
asset	O
Processing	O
plant	O
Units	O
of	O
ore	O
milled	O
over	O
mining	O
inventory	O
Mine	O
property	O
and	O
development	O
Units	O
of	O
ore	O
extracted	O
over	O
mining	O
inventory	O
applicable	O
to	O
the	O
development	O
Depreciation	O
of	O
assets	O
commences	O
when	O
the	O
assets	O
are	O
ready	O
for	O
their	O
intended	O
use.	O

The	O
depreciation	O
of	O
mine	O
property	O
and	O
development	O
commences	O
when	O
the	O
mine	O
is	O
commissioned	O
or	O
deemed	O
ready	O
for	O
use.	O

The	O
residual	O
values	O
,	O
useful	O
lives	O
and	O
methods	O
of	O
depreciation	O
of	O
property	O
,	O
plant	O
and	O
equipment	O
are	O
reviewed	O
at	O
each	O
reporting	O
period	O
and	O
adjusted	O
prospectively	O
,	O
if	O
appropriate.	O

Where	O
depreciation	O
rates	O
are	O
changed	O
,	O
the	O
net	O
written	O
down	O
value	O
of	O
the	O
asset	O
is	O
depreciated	O
from	O
the	O
date	O
of	O
the	O
change	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
the	O
new	O
depreciation	O
rate	O
,	O
with	O
the	O
change	O
accounted	O
for	O
as	O
a	O
change	O
in	O
accounting	O
estimate.	O

MINERAL	O
RESOURCE	O
AND	O
ORE	O
RESERvE	O
ESTIMATES	O
The	O
estimated	O
quantities	O
of	O
mineral	O
resource	O
and	O
ore	O
reserve	O
estimates	O
are	O
based	O
upon	O
interpretations	O
of	O
geological	O
and	O
geophysical	O
models	O
and	O
require	O
assumptions	O
to	O
be	O
made	O
regarding	O
exchange	O
rates	O
,	O
commodity	O
prices	O
,	O
future	O
capital	O
requirements	O
and	O
future	O
operating	O
performance.	O

Changes	O
in	O
reported	O
mineral	O
resource	O
and	O
ore	O
reserve	O
estimates	O
can	O
impact	O
the	O
carrying	O
value	O
of	O
property	O
,	O
plant	O
and	O
equipment	O
,	O
including	O
deferred	O
mining	O
expenditure	O
;	O
intangible	O
assets	O
;	O
capitalised	O
exploration	O
;	O
provisions	O
for	O
mine	O
rehabilitation	O
,	O
restoration	O
and	O
dismantling	O
obligations	O
;	O
and	O
recognition	O
of	O
deferred	O
tax	O
assets	O
as	O
well	O
as	O
the	O
amount	O
of	O
depreciation	O
charged	O
to	O
the	O
income	O
statement.	O

Changes	O
in	O
the	O
carrying	O
value	O
of	O
the	O
assets	O
may	O
arise	O
principally	O
through	O
changes	O
in	O
the	O
income	O
that	O
can	O
be	O
economically	O
generated	O
from	O
each	O
project.	O

Changes	O
in	O
depreciation	O
expense	O
may	O
arise	O
through	O
a	O
change	O
in	O
the	O
useful	O
life	O
over	O
which	O
property	O
,	O
plant	O
and	O
equipment	O
is	O
depreciated.	O

8.	O

Provisions	O
MINE	O
REHABILITATION	O
,	O
RESTORATION	O
&	O
DISMANTLING	O
OBLIGATIONS	O
The	O
provision	O
for	O
mine	O
rehabilitation	O
includes	O
future	O
cost	O
estimates	O
associated	O
with	O
reclamation	O
,	O
plant	O
closures	O
,	O
waste	O
site	O
closures	O
,	O
monitoring	O
,	O
demobilisation	O
of	O
equipment	O
,	O
decontamination	O
,	O
water	O
purification	O
and	O
permanent	O
storage	O
of	O
historical	O
residues.	O

Uncertainty	O
exists	O
as	O
to	O
the	O
amount	O
of	O
rehabilitation	O
obligations	O
which	O
will	O
be	O
incurred	O
due	O
to	O
the	O
impact	O
of	O
environmental	O
legislation	O
changes	O
and	O
many	O
other	O
factors	O
,	O
including	O
future	O
changes	O
in	O
technology	O
,	O
price	O
increases	O
and	O
changes	O
in	O
interest	O
rates.	O

The	O
calculation	O
of	O
these	O
provision	O
estimates	O
requires	O
assumptions	O
to	O
be	O
made	O
as	O
to	O
:	O
the	O
application	O
of	O
environmental	O
legislation	O
,	O
plant	O
closure	O
dates	O
,	O
available	O
technologies	O
,	O
engineering	O
cost	O
estimates	O
and	O
discount	O
rates.	O

A	O
change	O
in	O
any	O
of	O
the	O
assumptions	O
used	O
may	O
have	O
a	O
material	O
impact	O
on	O
the	O
carrying	O
value	O
of	O
mine	O
rehabilitation	O
,	O
restoration	O
and	O
dismantling	O
provisions.	O

Recognition	O
and	O
measurement	O
of	O
provisions	O
Provisions	O
are	O
measured	O
at	O
the	O
present	O
value	O
of	O
the	O
best	O
estimate	O
of	O
the	O
expenditure	O
required	O
to	O
settle	O
the	O
present	O
obligation	O
at	O
balance	O
sheet	O
date.	O

The	O
discount	O
rate	O
used	O
to	O
determine	O
the	O
present	O
value	O
reflects	O
current	O
market	O
assessments	O
of	O
the	O
time	O
value	O
of	O
money	O
and	O
the	O
risks	O
specific	O
to	O
the	O
liability.	O

The	O
increase	O
in	O
provisions	O
due	O
to	O
the	O
passage	O
of	O
time	O
is	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
income	O
statement	O
as	O
financing	O
expenses.	O

ANNUAL	O
AND	O

Provisions	O

of	O

in	O

on	O

basis	O

they	O
arise.	O

Ordinary	O
shares	O
entitle	O
the	O
holder	O
to	O
participate	O
in	O
dividends	O
and	O
the	O
proceeds	O
on	O
the	O
winding	O
up	O
of	O
the	O
Company	O
in	O
proportion	O
to	O
the	O
number	O
of	O
shares	O
held.	O

On	O
a	O
show	O
of	O
hands	O
,	O
every	O
holder	O
of	O
ordinary	O
shares	O
present	O
at	O
a	O
meeting	O
in	O
person	O
or	O
by	O
proxy	O
is	O
entitled	O
to	O
one	O
vote	O
,	O
and	O
upon	O
a	O
poll	O
each	O
holder	O
is	O
entitled	O
to	O
one	O
vote	O
per	O
share.	O

Recognition	O
and	O
measurement	O
of	O
issued	O
capital	O
Ordinary	O
shares	O
are	O
classified	O
as	O
equity.	O

Incremental	O
costs	O
directly	O
attributable	O
to	O
the	O
issue	O
of	O
new	O
shares	O
or	O
options	O
are	O
shown	O
in	O
equity	O
as	O
a	O
deduction.	O

Shares	O
bought	O
and	O
held	O
by	O
the	O
Employee	O
Share	O
Plan	O
Trust	O
to	O
meet	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
’	O
s	O
obligation	O
to	O
provide	O
shares	O
to	O
employees	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
the	O
terms	O
of	O
their	O
employment	O
contracts	O
and	O
employee	O
share	O
plans	O
as	O
and	O
when	O
they	O
may	O
vest	O
,	O
are	O
classified	O
as	O
treasury	O
shares	O
and	O
are	O
presented	O
as	O
a	O
deduction	O
from	O
total	O
equity	O
,	O
until	O
the	O
shares	O
are	O
cancelled	O
or	O
reissued.	O

Consolidated	O
Entity	O
issued	O

,	O

,	O
081	O
shares	O
to	O
Avanco	O
Resources	O
Limited	O
shareholders	O
during	O
2018	O
as	O
a	O
part	O
of	O
the	O
purchase.	O

Issued	O
ordinary	O
share	O
capital	O
is	O
classified	O
as	O
equity	O
and	O
is	O
recognised	O
at	O
the	O
fair	O
value.	O

of	O

share	O

value	O
on	O
issue.	O

.	O

A	O

Recognition	O
and	O
measurement	O
of	O
share-based	O
payments	O
The	O
fair	O
value	O
of	O
share-based	O
payment	O
transactions	O
measured	O
at	O
grant	O
date	O
are	O
recognised	O
as	O
an	O
employee	O
benefit	O
expense	O
with	O
a	O
corresponding	O
increase	O
in	O
equity	O
over	O
the	O
period	O
during	O
which	O
the	O
employees	O
become	O
unconditionally	O
entitled	O
to	O
the	O
instruments.	O

If	O
the	O
employee	O
does	O
not	O
meet	O
a	O
non-market	O
condition	O
,	O
such	O
as	O
a	O
service	O
condition	O
or	O
internal	O
KPIs	O
,	O
any	O
cumulative	O
previously	O
recognised	O
expense	O
is	O
reversed.	O

The	O
fair	O
value	O
of	O
the	O
share-based	O
payment	O
transactions	O
granted	O
are	O
adjusted	O
to	O
reflect	O
market	O
vesting	O
conditions	O
at	O
the	O
time	O
of	O
grant	O
,	O
and	O
are	O
not	O
subsequently	O
adjusted.	O

Non-market	O
vesting	O
conditions	O
are	O
included	O
in	O
assumptions	O
about	O
the	O
number	O
of	O
instruments	O
that	O
are	O
expected	O
to	O
become	O
exercisable	O
and	O
are	O
updated	O
at	O
each	O
balance	O
sheet	O
date.	O

The	O
impact	O
of	O
the	O
revision	O
to	O
original	O
estimates	O
for	O
non-	O
market	O
conditions	O
,	O
if	O
any	O
,	O
is	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
income	O
statement	O
with	O
a	O
corresponding	O
adjustment	O
to	O
equity.	O

Changes	O
as	O
a	O
result	O
of	O
market	O
conditions	O
are	O
not	O

after	O
the	O
initial	O
grant	O
date.	O

12.	O

Financial	O
risk	O
management	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
’	O
Group	O
Treasury	O
Function	O
(	O
Group	O
Treasury	O
)	O
manages	O
the	O
financial	O
risks	O
of	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity.	O

Group	O
Treasury	O
identifies	O
,	O
evaluates	O
and	O
manages	O
financial	O
risks	O
in	O
close	O
co-operation	O
with	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
’	O
operating	O
units.	O

The	O
Board	O
approves	O
principles	O
for	O
overall	O
risk	O
management	O
as	O
well	O
as	O
policies	O
covering	O
specific	O
risk	O
areas	O
,	O
such	O
as	O
market	O
,	O
credit	O
and	O
liquidity	O
risk.	O

This	O
note	O
presents	O
information	O
about	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
’	O
s	O
financial	O
assets	O
and	O
liabilities	O
,	O
its	O
exposure	O
to	O
financial	O
risks	O
,	O
and	O
its	O
objectives	O
,	O
policies	O
and	O
processes	O
for	O
measuring	O
and	O
managing	O
risks.	O

The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
’	O
s	O
activities	O
expose	O
it	O
primarily	O
to	O
the	O
following	O
financial	O
risks	O
:	O
/	O
commodity	O
prices	O
/	O
foreign	O
currency	O
exchange	O
rates	O
/	O
credit	O
risk	O
/	O
liquidity	O
risk.	O

The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
holds	O
the	O
following	O
financial	O
instruments	O
Carried	O
at	O
fair	O
value	O
using	O
level	O
Carried	O
at	O
fair	O
value	O
using	O
level	O
two	O
Carried	O
at	O
amortised	O
cost1	O
one	O
valuation	O
technique	O
(	O
based	O
valuation	O
technique	O
(	O
quoted	O
market	O
prices	O
on	O
share	O
prices	O

on	O
the	O
of	O

,	O

and	O

for	O

exchanges	O
)	O

terms	O
)	O

in	O

The	O
carrying	O
value	O
of	O
each	O
of	O

Recognition	O
and	O
measurement	O
Financial	O
assets	O
and	O
liabilities	O
are	O
recognised	O
when	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
becomes	O
party	O
to	O
the	O
contractual	O
provisions	O
of	O
an	O
instrument.	O

Non-derivative	O
financial	O
assets	O
The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
classifies	O
its	O
financial	O
assets	O
as	O
:	O
/	O
financial	O
assets	O
at	O
fair	O
value	O
through	O
other	O
comprehensive	O
income	O
/	O
financial	O
assets	O
at	O
fair	O
value	O
through	O
profit	O
and	O
loss	O
/	O
loans	O
and	O
receivables	O
at	O
amortised	O
cost.	O

Financial	O
assets	O
measured	O
at	O
amortised	O
cost	O
are	O
recognised	O
initially	O
at	O
fair	O
value	O
plus	O
any	O
directly	O
attributable	O
transaction	O
costs.	O

Trade	O
receivables	O
,	O
including	O
those	O
containing	O
an	O
embedded	O
derivative	O
,	O
are	O
carried	O
at	O
fair	O
value.	O

Concentrate	O
sales	O
receivables	O
are	O
recognised	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
the	O
recognition	O
and	O
measurement	O
criteria	O
disclosed	O
in	O
Note	O
one.	O

Provisional	O
payments	O
in	O
relation	O
to	O
trade	O
receivables	O
are	O
usually	O
due	O
within	O
30	O
days	O
from	O
the	O
date	O
of	O
invoice	O
issue	O
,	O
with	O
final	O
settlement	O
usually	O
due	O
within	O
60	O
days.	O

Other	O
receivables	O
are	O
recognised	O
initially	O
at	O
fair	O
value	O
and	O
subsequently	O
measured	O
at	O
amortised	O
cost	O
using	O
the	O
effective	O
interest	O
method.	O

The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
de-recognises	O
a	O
financial	O
asset	O
or	O
a	O
part	O
of	O
it	O
when	O
,	O
and	O
only	O
when	O
,	O
the	O
contractual	O
rights	O
to	O
the	O
cash	O
flows	O
from	O
the	O
financial	O
asset	O
expire	O
or	O
the	O
financial	O
asset	O
is	O
transferred	O
to	O
another	O
party	O
without	O
retaining	O
control	O
or	O
substantially	O
all	O
risks	O
and	O
rewards	O
of	O
the	O
asset.	O

On	O
de-recognition	O
of	O
a	O
financial	O
asset	O
,	O
the	O
difference	O
between	O
the	O
carrying	O
amount	O
(	O
measured	O
at	O
the	O
date	O
of	O
de-recognition	O
)	O
and	O
the	O
consideration	O
received	O
(	O
including	O
any	O
new	O
asset	O
obtained	O
less	O
any	O
new	O
liability	O
assumed	O
)	O
and	O
any	O
cumulative	O
gain	O
or	O
loss	O
that	O
had	O
been	O
recognised	O
in	O
equity	O
is	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
income	O
statement.	O

A	O
financial	O
asset	O
measured	O
at	O
amortised	O
cost	O
is	O
assessed	O
at	O
each	O
reporting	O
date	O
as	O
to	O
whether	O
there	O
is	O
any	O
objective	O
evidence	O
of	O
impairment	O
as	O
a	O
result	O
of	O
one	O
or	O
more	O
events	O
having	O
an	O
impact	O
on	O
the	O
estimated	O
future	O
cash	O
flows	O
of	O
the	O
asset.	O

119An	O
impairment	O
loss	O
in	O
respect	O
of	O
financial	O
assets	O
measured	O
at	O
amortised	O
cost	O
is	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
income	O
statement	O
and	O
is	O
measured	O
as	O
the	O
difference	O
between	O
the	O
asset	O
’	O
s	O
carrying	O
amount	O
and	O
the	O
present	O
value	O
of	O
estimated	O
future	O
cash	O
flows	O
discounted	O
at	O
the	O
asset	O
’	O
s	O
original	O
effective	O
interest	O
rate.	O

The	O
carrying	O
amount	O
of	O
the	O
asset	O
is	O
reduced	O
through	O
the	O
use	O
of	O
an	O
allowance	O
account.	O

In	O
the	O
event	O
that	O
an	O
impairment	O
loss	O
is	O
reversed	O
,	O
the	O
asset	O
’	O
s	O
carrying	O
amount	O
cannot	O
exceed	O
what	O
the	O
carrying	O
amount	O
would	O
have	O
been	O
had	O
the	O
impairment	O
not	O
been	O
recognised.	O

The	O
amount	O
of	O
the	O
reversal	O
is	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
income	O
statement.	O

Non-derivative	O
financial	O
liabilities	O
All	O
financial	O
liabilities	O
are	O
recognised	O
initially	O
at	O
fair	O
value	O
and	O
net	O
of	O
directly	O
attributable	O
transaction	O
costs.	O

Trade	O
and	O
other	O
payables	O
represent	O
liabilities	O
for	O
goods	O
and	O
services	O
provided	O
to	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
prior	O
to	O
the	O
end	O
of	O
the	O
financial	O
year	O
which	O
are	O
unpaid.	O

The	O
amounts	O
are	O
non-interest-bearing	O
,	O
unsecured	O
and	O
are	O
usually	O
paid	O
within	O
30	O
days	O
of	O
recognition.	O

The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
de-recognises	O
financial	O
liabilities	O
when	O
its	O
obligations	O
are	O
discharged	O
,	O
cancelled	O
or	O
expire.	O

The	O
difference	O
between	O
the	O
carrying	O
amount	O
of	O
the	O
liability	O
de-recognised	O
and	O
the	O
consideration	O
paid	O
and	O
payable	O
is	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
income	O
statement	O
Derivative	O
financial	O
instruments	O
Recognition	O
and	O
measurement	O
Derivative	O
financial	O
instruments	O
are	O
initially	O
recognised	O
at	O
fair	O
value	O
on	O
the	O
date	O
the	O
derivative	O
contract	O
is	O
entered	O
into	O
and	O
are	O
subsequently	O
remeasured	O
to	O
their	O
fair	O
value	O
at	O
each	O
reporting	O
date.	O

Changes	O
in	O
the	O
fair	O
value	O
of	O
any	O
derivative	O
instrument	O
are	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
income	O
statement	O
or	O
other	O
comprehensive	O
income	O
,	O
based	O
the	O
designation	O
and	O
effectiveness	O
of	O
the	O
hedge	O
instrument.	O

Formal	O
designation	O
of	O
the	O
hedge	O
and	O
documentation	O
of	O
the	O
relationship	O
between	O
the	O
hedging	O
instrument	O
and	O
the	O
hedged	O
item	O
is	O
finalised	O
at	O
the	O
inception	O
of	O
the	O
transaction.	O

Changes	O
in	O
the	O
fair	O
value	O
of	O
the	O
derivative	O
financial	O
instrument	O
,	O
which	O
has	O
been	O
designated	O
in	O
a	O
hedge	O
relationship	O
,	O
will	O
be	O
recognised	O
in	O
other	O
comprehensive	O
income	O
if	O
the	O
hedging	O
relationship	O
remains	O
effective	O
and	O
the	O
underlying	O
hedge	O
item	O
has	O
not	O
been	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
income	O
statement	O
,	O
or	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
income	O
statement	O
if	O
the	O
hedge	O
relationship	O
is	O
no	O
longer	O
effective	O
or	O
the	O
underlying	O
hedged	O
item	O
has	O
been	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
income	O
statement.	O

Any	O
ineffective	O
portion	O
of	O
changes	O
in	O
the	O
fair	O
value	O
of	O
derivative	O
financial	O
instruments	O
is	O
recognised	O
immediately	O
in	O
the	O
income	O
statement.	O

The	O
amount	O
recognised	O
in	O
other	O
comprehensive	O
income	O
is	O
reclassified	O
to	O
the	O
income	O
statement	O
in	O
the	O
same	O
period	O
as	O
the	O
underlying	O
item	O
is	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
income	O
statement.	O

Commodity	O
price	O
risk	O

and	O
sensitivity	O

HEDGE	O
EFFECTIvENESS	O
A	O

which	O
is	O
established	O
at	O
inception	O
is	O
assessed	O
for	O

in	O

in	O
the	O
income	O
statement.	O

Significant	O
judgement	O
is	O

regarding	O
mine	O

,	O

and	O

metal	O

and	O

when	O
determining	O
a	O

relationship	O
’	O
s	O
effectiveness.	O

Copper	O
derivative	O
contracts	O
The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
manages	O
the	O
exposure	O
to	O
copper	O
price	O
volatility	O
on	O
completed	O
sales	O
from	O
contractual	O
quotation	O
pricing	O
adjustments	O
by	O
entering	O
into	O
copper	O
derivative	O
contracts	O
at	O
the	O
time	O
of	O
concentrate	O
shipments.	O

These	O
fix	O
the	O
forward	O
price	O
at	O
the	O
time	O
of	O
shipment.	O

These	O
derivative	O
contracts	O
are	O
designated	O
as	O
hedges	O
and	O
are	O
recognised	O
within	O
the	O
income	O
statement	O
as	O
part	O
of	O
revenue.	O

As	O
a	O
result	O
of	O
these	O
hedges	O
,	O
the	O
impact	O
of	O
changes	O
in	O
copper	O
price	O
after	O
the	O
date	O
of	O
sale	O
on	O
the	O
income	O
statement	O
is	O
expected	O
to	O
be	O
negligible.	O

Commodity	O
price	O
sensitivity	O
analysis	O
If	O
copper	O
prices	O
were	O
to	O
vary	O
significantly	O
,	O
then	O
the	O
expected	O
impact	O
on	O
the	O
income	O
statement	O
would	O
be	O
negligible	O
due	O
to	O
the	O
copper	O
price	O
hedging	O
activity.	O

As	O
such	O
,	O
our	O
analysis	O
focuses	O
on	O
the	O
impact	O
of	O
movements	O
in	O
gold	O
prices	O
as	O
variations	O
in	O
silver	O
prices	O
have	O
also	O
been	O
deemed	O
immaterial	O
for	O
the	O
purpose	O
of	O
this	O
analysis	O
(	O
see	O
table	O
below	O
)	O
.	O

accordance	O
with	O

,	O

sensitivity	O

on	O

Consolidated	O

Foreign	O
currency	O

risk	O
management	O
and	O
sensitivity	O
analysis	O
The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
is	O
exposed	O
to	O
foreign	O
currency	O
risk	O
arising	O
from	O
assets	O
and	O
liabilities	O
that	O
are	O
held	O
in	O
currencies	O
other	O
than	O
the	O
Australian	O
dollar.	O

The	O
Group	O
’	O
s	O
principal	O
operations	O
have	O
a	O
functional	O
currency	O
of	O
Australian	O
dollars.	O

An	O
entity	O
’	O
s	O
functional	O
currency	O
is	O
the	O
currency	O
of	O
the	O
primary	O
economic	O
environment	O
in	O
which	O
the	O
entity	O
operates.	O

Determination	O
of	O
an	O
entity	O
’	O
s	O
functional	O
currency	O
requires	O
management	O
’	O
s	O
judgement	O
when	O
considering	O
a	O
number	O
of	O
factors	O
,	O
including	O
the	O
currency	O
that	O
mainly	O
influences	O
revenue	O
,	O
costs	O
of	O
production	O
,	O
and	O
competitive	O
forces	O
and	O
regulations	O
which	O
impact	O
on	O
revenue.	O

In	O
addition	O
,	O
consideration	O
must	O
be	O
given	O
to	O
the	O
currency	O
in	O
which	O
financing	O
and	O
operating	O
activities	O
are	O
undertaken.	O

Foreign	O
currency	O
transactions	O
are	O
translated	O
into	O
the	O
functional	O
currency	O
using	O
exchange	O
rates	O
prevailing	O
at	O
the	O
date	O
of	O
the	O
transaction.	O

Foreign	O
exchange	O
gains	O
and	O
losses	O
resulting	O
from	O
the	O
settlement	O
of	O
such	O
transactions	O
and	O
from	O
the	O
translation	O
at	O
year-end	O
exchange	O
rates	O
of	O
financial	O
assets	O
and	O
liabilities	O
denominated	O
in	O
foreign	O
currencies	O
are	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
income	O
statement.	O

Interest	O
rate	O
risk	O
management	O
and	O

The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
does	O

2018	O

on	O

The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
carries	O
term	O
deposits	O
with	O
fixed	O
interest	O
rates.	O

The	O
effect	O
of	O
a	O
change	O
in	O
interest	O
rates	O
at	O
balance	O
date	O
would	O
not	O

a	O
significant	O
impact	O
on	O
the	O
after	O

as	O

Credit	O
risk	O
management	O
Credit	O
risk	O
refers	O
to	O
the	O
risk	O
that	O
any	O
counterparty	O
will	O
default	O
on	O
its	O
contractual	O
obligations	O
resulting	O
in	O
financial	O
loss	O
to	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity.	O

Counterparty	O
credit	O
risk	O
arises	O
through	O
sales	O
of	O
metal	O
in	O
concentrate	O
on	O
normal	O
terms	O
of	O
trade	O
,	O
cash	O
deposits	O
and	O
derivative	O
financial	O
instruments.	O

At	O
the	O
reporting	O
date	O
,	O
the	O
carrying	O
amount	O
of	O
financial	O
assets	O
in	O
the	O
balance	O
sheet	O
represents	O
the	O
maximum	O
credit	O
exposure	O
on	O
cash	O
and	O
cash	O
equivalents	O
,	O
trade	O
receivables	O
,	O
other	O
receivables	O
and	O
derivative	O
assets.	O

The	O
credit	O
risk	O
on	O
cash	O
and	O
cash	O
equivalents	O
is	O
managed	O
by	O
restricting	O
material	O
financial	O
transactions	O
to	O
banks	O
which	O
are	O
assigned	O
an	O
S&P	O
equivalent	O
of	O
A-1	O
short	O
term	O
credit	O
ratings	O
by	O
international	O
credit	O
rating	O
agencies	O
and	O
limiting	O
the	O
amount	O
of	O
funds	O
that	O
can	O
be	O
invested	O
with	O
a	O
single	O
counterparty	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
’	O
Credit	O
Risk	O
Management	O
Policy.	O

Credit	O
risk	O
in	O
trade	O
receivables	O
is	O
managed	O
by	O
undertaking	O
regular	O
risk	O
assessment	O
and	O
reviewing	O
credit	O
limits	O
of	O
customers.	O

As	O
there	O
are	O
a	O
relatively	O
small	O
number	O
of	O
transactions	O
,	O
they	O
are	O
closely	O
monitored	O
to	O
ensure	O
risk	O
of	O
default	O
is	O
kept	O
to	O
an	O
acceptable	O
level.	O

Sales	O
contracts	O
generally	O
require	O
a	O
provisional	O
payment	O
of	O
at	O
least	O
90	O
per	O
cent	O
of	O
the	O
estimated	O
value	O
of	O
each	O
sale	O
either	O
promptly	O
after	O
vessel	O
loading	O
or	O
upon	O
the	O
vessel	O
arriving	O
at	O
the	O
discharge	O
port.	O

Where	O
appropriate	O
,	O
sales	O
are	O
covered	O
by	O
letter	O
of	O
credit	O
arrangements	O
with	O
approved	O
financial	O
institutions.	O

123Liquidity	O
risk	O
management	O
Liquidity	O

Contingencies	O
CONTINGENCIES	O
By	O
their	O
nature	O
,	O
contingencies	O
will	O
only	O
be	O
resolved	O
when	O
one	O
or	O
more	O
uncertain	O
future	O
events	O
occur	O
or	O
fail	O
to	O
occur.	O

Determination	O
of	O
contingent	O
liabilities	O
disclosed	O
in	O
the	O
financial	O
statements	O
requires	O
the	O
exercise	O
of	O
significant	O
judgement	O
regarding	O
the	O
outcome	O
of	O
future	O
events.	O

The	O
financial	O
results	O
of	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
in	O
future	O
periods	O
may	O
be	O
impacted	O
unfavourably	O
in	O
the	O
event	O
of	O
an	O
unfavourable	O
outcome	O
of	O
a	O
number	O
of	O
matters	O
outlined	O
in	O
this	O
note.	O

Bank	O
guarantees	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
Group	O
Treasury	O
Pty	O
Ltd	O
has	O
provided	O
certain	O
bank	O
guarantees	O
to	O
third	O
parties	O
,	O
associated	O
with	O
the	O
terms	O
of	O
mining	O
leases	O
,	O
power	O
infrastructure	O
contracts	O
,	O
exploration	O
licences	O
and	O
office	O
leases	O
,	O
in	O
respect	O
of	O
which	O
the	O
relevant	O
entity	O
is	O
obliged	O
to	O
indemnify	O
the	O
bank	O
if	O
the	O
guarantee	O
is	O
called	O
upon.	O

At	O
the	O
end	O
of	O
the	O
financial	O
year	O
,	O
no	O
claims	O
have	O
been	O
made	O
under	O
any	O
of	O
these	O
guarantees.	O

The	O
amount	O
of	O
some	O
of	O
these	O
guarantees	O
may	O
vary	O
from	O
time	O
to	O
time	O
depending	O
upon	O
the	O
requirements	O
of	O
the	O
recipient.	O

These	O
guarantees	O
amounted	O
to	O
$209.1	O
million	O
as	O
at	O
31	O
December	O
2018	O
(	O
31	O
December	O
2017	O
:	O
$52.9	O
million	O
)	O
and	O
are	O
backed	O
by	O
deposits.	O

Presently	O
,	O
all	O
guarantees	O
are	O
voluntarily	O
cash-backed	O
by	O
deposits	O
in	O
order	O
to	O
reduce	O
the	O
bank	O
fees	O
payable	O
but	O
all	O
funds	O
can	O
be	O
withdrawn	O
as	O
and	O
when	O
required	O
should	O
the	O
need	O
arise.	O

Deeds	O
of	O
indemnity	O
The	O

Entity	O
has	O

of	O

,	O

former	O

–	O

Special	O
Projects	O
,	O
the	O
former	O
Group	O
Treasurer	O
and	O
each	O

who	O
was	O

Each	O

,	O

or	O
employee	O

of	O
OZ	O

company.	O

OZ	O

OZ	O
Minerals	O

that	O

and	O
OZ	O

AFP.	O

OZ	O
Minerals	O

that	O

not	O

Other	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
Limited	O
and	O
its	O
controlled	O
entities	O
are	O
defendants	O
from	O
time	O
to	O
time	O
in	O
other	O
legal	O
proceedings	O
or	O
disputes	O
,	O

from	O
the	O

of	O
their	O
business.	O

OZ	O
Minerals	O
does	O
not	O

that	O

of	O

of	O

or	O

is	O

to	O

company	O
’	O
s	O
or	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
’	O
s	O
financial	O
position.	O

125Group	O
structure	O
and	O
other	O
information	O
14.	O

Subsidiary	O
acquisition	O
The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
acquired	O
Avanco	O
during	O
the	O
year	O
which	O
has	O
been	O
accounted	O
for	O
as	O
a	O
business	O
combination.	O

The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
accounts	O
for	O
the	O
acquisition	O
of	O
subsidiaries	O
using	O
the	O
acquisition	O
method	O
of	O
accounting	O
on	O
acquisition	O
date	O
by	O
recognising	O
the	O
identifiable	O
assets	O
acquired	O
and	O
the	O
liabilities	O
assumed.	O

OZ	O
Minerals	O
obtained	O
control	O
of	O
Avanco	O
Resources	O
Ltd	O
on	O
13	O
June	O
2018.	O

OZ	O
Minerals	O
acquired	O
100%	O
of	O
Avanco	O
Resources	O
Ltd	O
’	O
s	O
shares	O
through	O
an	O
off-market	O
offer	O
made	O
to	O
shareholders	O
and	O
compulsory	O
acquisition.	O

The	O
Avanco	O
acquisition	O
provides	O
geographical	O
diversification	O
into	O
new	O
mineral	O
provinces	O
for	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
with	O
a	O
large	O
copper	O
gold	O
mineral	O
resource	O
base	O
in	O
the	O
Carajas.	O

While	O
the	O
Antas	O
operating	O
mine	O
immediately	O
increases	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
’	O
s	O
production	O
,	O
the	O
CentroGold	O
,	O
Pedra	O
Branca	O
and	O
Pantera	O
projects	O
,	O
along	O
with	O
other	O
exploration	O
prospects	O
in	O
the	O
Carajas	O
province	O
(	O
and	O
the	O
neighbouring	O
Gurupi	O
province	O
)	O
,	O
significantly	O
enhance	O
the	O
growth	O
pipeline	O
and	O
potential	O
for	O
near-term	O
production	O
growth.	O

Avanco	O
’	O
s	O
assets	O
and	O
liabilities	O
have	O
been	O
recognised	O
at	O
their	O
provisional	O
fair	O
values	O
as	O
at	O
30	O
June	O
2018	O
due	O
to	O
the	O
proximity	O
of	O
the	O
acquisition	O
to	O
30	O
June	O
2018.	O

The	O
provisional	O
recognition	O
will	O
be	O
reviewed	O
and	O
finalised	O
within	O
12	O
months	O
of	O
the	O
acquisition	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
accounting	O
standards	O
,	O
should	O
any	O
subsequent	O
information	O
provide	O
better	O
evidence	O
of	O
the	O
fair	O
values	O
at	O
the	O
date	O
of	O
acquisition.	O

If	O
100%	O
interest	O
in	O
Avanco	O
was	O
acquired	O
on	O
1	O
January	O
2018	O
,	O
the	O
revenue	O
of	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
would	O
have	O
been	O
higher	O
by	O
$52.7	O
million	O
and	O
the	O
profit	O
after	O
tax	O
would	O
have	O
been	O
lower	O
by	O
$4.9	O
million.	O

Development	O
of	O
the	O
CentroGold	O
Project	O
is	O
subject	O
to	O
an	O
injunction	O
which	O
presently	O
restricts	O
development	O
activities.	O

Legal	O
processes	O
are	O
being	O
followed	O
to	O
facilitate	O
lifting	O
of	O
the	O
injunction.	O

As	O
at	O
31	O
December	O
2018	O
the	O
fair	O
values	O
recognised	O
remain	O
provisional	O
pending	O
completion	O
of	O
a	O
review	O
of	O
the	O
Antas	O

mine	O

,	O

128	O
ANNUAL	O
AND	O
SUSTAINABILITY	O
REPORT	O
2018F	O
IN	O
A	O
N	O
C	O
IA	O
L	O
R	O
E	O
P	O
O	O
R	O
T	O
Basis	O
of	O
consolidation	O
Investments	O
in	O
subsidiaries	O
Subsidiaries	O
are	O
those	O
entities	O
over	O
which	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
is	O
capable	O
of	O
exerting	O
control.	O

The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
controls	O
an	O
entity	O
when	O
it	O
is	O
exposed	O
to	O
,	O
or	O
has	O
rights	O
to	O
,	O
variable	O
returns	O
from	O
its	O
involvement	O
with	O
the	O
entity	O
and	O
has	O
the	O
ability	O
to	O
affect	O
those	O
returns	O
through	O
its	O
power	O
over	O
the	O
entity.	O

Where	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
holds	O
less	O
than	O
a	O
majority	O
of	O
the	O
voting	O
rights	O
,	O
other	O
relevant	O
factors	O
are	O
considered	O
in	O
assessing	O
whether	O
power	O
over	O
the	O
entity	O
exists.	O

Factors	O
considered	O
include	O
rights	O
arising	O
from	O
other	O
contractual	O
arrangements	O
,	O
any	O
contractual	O
arrangements	O
with	O
other	O
vote	O
holders	O
as	O
well	O
as	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
’	O
s	O
voting	O
and	O
potential	O
voting	O
rights.	O

The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
reassesses	O
whether	O
it	O
controls	O
an	O
entity	O
if	O
circumstances	O
indicate	O
that	O
there	O
has	O
been	O
a	O
change	O
in	O
one	O
of	O
the	O
factors	O
which	O
indicate	O
control.	O

Subsidiaries	O
are	O
consolidated	O
from	O
the	O
date	O
on	O
which	O
control	O
is	O
assessed	O
to	O
exist	O
until	O
the	O
date	O
that	O
control	O
ceases.	O

The	O
purchase	O
method	O
of	O
accounting	O
is	O
used	O
to	O
account	O
for	O
the	O
acquisition	O
of	O
subsidiaries	O
by	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity.	O

Intercompany	O
transactions	O
,	O
balances	O
and	O
unrealised	O
gains	O
and	O
losses	O
on	O
transactions	O
between	O
companies	O
controlled	O
by	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
are	O
eliminated	O
on	O
consolidation.	O

During	O
the	O
year	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
incorporated	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
Brazil	O
(	O
Holdings	O
)	O
Pty	O
Ltd	O

wholly-owned	O
subsidiary	O
on	O
5	O
April	O

)	O
.	O

of	O
the	O
Act	O

in	O

18.	O

Related	O
party	O
transactions	O
A	O
number	O
of	O
KMP	O
,	O
or	O
their	O
related	O
parties	O
,	O
hold	O
positions	O
in	O
other	O
entities	O
that	O
may	O
result	O
in	O
them	O

control	O

of	O
those	O
entities.	O

Where	O
the	O
Consolidated	O

with	O
the	O
KMP	O
and	O
their	O
related	O

and	O
conditions	O
of	O

are	O
no	O

than	O
those	O
available	O

or	O
which	O

New	O

(	O
i	O
)	O
Changes	O

during	O
the	O
year	O

for	O

AASB	O
15	O
as	O
described	O
below.	O

The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
has	O
adopted	O
all	O
of	O
the	O
new	O
,	O

or	O

that	O
are	O

Consolidated	O

has	O
for	O
the	O
first	O
time	O
applied	O
AASB	O
15	O
Revenue	O
from	O
Contracts	O
with	O
Customers	O
with	O
effect	O
from	O
1	O
January	O
2018.	O

AASB	O
15	O
Revenue	O
from	O
contracts	O
with	O
customers	O
AASB	O
15	O
changes	O
the	O
timing	O
(	O
and	O
in	O
some	O
case	O
,	O
the	O
quantum	O
)	O
of	O
revenue	O
recognised	O
from	O
customers.	O

Under	O
the	O
previous	O
standard	O
revenue	O
for	O
domestic	O
sales	O
is	O
recognised	O
when	O
the	O
concentrates	O
are	O
delivered	O
to	O
the	O
customers	O
’	O
premises	O
,	O
which	O
is	O
the	O
point	O
when	O
the	O
customer	O
takes	O
over	O
the	O
risk	O
and	O
rewards	O
of	O
ownership	O
transfer.	O

The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
’	O
s	O
assessment	O
indicates	O
that	O
under	O
AASB	O
15	O
,	O
revenue	O
is	O
continued	O
to	O
be	O
recognised	O
on	O
the	O
same	O
basis	O
when	O
the	O
customer	O
obtains	O
control	O
of	O
the	O
concentrates.	O

Revenue	O
for	O
export	O
sales	O
was	O
recognised	O
when	O
shipments	O
of	O
concentrates	O
were	O
loaded	O
on	O
to	O
the	O
vessel	O
as	O
the	O
risk	O
and	O
reward	O
of	O
ownership	O
was	O
transferred	O
to	O
the	O
customer	O
at	O
that	O
point.	O

The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
’	O
s	O
assessment	O
under	O
AASB	O
15	O
indicates	O
that	O
the	O
export	O
contracts	O
are	O
made	O
up	O
of	O
two	O
performance	O
obligations.	O

The	O
first	O
obligation	O
is	O
to	O
deliver	O
the	O
concentrates	O
to	O
the	O
port	O
of	O
shipment	O
and	O
the	O
second	O
obligation	O
is	O
to	O
organise	O
shipping	O
of	O
the	O
concentrate	O
,	O
which	O
will	O
be	O
satisfied	O
when	O
concentrates	O
are	O
delivered	O
to	O
the	O
destination	O
port.	O

The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
assessed	O
that	O
revenue	O
relating	O
to	O
the	O
first	O
obligation	O
of	O
delivery	O
of	O
the	O
concentrates	O
to	O
the	O
port	O
of	O
shipping	O
will	O
be	O
recognised	O
at	O
that	O
point	O
and	O
revenue	O
relating	O
to	O
the	O
shipping	O
obligation	O
will	O
be	O
recognised	O
in	O
future	O
periods	O
upon	O
delivery	O
of	O
concentrates.	O

The	O
impact	O
of	O
the	O
change	O
in	O
accounting	O
policy	O
was	O
accounted	O
for	O
using	O
the	O
full	O
retrospective	O
transitional	O
provisions	O
and	O
did	O
not	O
have	O
a	O
material	O
impact	O
on	O
the	O
amount	O
of	O
revenue	O
recognised	O
as	O
the	O
transfer	O
of	O
risks	O
and	O
rewards	O
under	O
the	O
previous	O
AASB	O
118.	O

Revenue	O
coincides	O
with	O
the	O
fulfilment	O
of	O
the	O
performance	O
obligation	O
to	O
transfer	O
concentrate	O
and	O
revenue	O
from	O
freight	O
services	O
for	O

,	O
insurance	O
and	O
freight	O
contracts	O
is	O
immaterial	O
in	O
the	O

and	O

periods.	O

134	O
ANNUAL	O
AND	O
SUSTAINABILITY	O
REPORT	O
2018F	O
IN	O
A	O
N	O
C	O
IA	O

R	O
T	O
(	O
ii	O
)	O
Early	O
adoption	O
of	O
standards	O
The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
has	O
not	O
early-adopted	O
any	O
standards	O
in	O
the	O
Annual	O
Report	O
during	O
the	O
year	O
ended	O
31	O
December	O
2018.	O

(	O
iii	O
)	O
Issued	O
standards	O
and	O
pronouncements	O
not	O
early-adopted	O
At	O
the	O
date	O
of	O
authorisation	O
of	O
the	O
Financial	O
Statements	O
,	O
the	O
following	O
AASB	O
Standards	O
had	O
been	O
issued	O
but	O
were	O
not	O
yet	O
effective.	O

AASB	O
16	O
Leases	O
AASB	O
16	O
Leases	O
eliminates	O
the	O
distinction	O
between	O
operating	O
and	O
finance	O
leases	O
and	O
brings	O
all	O
leases	O
(	O
other	O
than	O
short	O
term	O
and	O
low	O
value	O
leases	O
)	O
onto	O
the	O
balance	O
sheet.	O

A	O
lessee	O
recognises	O
a	O
right-of-use	O
asset	O
representing	O
its	O
right	O
to	O
use	O
the	O
underlying	O
asset	O
and	O
a	O
lease	O
liability	O
representing	O
its	O
obligation	O
to	O
make	O
lease	O
payments.	O

The	O
standard	O
is	O
applicable	O
to	O
annual	O
reporting	O
periods	O
beginning	O
on	O
or	O
after	O
1	O
January	O
2019.	O

The	O
AASB	O
16	O
will	O
result	O
in	O
higher	O
assets	O
and	O
liabilities	O
on	O
the	O
balance	O
sheet	O
and	O
the	O
cumulative	O
effect	O
of	O
adopting	O
AASB	O
16	O
will	O
be	O
recognised	O
as	O
an	O
adjustment	O
to	O
the	O
opening	O
balance	O
of	O
retained	O
earnings	O
at	O
1	O
January	O
2019	O
with	O
no	O
restatement	O
of	O
comparative	O
information.	O

The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
will	O
recognise	O
right-of-use	O
assets	O
and	O
lease	O
liabilities	O
for	O
the	O
arrangements	O
assessed	O
as	O
leases	O
on	O
transition	O
unless	O
they	O
are	O
short	O
term	O
,	O
low	O
value	O
,	O
or	O
previously	O
did	O
not	O
meet	O
the	O
definition	O
of	O
a	O
lease	O
for	O
arrangements	O
in	O
place	O
at	O
31	O
December	O
2018.	O

AASB	O
16	O
will	O
be	O
applied	O
to	O
all	O
new	O
arrangements	O
entered	O
into	O
from	O
1	O
January	O
2019.	O

Many	O
activities	O
of	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
’	O
operations	O
are	O
conducted	O
by	O
contractors	O
including	O
mining	O
,	O
mine	O
development	O
,	O
infrastructure	O
and	O
site	O
services.	O

Where	O
contracts	O
require	O
payment	O
of	O
fixed	O
charges	O
that	O
relate	O
to	O
use	O
of	O
equipment	O
or	O
property	O
,	O
they	O
will	O
be	O
deemed	O
to	O
contain	O
leases	O
under	O
AASB	O
16	O
and	O
the	O
present	O
value	O
of	O
the	O
fixed	O
charges	O
will	O
be	O
recognised	O
as	O
a	O
right-of-use	O
asset	O
along	O
with	O
a	O
lease	O
liability.	O

The	O
nature	O
of	O
expenses	O
relating	O
to	O
such	O
fixed	O
charges	O
which	O
would	O
have	O
been	O
recognised	O
as	O
an	O
expense	O
attributable	O
to	O
the	O
function	O
,	O
will	O
change	O
to	O
depreciation	O
for	O
right-of-use	O
assets	O
and	O
interest	O
expense	O
on	O
lease	O
liabilities.	O

The	O
variable	O
charges	O
required	O
to	O
be	O
paid	O
under	O
the	O
contracts	O
will	O
continue	O
to	O
be	O
recognised	O
as	O
an	O
expense	O
in	O
profit	O
or	O
loss	O
or	O
capitalised	O
as	O
incurred	O
depending	O
on	O
the	O
purpose	O
for	O
which	O
the	O
activity	O
was	O
undertaken.	O

The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
is	O
currently	O
undertaking	O
an	O
analysis	O
of	O
the	O
financial	O
reporting	O
impact	O
,	O
noting	O
that	O
:	O
/	O
the	O
group	O
has	O
not	O

and	O

of	O
all	O

143144	O
ANNUAL	O
AND	O
SUSTAINABILITY	O
REPORT	O
2018G	O
L	O
O	O
S	O
S	O
A	O
R	O
Y	O
Glossary	O
Acid	O
rock	O
drainage	O
Hectare	O
(	O
ha	O
)	O
Site	O
culture	O
development	O
strategy	O
When	O
rock	O
surfaces	O
are	O
exposed	O
to	O
air	O
and	O
A	O
hectare	O
is	O
a	O
unit	O
of	O
area	O
equal	O
to	O
A	O
Prominent	O
Hill	O
initiative	O
that	O
enables	O
rain	O
,	O
a	O
reaction	O
can	O
occur	O
with	O
the	O
elements	O
10	O
,	O
000	O
square	O
metres.	O

Usually	O
used	O
employee	O
and	O
contractor	O
management	O
in	O
the	O
rock	O
which	O
results	O
in	O
a	O
change	O
in	O
the	O
to	O
measure	O
land.	O

to	O
define	O
,	O
assess	O
and	O
improve	O
key	O
areas	O
characteristics	O
of	O
the	O
water	O
that	O
runs	O
off.	O

to	O
improve	O
the	O
overall	O
safety	O
culture.	O

If	O
the	O
rock	O
contains	O
sulphides	O
,	O
oxidation	O
IUCN	O
Red	O
List	O
processes	O
can	O
acidify	O
the	O
water.	O

This	O
The	O
International	O
Union	O
for	O
Conservation	O
Stakeholders	O
process	O
is	O
known	O
as	O
acid	O
rock	O
drainage.	O

of	O
Nature	O
and	O
Natural	O
Resources	O
(	O
IUCN	O
)	O
Any	O
person	O
,	O
group	O
or	O
interested	O
party	O
Red	O
List	O
of	O
threatened	O
species	O
provides	O
that	O
may	O
be	O
impacted	O
by	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
’	O
Biodiversity	O
information	O
about	O
the	O
characteristics	O
,	O
operations	O
,	O
activities	O
or	O
performance.	O

Biodiversity	O
is	O
the	O
variety	O
of	O
plants	O
,	O
conservation	O
status	O
and	O
distribution	O
of	O
animals	O
and	O
micro-organisms	O
,	O
their	O
genetic	O
flora	O
and	O
fauna	O
species	O
facing	O
the	O
risk	O
Tailings	O
variation	O
and	O
the	O
different	O
ecosystems	O
of	O
of	O
extinction.	O

Finely	O
ground	O
materials	O
from	O
which	O
which	O
they	O
inhabit.	O

valuable	O
minerals	O
have	O
been	O
largely	O
Kilolitre	O
(	O
kL	O
)	O
extracted.	O

Carbon	O
dioxide	O
equivalent	O
(	O
CO2-e	O
)	O
One	O
kilolitre	O
is	O
equal	O
to	O
one	O
thousand	O
litres.	O

Carbon	O
dioxide	O
equivalent	O
is	O
a	O
standard	O
Tailings	O
storage	O
facility	O
(	O
TSF	O
)	O
measurement	O
used	O
to	O
indicate	O
the	O
impact	O
Leading	O
my	O
career	O
Facility	O
designed	O
for	O
the	O
storage	O
of	O
tailings	O
of	O
various	O
greenhouse	O
gas	O
emissions	O
A	O
training	O
and	O
mentoring	O
program	O
for	O
high	O
material	O
produced	O
during	O
ore	O
processing.	O

on	O
global	O
warming	O
relative	O
to	O
the	O
same	O
performing	O
women	O
,	O
run	O
collaboratively	O
amount	O
of	O
carbon	O
dioxide	O
(	O
CO	O
)	O
.	O

between	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
,	O
Beach	O
Energy	O
and	O
Total	O
recordable	O
injury	O
frequency	O
rate	O
2	O
Thiess	O
Mining	O
(	O
Prominent	O
Hill	O
)	O
.	O

(	O
TRIFR	O
)	O
Copper	O
concentrate	O
TRIFR	O
is	O
the	O
total	O
number	O
of	O
recordable	O
Lost	O
time	O
injury	O
frequency	O
rate	O
(	O
LTIFR	O
)	O
injuries	O
per	O
million	O
working	O
hours.	O

The	O
Prominent	O
Hill	O
operation	O
produces	O
A	O
lost	O
time	O
injury	O
is	O
a	O
work-related	O
injury	O
or	O

relate	O
to	O
end	O
of	O
hole	O
samples	O
where	O
only	O
three	O
of	O
the	O
15	O
rare	O
earth	O
elements	O
were	O
assayed	O
,	O
however	O
the	O
high-grade	O
nature	O
of	O
the	O
results	O
and	O
thickness	O
of	O
the	O
preserved	O
regolith	O
above	O
these	O
samples	O
suggest	O
there	O
is	O
a	O
great	O
potential	O
for	O
large	O
scale	O
IAC-REE	O
style	O
deposits.	O

the	O
existing	O
REE	O
assay	O
data	O
from	O
explorers	O
in	O
the	O
province	O
also	O

fact	O
that	O

is	O
a	O
good	O
indicator	O
of	O
total	O
REE	O
enrichment.	O

is	O
an	O

of	O
the	O
potential	O
scale	O
of	O
the	O
Cascade	O
REE	O
Project	O

of	O

ABOUT	O
MEEKA	O
GOLD	O
LIMITED	O
Meeka	O
Gold	O
(	O
ASX	O
:	O
MEK	O
)	O
is	O
a	O
junior	O
gold	O
and	O
rare	O
earths	O
explorer	O
with	O
a	O
portfolio	O
of	O
exploration	O
projects	O
across	O
Western	O
Australia.	O

Meeka	O
’	O
s	O
flagship	O
Murchison	O
Gold	O
Project	O
has	O
a	O
combined	O
343km	O
²	O

landholding	O
in	O
the	O
prolific	O
Murchison	O
Gold	O
Fields	O
of	O
Western	O
Australia	O
and	O
hosts	O
a	O
large	O
high	O
grade	O
1.1Moz	O
Mineral	O
Resource.	O

The	O
Company	O
is	O
actively	O
exploring	O
on	O
this	O
tenure	O
while	O
also	O
progressing	O
toward	O
production	O
with	O
the	O
release	O
of	O
the	O
Murchison	O
Gold	O
Project	O
Scoping	O
Study	O
in	O
December	O
2021	O
outlining	O
a	O
robust	O
Project	O
that	O
produces	O
over	O
420koz	O
of	O
gold	O
and	O
delivers	O
significant	O
free	O
cashflow.	O

Complimentary	O
to	O
the	O
Murchison	O
Gold	O
Project	O
,	O
the	O
Company	O
owns	O
the	O
Circle	O
Valley	O
Gold	O
Project	O
in	O
southern	O
WA.	O

Circle	O
Valley	O
sits	O
in	O
the	O
Albany-Fraser	O
Mobile	O
Belt	O
,	O
which	O
hosts	O
the	O
Tropicana	O
gold	O
mine	O
(	O
3Moz	O
past	O
production	O
)	O
.	O

Gold	O
mineralisation	O
has	O
been	O
identified	O
in	O
two	O
separate	O
locations	O
at	O
Circle	O
Valley	O
and	O
presents	O
an	O
exciting	O
greenfield	O
exploration	O
opportunity	O
,	O
which	O
the	O
Company	O
is	O
aggressively	O

2	O
,	O
068km2	O
of	O
exploration	O
tenure	O
in	O

ionic	O

FORWARD	O
LOOKING	O
STATEMENTS	O
Certain	O
statements	O
in	O
this	O
report	O
relate	O
to	O
the	O
future	O
,	O
including	O
forward	O
looking	O
statements	O
relating	O
to	O
the	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
financial	O
position	O
,	O
strategy	O
and	O
expected	O
operating	O
results.	O

These	O
forward-looking	O
statements	O
involve	O
known	O
and	O
unknown	O
risks	O
,	O
uncertainties	O
,	O
assumptions	O
and	O
other	O
important	O
factors	O
that	O
could	O
cause	O
the	O
actual	O
results	O
,	O
performance	O
or	O
achievements	O
of	O
the	O
Company	O
to	O
be	O
materially	O
different	O
from	O
future	O
results	O
,	O
performance	O
or	O
achievements	O
expressed	O
or	O
implied	O
by	O
such	O
statements.	O

Actual	O
events	O
or	O
results	O
may	O
differ	O
materially	O
from	O
the	O
events	O
or	O
results	O
expressed	O
or	O
implied	O
in	O
any	O
forward-looking	O
statement	O
and	O
deviations	O
are	O
both	O
normal	O
and	O
to	O
be	O
expected.	O

Other	O
than	O
required	O
by	O
law	O
,	O
neither	O
the	O
Company	O
,	O
their	O
officers	O
nor	O
any	O
other	O
person	O
gives	O
any	O
representation	O
,	O
assurance	O
or	O
guarantee	O
that	O
the	O
occurrence	O
of	O
the	O
events	O
expressed	O
or	O
implied	O
in	O
any	O
forward-looking	O
statements	O
will	O
actually	O
occur.	O

You	O
are	O

not	O
to	O
place	O
undue	O
reliance	O
on	O
those	O
statements.	O

CHAIRMAN	O
’	O
S	O
LETTER	O
Dear	O
Shareholders	O
The	O
2021	O
financial	O
year	O
has	O
been	O
an	O
exciting	O
year	O
for	O
your	O
company	O
,	O
with	O
successes	O
achieved	O
at	O
Eastern	O
Lefroy	O
(	O
Au/Cu	O
)	O
,	O
Western	O
Lefroy	O
(	O
Au	O
)	O
and	O
Lake	O
Johnstone	O
(	O
Ni	O
)	O
.	O

In	O
all	O
,	O
over	O
34	O
,	O
000	O
metres	O
of	O
diamond/RC/aircore	O
was	O
drilled	O
and	O
significant	O
auger	O
and	O
geophysical	O
surveys	O
were	O
completed.	O

It	O
is	O
pleasing	O
to	O
report	O
that	O
the	O
safety	O
,	O
environmental	O
and	O
community	O
performance	O
at	O
our	O
projects	O
has	O
again	O
been	O
excellent	O
and	O
congratulate	O
all	O
staff	O
and	O
contractors	O
for	O
their	O
preparation	O
and	O
diligence	O
,	O
especially	O
while	O
carrying	O
out	O
their	O
fieldwork.	O

As	O
100%	O
operator	O
in	O
Eastern	O
Lefroy	O
(	O
266	O
sq	O
km	O
)	O
,	O
we	O
extended	O
our	O
knowledge	O
of	O
gold	O
mineralisation	O
at	O
Lucky	O
Strike	O
,	O
Hang	O
Glider	O
Hill	O
and	O
Havelock	O
and	O
from	O
January	O
2001	O
we	O
conducted	O
several	O
large	O
drill	O
and	O
geophysical	O
programs	O
to	O
define	O
Au/Cu	O
mineralisation	O
trends	O
at	O
the	O
newly	O
acquired	O
Burns	O
project.	O

At	O
the	O
Western	O
Lefroy	O
project	O
(	O
372	O
sq	O
km	O
)	O
,	O
our	O
partner	O
Goldfields	O
completed	O
14	O
,	O
723m	O
of	O
drilling	O
and	O
in	O
June	O
2021	O
decided	O
to	O
exercise	O
its	O
option	O
to	O
purchase	O
50%	O
of	O
Western	O
Lefroy	O
and	O
spend	O
up	O
to	O
another	O
$15m	O
over	O
the	O
next	O
three	O
years	O
seeking	O
major	O
discoveries	O
under/around	O
Lake	O
Lefroy.	O

The	O
commercial	O
arrangements	O
for	O
the	O
extension	O
included	O
return	O
of	O
the	O
high	O
potential	O
Coogee	O
South	O
area	O
to	O
the	O
Eastern	O
Lefroy	O
project	O
and	O
$1.38m	O
cash.	O

At	O
Lake	O
Johnson	O
we	O
have	O
confirmed	O
the	O
presence	O
of	O
nickel	O
mineralisation	O
and	O
started	O
planning	O
for	O
exploration	O
to	O
define	O
mineable	O
nickel	O
resources	O
in	O
the	O
coming	O
year.	O

Undoubtedly	O
the	O
highlight	O
for	O
the	O
year	O
was	O
the	O
high-grade	O
Au/Cu	O
intercept	O
at	O
Burns	O
in	O
March	O
2021.	O

We	O
will	O
do	O
more	O
to	O
properly	O
follow	O
this	O
up	O
in	O
the	O
near	O
future	O
,	O
but	O
are	O
currently	O
constrained	O
by	O
long	O
assay	O
times.	O

What	O
we	O
already	O
know	O
,	O
however	O
,	O
is	O
that	O
Burns	O
is	O
a	O
very	O
exciting	O
area.	O

It	O
is	O
abundantly	O
clear	O
that	O
the	O
amount	O
of	O
metal	O
we	O
have	O
found	O
already	O
,	O
even	O
though	O
our	O
exploration	O
has	O
been	O
limited	O
to	O
date	O
,	O
shows	O
that	O
we	O
have	O
only	O
scratched	O
the	O
surface	O
of	O
what	O
we	O
will	O
define	O
in	O
the	O
Burns	O
area.	O

This	O
could	O
include	O
large	O
tonnage	O
,	O
low	O
to	O
medium	O
grade	O
open	O
pittable	O
Cu/Au	O
mineralisation	O
in	O
the	O
western	O
basalt	O
zone	O
and	O
higher-grade	O
Au	O
in	O
the	O
Eastern	O
Porphyry.	O

We	O
have	O
recently	O
been	O
granted	O
approval	O
to	O
explore	O
on	O
Lake	O
Randall	O
as	O
part	O
of	O
our	O
Burns	O
project	O
exploration	O
and	O
will	O
start	O
work	O
on	O
this	O
by	O
year	O
end	O
2021.	O

In	O
2022	O

expect	O

hard	O
work	O
and	O
patience	O
to	O
be	O
further	O
rewarded.	O

We	O
will	O
initially	O
focus	O
on	O
Burns	O
exploration	O
and	O
programs	O
at	O
Coogee	O
South.	O

Later	O

will	O

to	O

targets	O
at	O
Havelock	O
and	O
Hang	O
Glider	O

their	O
own	O

to	O
develop	O
the	O
100	O
,	O
000	O
ounces	O
we	O

already	O
defined	O
at	O

and	O
Red	O
Dale.	O

EXPLORATION	O
OVERVIEW	O
Lefroy	O
Gold	O
Project	O
The	O
Lefroy	O
Gold	O
Project	O
(	O
‘	O
LGP	O
’	O
)	O
is	O
located	O
some	O
50km	O
to	O
the	O
South	O
East	O
of	O
Kalgoorlie	O
in	O
the	O
Eastern	O
Goldfields	O
Province	O
of	O
Western	O
Australia	O
and	O
is	O
the	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
flagship	O
project.	O

Lefroy	O
Gold	O
Project	O
(	O
LGP	O
)	O
The	O
Lefroy	O
Gold	O
Project	O
is	O
wholly	O
owned	O
by	O
the	O
Company	O
and	O
located	O
approximately	O
50km	O
to	O
the	O
south	O
east	O
of	O
Kalgoorlie	O
in	O
the	O
Eastern	O
Goldfields	O
Province	O
of	O
Western	O
Australia	O
(	O
Figure	O
1	O
)	O
.	O

The	O
commanding	O
,	O
semi-contiguous	O
,	O
granted	O
land	O
package	O
covers	O
637.6km2	O
immediately	O
east	O
of	O
and	O
adjoining	O
the	O
world	O
class	O
+10Moz	O
St	O
Ives	O
Gold	O
camp	O
,	O
operated	O
by	O
Gold	O
Fields	O
Limited	O
(	O
NYSE	O
:	O
GFI	O
)	O
(	O
“	O
Gold	O
Fields	O
”	O
)	O
,	O
and	O
is	O
immediately	O
south	O
of	O
the	O
high-grade	O
Mt	O
Monger	O
gold	O
centre	O
operated	O
by	O
Silver	O
Lake	O
Resources	O
Limited	O
(	O
ASX	O
:	O
SLR	O
)	O
(	O
“	O
Silver	O
Lake	O
”	O
)	O
.	O

Four	O
gold	O
processing	O
operations	O
are	O
strategically	O
located	O
within	O
50km	O
of	O
the	O
project	O
and	O
provide	O
commercial	O
options	O
for	O
processing	O
any	O
gold	O
resources	O
discovered.	O

LGP	O
is	O
referenced	O
in	O
two	O
packages	O
,	O
i.e.	O

Eastern	O
Lefroy	O
covering	O
265.6km2	O
of	O

1	O
)	O

Monger	O
fault	O
and	O
;	O
Page	O
8	O
DIRECTORS	O
’	O
REPORT	O
(	O
CONTINUED	O
)	O

Lefroy	O
Project	O
(	O
“	O

”	O
)	O
tenements	O
(	O

1	O
)	O

372km2	O
adjoining	O
the	O
Gold	O
Fields	O
tenements	O
that	O
make	O
up	O
the	O
St	O
Ives	O
mining	O
operation.	O

Fields	O
can	O
earn	O
up	O
to	O
a	O
70%	O
interest	O
in	O
the	O
LEX	O
tenements	O

to	O

of	O

on	O
exploration	O
activities	O
within	O
6	O
years	O
of	O

date	O
,	O
7	O
June	O
,	O
2018.	O

The	O
LGP	O
covers	O
a	O
large	O
belt	O
of	O
Archaean	O
aged	O
rocks	O
that	O
are	O
transected	O
by	O
major	O

trends	O

in	O

REMUNERATION	O
OF	O
KEY	O
MANAGEMENT	O
PERSONNEL	O
The	O
names	O
and	O
position	O
of	O
key	O
management	O
personnel	O
(	O
‘	O
KMP	O
’	O
)	O
for	O
the	O
year	O
were	O
as	O
follows	O
:	O
Gordon	O
Galt	O
(	O
Non	O
-	O

executive	O
Chairman	O
)	O
Michael	O
Davies	O
(	O
Non	O
-	O

executive	O
Director	O
)	O
Geoffrey	O
Pigott	O
(	O
Non	O
-	O

executive	O
Director	O
)	O
Wade	O
Johnson	O
(	O
Managing	O
Director	O
)	O
Remuneration	O
Policy	O
The	O
remuneration	O
policy	O
of	O
Lefroy	O
Exploration	O
Limited	O
is	O
designed	O
to	O
align	O
key	O
management	O
personnel	O
objectives	O
with	O
shareholder	O
and	O
business	O
objectives	O
by	O
providing	O
a	O
fixed	O
remuneration	O
component	O
and	O
offering	O
long-term	O
incentives	O
when	O
considered	O
appropriate.	O

The	O
Board	O
of	O
Lefroy	O
Exploration	O
Limited	O
believes	O
the	O
remuneration	O
policy	O
is	O
effective	O
in	O
its	O
ability	O
to	O
attract	O
and	O
retain	O
suitable	O
key	O
management	O
personnel	O
to	O
manage	O
the	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
activities.	O

The	O
board	O
will	O
review	O
executive	O
packages	O
as	O
and	O
when	O
it	O
considers	O
it	O
appropriate	O
to	O
do	O
so	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
its	O
remuneration	O
policy	O
and	O
by	O
reference	O
to	O
the	O
Group	O
’	O
s	O
performance	O
,	O
executive	O
performance	O
and	O
comparable	O
information	O
from	O
industry	O
sectors	O
and	O
other	O
listed	O
companies	O
in	O
similar	O
industries.	O

The	O
Board	O
may	O
exercise	O
discretion	O
in	O
relation	O
to	O
approving	O
incentives	O
,	O
bonuses	O
and	O
shares	O
under	O
the	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
Share	O
Plan	O
Trust	O
from	O
time	O
to	O
time.	O

The	O
policy	O
is	O
designed	O
to	O
reward	O
executives	O
for	O
performance	O
that	O
results	O
in	O
long-term	O
growth	O
in	O
shareholder	O
wealth.	O

The	O
Managing	O
Director	O
receives	O
the	O
superannuation	O
guarantee	O
contribution	O
required	O
by	O
the	O
government	O
of	O
Australia	O
,	O
which	O
was	O
9.5%	O
for	O
the	O
2021	O
financial	O
year	O
,	O
but	O
is	O
not	O
entitled	O
to	O
receive	O
any	O
other	O
retirement	O
benefits.	O

The	O
Board	O
’	O
s	O
policy	O
is	O
to	O
remunerate	O
non-executive	O
directors	O
at	O
market	O
rates	O
for	O
comparable	O
companies	O
for	O
time	O
,	O
commitment	O
and	O
responsibilities.	O

The	O
Board	O
determines	O
payments	O
to	O
the	O
non-executive	O
directors	O
and	O
reviews	O
their	O
remuneration	O
annually	O
,	O
based	O
on	O
market	O
practice	O
,	O
duties	O
and	O
accountability.	O

Independent	O
external	O
advice	O
is	O
sought	O
as	O
and	O
when	O
required.	O

To	O
align	O
directors	O
’	O
interests	O
with	O
shareholder	O
interests	O
,	O
the	O
directors	O
are	O
encouraged	O
to	O
hold	O
shares	O
in	O
the	O
Company	O
and	O
are	O
able	O
to	O
participate	O
in	O
the	O
Share	O
Plan	O
when	O
considered	O
appropriate	O
by	O
the	O
Board.	O

Performance	O
based	O
remuneration	O
The	O
Group	O
utilises	O
performance	O
based	O
remuneration	O
to	O
attract	O
and	O
motivate	O
directors	O
and	O
employees	O
and	O
has	O
the	O
Lefroy	O
Exploration	O
Ltd	O
Share	O
Plan	O
which	O
was	O
approved	O
by	O
shareholders	O
on	O
12	O
September	O
2016.	O

Shares	O
issued	O
under	O
the	O
Plan	O
do	O
not	O
vest	O
until	O
certain	O
hurdles	O
have	O
been	O
met.	O

The	O
hurdles	O
are	O
based	O
around	O
future	O
events	O
that	O
will	O
advance	O
the	O
Company	O
towards	O
its	O
objectives.	O

Use	O
of	O
remuneration	O
consultants	O
The	O
Group	O
did	O
not	O
employ	O
the	O
services	O
of	O
any	O
remuneration	O
consultants	O
during	O
the	O
financial	O
year	O
ended	O
30	O
June	O
2021.	O

agreements	O
