upon	O
a	O
poll	O
is	O
entitled	O
to	O
one	O
vote	O
for	O
each	O
share	O
held.	O

(	O
c	O
)	O
Capital	O
risk	O
management	O
The	O
Group	O
defines	O
capital	O
as	O
issued	O
share	O
capital.	O

Its	O
objective	O
when	O
managing	O
capital	O
is	O
to	O
safeguard	O
its	O
ability	O
to	O
continue	O
as	O
a	O
going	O
concern	O
,	O
so	O
that	O
it	O
may	O
strive	O
to	O
provide	O
returns	O
for	O
shareholders	O
and	O
benefits	O
for	O
other	O
stakeholders.	O

Due	O
to	O
the	O
nature	O
of	O
the	O
Group	O
’	O
s	O
activities	O
,	O
being	O
mineral	O
exploration	O
,	O
the	O
Group	O
does	O
not	O
have	O
ready	O
access	O
to	O
credit	O
facilities	O
,	O
with	O
the	O
primary	O
source	O
of	O
funding	O
being	O
equity	O
raisings.	O

Therefore	O
,	O
the	O
focus	O
of	O
the	O
Group	O
’	O
s	O
capital	O
risk	O
management	O
is	O
the	O
current	O
working	O
capital	O
position	O
against	O
the	O
requirements	O
of	O
the	O
Group	O
to	O
meet	O
exploration	O
programmes	O
and	O
corporate	O
overheads.	O

The	O
Group	O
’	O
s	O
strategy	O
is	O
to	O
ensure	O
appropriate	O
liquidity	O
is	O
maintained	O
to	O
meet	O
anticipated	O
operating	O
requirements	O
,	O
with	O
a	O
view	O
to	O
initiating	O
appropriate	O
capital	O
raisings	O
as	O
required.	O

The	O
working	O
capital	O
position	O
of	O
the	O
Group	O
at	O
30	O
June	O
2019	O
and	O
30	O
June	O
2018	O
are	O
as	O

:	O

RESERVES	O

)	O
Options	O

Basis	O
for	O
opinion	O
We	O

our	O

in	O

with	O

Standards.	O

under	O

are	O

in	O

for	O

of	O
the	O

section	O
of	O
our	O
report.	O

We	O
are	O
independent	O
of	O
the	O
Group	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
the	O
ethical	O
requirements	O
of	O
the	O

and	O

Standards	O
Board	O
’	O
s	O
APES	O
110	O
Code	O
of	O
Ethics	O
for	O
Professional	O
Accountants	O
(	O
the	O
Code	O
)	O
that	O
are	O
relevant	O
to	O
our	O
audit	O
of	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
in	O
Australia.	O

We	O
have	O
also	O
fulfilled	O
our	O
other	O
ethical	O
responsibilities	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
the	O
Code.	O

We	O
believe	O
that	O
the	O
audit	O
evidence	O
we	O
have	O
obtained	O
is	O
sufficient	O
and	O
appropriate	O
to	O
provide	O
a	O
basis	O
for	O
our	O
opinion.	O

Key	O
audit	O
matters	O
Key	O
audit	O
matters	O
are	O
those	O
matters	O
that	O
,	O
in	O
our	O
professional	O
judgment	O
,	O
were	O
of	O
most	O
significance	O
in	O
our	O
audit	O
of	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
of	O
the	O
current	O
year.	O

These	O
matters	O
were	O
addressed	O
in	O
the	O
context	O
of	O
our	O
audit	O
of	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
as	O
a	O
whole	O
,	O
and	O
in	O
forming	O
our	O
opinion	O
thereon	O
,	O
but	O
we	O
do	O
not	O
provide	O
a	O
separate	O
opinion	O
on	O
these	O
matters.	O

For	O
each	O
matter	O
below	O
,	O
our	O
description	O
of	O
how	O
our	O
audit	O
addressed	O
the	O
matter	O
is	O
provided	O
in	O
that	O
context.	O

We	O
have	O
fulfilled	O
the	O
responsibilities	O
described	O
in	O
the	O
Auditor	O
’	O
s	O
Responsibilities	O
for	O
the	O
Audit	O
of	O
the	O
Financial	O
Report	O
section	O
of	O
our	O
report	O
,	O
including	O
in	O
relation	O
to	O
these	O
matters.	O

Accordingly	O
,	O
our	O
audit	O
included	O
the	O
performance	O
of	O
procedures	O
designed	O
to	O
respond	O
to	O
our	O
assessment	O
of	O
the	O
risks	O
of	O
material	O
misstatement	O
of	O
the	O
financial	O
report.	O

The	O
results	O
of	O
our	O
audit	O
procedures	O
,	O
including	O
the	O
procedures	O
performed	O
to	O
address	O
the	O
matters	O
below	O
,	O
provide	O
the	O
basis	O
for	O
our	O
audit	O
opinion	O
on	O
the	O
accompanying	O
financial	O
report.	O

A	O
member	O

Auditor's	O

for	O

audit	O

Our	O
objectives	O

to	O

about	O

a	O

to	O

or	O

and	O
to	O
issue	O
an	O
auditor	O
’	O
s	O
report	O
that	O
includes	O
our	O
opinion.	O

Reasonable	O
assurance	O
is	O
a	O
high	O
level	O
of	O
assurance	O
,	O
but	O
is	O
not	O
a	O
guarantee	O
that	O
an	O
audit	O
conducted	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
the	O
International	O
Auditing	O
Standards	O
will	O
always	O
detect	O
a	O
material	O
misstatement	O
when	O
it	O
exists.	O

Misstatements	O
can	O
arise	O
from	O
fraud	O
or	O
error	O
and	O
are	O
considered	O
material	O
if	O
,	O
individually	O
or	O
in	O
the	O
aggregate	O
,	O
they	O
could	O
reasonably	O
be	O
expected	O
to	O
influence	O
the	O
economic	O
decisions	O
of	O
users	O
taken	O
on	O
the	O
basis	O
of	O
this	O
financial	O
report.	O

part	O
of	O
an	O

with	O
the	O
International	O
Auditing	O
Standards	O
,	O
we	O
exercise	O
professional	O
judgment	O
and	O

professional	O

throughout	O
the	O
audit.	O

The	O
Board	O
of	O
Lefroy	O

for	O
the	O

of	O
the	O
Company	O
and	O
seeks	O
to	O
communicate	O
with	O
Shareholders.	O

with	O
ASX	O

,	O

About	O

Yilgarn	O
Block	O
of	O
Western	O
Australia.	O

Key	O
projects	O
include	O
the	O
Lefroy	O
Gold	O
Project	O
to	O
the	O
southeast	O
of	O
Kalgoorlie	O
and	O
the	O
Lake	O
Johnston	O
Project	O
120km	O
to	O
the	O
west	O
of	O

Lefroy	O
Gold	O
Project	O
contains	O

and	O

621km2	O
in	O
the	O
heart	O
of	O
the	O
world	O
class	O
gold	O
production	O
area	O
between	O
Kalgoorlie	O
and	O
Norseman.	O

Project	O
is	O

Gold	O

’	O
St	O
Ives	O
gold	O

in	O
Lake	O
Lefroy	O

is	O
also	O
immediately	O
south	O
of	O
Silver	O
Lake	O
Resources	O
’	O
(	O
ASX	O
:	O
SLR	O
)	O
Daisy	O
Milano	O
gold	O
mining	O
operation.	O

is	O

Lefroy	O

Lefroy	O
package	O

Lefroy	O

)	O
.	O

with	O

Fields	O

the	O
Western	O
Lefroy	O
tenement	O
package	O

on	O
7	O
June	O
2018.	O

Gold	O
Fields	O
can	O

up	O

70%	O

in	O

package	O

Chairman	O
’	O
s	O
Letter	O
Dear	O
Fellow	O
Shareholder	O
It	O
is	O
with	O
great	O

that	O
I	O
present	O
you	O
with	O
the	O
2018	O
Annual	O

for	O
Riversgold.	O

Financial	O
Year	O
2018	O
saw	O
a	O
number	O
of	O
significant	O
achievements	O
by	O
Riversgold	O
including	O
and	O
following	O
the	O
completion	O
of	O
its	O
$6	O
million	O
Initial	O
Public	O
Offer	O
and	O
subsequent	O
listing	O
on	O
the	O
ASX	O
in	O
October	O
2017.	O

The	O
successful	O
listing	O
was	O
achieved	O
in	O
a	O
difficult	O
investment	O
market	O
for	O
mineral	O
exploration	O
companies	O
and	O
was	O
aided	O
by	O
the	O
support	O
of	O
our	O
cornerstone	O
investor	O
Evolution	O
Mining	O
Limited	O
which	O
remains	O
a	O
supportive	O
shareholder	O
today.	O

Whilst	O
investor	O
sentiment	O
in	O
the	O
period	O
since	O
Riversgold	O
’	O
s	O
listing	O
has	O
remained	O
challenging	O
for	O
gold	O
exploration	O
companies	O
,	O
the	O
Company	O
has	O
advanced	O
its	O
two-pronged	O
exploration	O
strategy	O
and	O
delivered	O
a	O
number	O
of	O
promising	O
early	O
results.	O

This	O
strategy	O
combines	O
lower	O
risk	O
,	O
year-round	O
exploration	O
for	O
deposits	O
with	O
near-term	O
production	O
potential	O
at	O
the	O
Kurnalpi	O
Projects	O
in	O
Western	O
Australia	O
’	O
s	O
Eastern	O
Goldfields	O
with	O
higher	O
risk	O
exploration	O
for	O
larger	O
targets	O
in	O
Alaska	O
,	O
South	O
Australia	O
and	O
Cambodia.	O

Riversgold	O
’	O
s	O
activities	O
in	O
WA	O
commenced	O
within	O
two	O
weeks	O
of	O
the	O
ASX	O
listing	O
with	O
a	O
maiden	O
drill	O
program	O
at	O
the	O
Yilgani	O
prospect.	O

Subsequent	O
drill	O
programs	O
at	O
the	O
Farr-Jones	O
and	O
Cutler	O
prospects	O
produced	O
a	O
number	O
of	O
high-grade	O
results	O
and	O
follow	O
up	O
work	O
at	O
these	O
prospects	O
,	O
and	O
at	O
neighbouring	O
geochemical	O
anomalies	O
,	O
remains	O
a	O
priority.	O

Riversgold	O
has	O
also	O
completed	O
permitting	O
at	O
its	O
Queen	O
Lapage	O
prospect	O
,	O
a	O
15	O
kilometre	O
long	O
segment	O
of	O
the	O
mineralised	O
Randell	O
Shear	O
Zone	O
hosted	O
beneath	O
a	O
salt	O
lake	O
and	O
along	O
strike	O
from	O
historic	O
mining	O
operations.	O

Queen	O
Lapage	O
is	O
one	O
of	O
the	O
most	O
attractive	O
exploration	O
targets	O
at	O
Kurnalpi	O
due	O
to	O
the	O
potential	O
for	O
a	O
gold	O

of	O
significant	O
scale	O
and	O
will	O
be	O
a	O
key	O
target	O
for	O

in	O
FY2019.	O

The	O
Kurnalpi	O
Projects	O
are	O
in	O
an	O

location	O
close	O
to	O
a	O
number	O
of	O
existing	O
gold	O
processing	O
facilities	O
,	O

and	O
a	O

to	O
potentially	O
fast	O

the	O

of	O
even	O

gold	O
deposits.	O

In	O
Alaska	O
,	O
Riversgold	O
completed	O
its	O
maiden	O
exploration	O
program	O
in	O
an	O
area	O
150km	O
south-west	O
of	O
Donlin	O
Creek	O
,	O
one	O
of	O
the	O
world	O
’	O
s	O
largest	O
gold	O
discoveries	O
at	O
45	O
million	O
ounces.	O

Riversgold	O
’	O
s	O
project	O
area	O
contains	O
multiple	O
occurrences	O
of	O
high-grade	O
rock	O
chips	O
with	O
coincident	O
geophysical	O
anomalism	O
in	O
a	O

area	O
with	O
little	O
to	O

previous	O

and	O
geophysical	O
surveying	O
completed	O
during	O
the	O
2018	O
Alaskan	O
field	O
season	O
further	O
confirmed	O

of	O

these	O

Overview	O
Riversgold	O
Limited	O
(	O
“	O
Riversgold	O
”	O
or	O
“	O
the	O
Company	O
”	O
)	O
completed	O
a	O
successful	O
initial	O

Offering	O
(	O
IPO	O
)	O
raising	O
approximately	O
$6.1	O
million	O
(	O
before	O
costs	O
)	O

successfully	O
listed	O
on	O
the	O
Australian	O
Securities	O
Exchange	O
(	O
ASX	O
)	O
on	O
10	O
October	O
2017.	O

The	O
Company	O
was	O
fortunate	O
to	O
secure	O
a	O
strategic	O
cornerstone	O
investment	O
from	O
ASX-listed	O
gold	O
mining	O
company	O

Mining	O
Limited	O
(	O
ASX	O
:	O

)	O

contributed	O
$2.5	O
million	O
to	O
the	O
IPO.	O

several	O

has	O
a	O

Queen	O
Lapage	O
The	O
Queen	O
Lapage	O
target	O
is	O
characterised	O
by	O
a	O
11km	O
long	O
segment	O
of	O
the	O
Randell	O
Fault	O
under	O
the	O
thin	O
sediments	O
of	O
Lake	O
Yindarlgooda.	O

The	O
local	O
geology	O
consists	O
of	O
a	O
NNW	O
trending	O
sequence	O
of	O
mafic	O
and	O
ultramafic	O
rocks	O
juxtaposed	O
against	O
a	O
sedimentary	O
unit	O
along	O
a	O
faulted	O
contact.	O

A	O
series	O
of	O
later	O
NE-	O
trending	O
fault	O
cross-cut	O
both	O
the	O
regional	O
geology	O
and	O
the	O
faulted	O
contact.	O

aircore	O
drilling	O
on	O

the	O
lake	O
,	O
conducted	O
during	O
the	O

intersected	O

’	O
Report	O
Environmental	O
Regulation	O
and	O
Performance	O
The	O
Group	O
holds	O
various	O
exploration	O
licences	O
and	O
permits	O
to	O
regulate	O
its	O
exploration	O
activities.	O

These	O
licences	O
include	O
conditions	O
and	O
regulations	O
with	O
respect	O
to	O
the	O
rehabilitation	O
of	O
areas	O
disturbed	O
during	O
the	O
course	O
of	O
its	O
exploration	O
activities.	O

So	O
far	O
as	O
the	O
Directors	O
are	O
aware	O
,	O
all	O
exploration	O
activities	O
have	O
been	O
undertaken	O
in	O
compliance	O
with	O
all	O
relevant	O
environmental	O
regulations.	O

Remuneration	O
Report	O
(	O
Audited	O
)	O
Remuneration	O
paid	O
to	O
Directors	O
and	O
Officers	O
of	O
the	O
Company	O
is	O
set	O
by	O
reference	O
to	O
such	O
payments	O
made	O
by	O
other	O
ASX	O
listed	O
companies	O
of	O
a	O
similar	O
size	O
and	O
operating	O
in	O
the	O
mineral	O
exploration	O
industry.	O

In	O
addition	O
,	O
reference	O
is	O
made	O
to	O
the	O
specific	O
skills	O
and	O
experience	O
of	O
the	O
Directors	O
and	O
Officers.	O

Details	O
of	O
the	O
nature	O
and	O
amount	O
of	O
remuneration	O
of	O
each	O
Director	O
,	O
and	O
other	O
Key	O
Management	O
Personnel	O
if	O
applicable	O
,	O
are	O
disclosed	O
annually	O
in	O
the	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
Annual	O
Report.	O

Remuneration	O
Committee	O
The	O
Board	O
has	O
adopted	O
a	O
formal	O
Remuneration	O
Committee	O
Charter	O
which	O
provides	O
a	O
framework	O
for	O
the	O
consideration	O
of	O
remuneration	O
matters.	O

The	O
Company	O
does	O
not	O
have	O
a	O
separate	O
remuneration	O
committee	O
and	O
as	O
such	O
all	O
remuneration	O
matters	O
are	O
considered	O
by	O
the	O
Board	O
as	O
a	O
whole	O
,	O
with	O
no	O
Member	O
deliberating	O
or	O
considering	O
such	O
matter	O
in	O
respect	O
of	O
their	O
own	O
remuneration.	O

In	O
the	O
absence	O
of	O
a	O
separate	O
Remuneration	O
Committee	O
,	O
the	O
Board	O
is	O
responsible	O
for	O
:	O
1.	O

Setting	O
remuneration	O
packages	O
for	O
Executive	O
Directors	O
,	O
Non-Executive	O
Directors	O
and	O
other	O
Key	O
Management	O
Personnel	O
;	O
and	O
2.	O

Implementing	O
employee	O
incentive	O
and	O
equity	O
based	O
plans	O
and	O
making	O
awards	O
pursuant	O
to	O
those	O
plans.	O

Non-Executive	O
Remuneration	O
The	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
policy	O
is	O
to	O
remunerate	O
Non-Executive	O
Directors	O
,	O
at	O
rates	O
comparable	O
to	O
other	O
ASX	O
listed	O
companies	O
in	O
the	O
same	O
industry	O
,	O
for	O
their	O
time	O
,	O
commitment	O
and	O
responsibilities.	O

Non-Executive	O
Remuneration	O
is	O
not	O
linked	O
to	O
the	O
performance	O
of	O
the	O
Company	O
,	O
however	O
to	O
align	O
Directors	O
’	O
interests	O
with	O
shareholders	O
’	O
interests	O
,	O
remuneration	O
may	O
be	O
provided	O
to	O
Non-Executive	O
Directors	O
in	O
the	O
form	O
of	O
equity	O
based	O
long	O
term	O
incentives.	O

1.	O

Fees	O
payable	O
to	O
Non-Executive	O
Directors	O
are	O
set	O
within	O
the	O
aggregate	O
amount	O
approved	O
by	O
shareholders	O
at	O
the	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
Annual	O
General	O
Meeting	O
;	O
2.	O

Non-Executive	O
Directors	O
’	O
fees	O
are	O
payable	O
in	O
the	O
form	O
of	O
cash	O
and	O
superannuation	O
benefits	O
;	O
3.	O

Non-Executive	O
superannuation	O
benefits	O
are	O
limited	O
to	O
statutory	O
superannuation	O
entitlements	O
;	O
and	O
4.	O

Participation	O
in	O
equity	O
based	O
remuneration	O
schemes	O
by	O
Non-Executive	O
Directors	O
is	O
subject	O
to	O
consideration	O
and	O
approval	O
by	O
the	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
shareholders.	O

The	O
maximum	O
Non-Executive	O
Directors	O
fees	O
,	O
payable	O
in	O
aggregate	O
are	O
currently	O
set	O
at	O
$200	O
,	O
000	O
per	O
annum.	O

22	O
Riversgold	O
Limited	O
ABN	O
64	O
617	O
614	O
598	O
Directors	O
’	O
Report	O
Remuneration	O
Report	O
(	O
Continued	O
)	O
Executive	O
Director	O
and	O
Other	O
Key	O
Management	O
Personnel	O
Remuneration	O
Executive	O
remuneration	O
consists	O
of	O
base	O
salary	O
,	O
plus	O
other	O
performance	O
incentives	O
to	O
ensure	O
that	O
:	O
1.	O

Remuneration	O
packages	O
incorporate	O
a	O
balance	O
between	O
fixed	O
and	O
incentive	O
pay	O
,	O
reflecting	O
short	O
and	O
long	O
term	O
performance	O
objectives	O
appropriate	O
to	O
the	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
circumstances	O
and	O
objectives	O
;	O
and	O
2.	O

A	O
proportion	O
of	O
remuneration	O
is	O
structured	O
in	O
a	O
manner	O
to	O
link	O
reward	O
to	O
corporate	O
and	O
individual	O
performances.	O

Executives	O
are	O
offered	O
a	O
competitive	O
level	O
of	O
base	O
salary	O
at	O
market	O
rates	O
(	O
based	O
on	O
comparable	O
ASX	O
listed	O
companies	O
)	O
and	O
are	O
reviewed	O
regularly	O
to	O
ensure	O
market	O
competitiveness.	O

To	O
date	O
the	O
Company	O
has	O
not	O
engaged	O
external	O
remuneration	O
consultants	O
to	O
advise	O
the	O
Board	O
on	O
remuneration	O
matters.	O

Incentive	O
Plans	O
The	O
Company	O
provides	O
long	O
term	O
incentives	O
to	O
Directors	O
and	O
Employees	O
pursuant	O
to	O
the	O
Riversgold	O
Incentive	O
Option	O
Plan	O
,	O
which	O
was	O
last	O
approved	O
by	O
shareholders	O
on	O
28	O
April	O
2017.	O

The	O
Board	O
,	O
acting	O
in	O
remuneration	O
matters	O
:	O
1.	O

Ensures	O
that	O
incentive	O
plans	O
are	O
designed	O
around	O
appropriate	O
and	O
realistic	O
performance	O
targets	O
and	O
provide	O
rewards	O
when	O
those	O
targets	O
are	O
achieved	O
;	O
2.	O

Reviews	O
and	O
approves	O
existing	O
incentive	O
plans	O
established	O
for	O
employees	O
;	O
and	O
3.	O

Approves	O
the	O
administration	O
of	O
the	O
incentive	O
plans	O
,	O
including	O
receiving	O
recommendations	O
for	O
,	O
and	O
the	O
consideration	O
and	O
approval	O
of	O
grants	O
pursuant	O
to	O
such	O
incentive	O
plans.	O

Engagement	O
of	O
Non-Executive	O
Directors	O
Non-Executive	O
Directors	O
conduct	O
their	O
duties	O
under	O
the	O
following	O
terms	O
:	O
1.	O

A	O
Non-Executive	O
Director	O
may	O
resign	O
from	O
his/her	O
position	O
and	O
thus	O
terminate	O
their	O
contract	O
on	O
written	O
notice	O
to	O
the	O
Company	O
;	O
and	O
2.	O

A	O
Non-Executive	O
Director	O
may	O
,	O
following	O
resolution	O
of	O
the	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
shareholders	O
,	O
be	O
removed	O
before	O
the	O
expiration	O
of	O
their	O
period	O
of	O
office	O
(	O
if	O
applicable	O
)	O
.	O

Payment	O
is	O
made	O
in	O
lieu	O
of	O
any	O
notice	O
period	O
if	O
termination	O
is	O
initiated	O
by	O
the	O
Company	O
,	O
except	O
where	O
termination	O
is	O
initiated	O
for	O
serious	O
misconduct.	O

In	O
consideration	O
of	O
the	O
services	O
provided	O
by	O
Mr	O
Jeff	O
Foster	O
as	O
Non-Executive	O
Director	O
the	O
Company	O
will	O
pay	O
him	O
a	O
fee	O
of	O
$40	O
,	O
000	O
per	O
annum.	O

In	O
consideration	O
of	O
the	O
services	O
provided	O
by	O
Mr	O
Rod	O
Webster	O
as	O
Non-Executive	O
Chairman	O
the	O
Company	O
will	O
pay	O
him	O
a	O
fee	O
of	O
$70	O
,	O
000	O
per	O
annum.	O

Messrs	O
Foster	O
and	O
Webster	O
are	O
also	O
entitled	O
to	O
fees	O
for	O
other	O
amounts	O
as	O
the	O
Board	O
determines	O
where	O
they	O
perform	O
special	O
duties	O
or	O
otherwise	O
perform	O
extra	O
services	O
or	O
make	O
special	O
exertions	O
on	O
behalf	O
of	O
the	O
Company.	O

There	O
were	O
no	O
such	O
fees	O
paid	O
during	O
the	O
financial	O
period	O
ended	O
30	O
June	O
2018.	O

Riversgold	O

Remuneration	O

)	O
Engagement	O
of	O
Executive	O
Directors	O
The	O
Company	O
has	O
entered	O
into	O
executive	O
service	O
agreements	O
with	O
Mr	O
Allan	O
Kelly	O
on	O
the	O
following	O
material	O
terms	O
and	O
conditions	O
:	O
Mr	O
Kelly	O
’	O
s	O
current	O
service	O
agreement	O
with	O
the	O
Company	O
,	O
in	O
respect	O
of	O
his	O
engagement	O
as	O
Managing	O
Director	O
,	O
was	O
effective	O
from	O
the	O
admission	O
of	O
the	O
Company	O
to	O
the	O

of	O
the	O
ASX	O
,	O
6	O
October	O
2017.	O

Mr	O
Kelly	O
will	O
receive	O
a	O
base	O
salary	O
of	O
$250	O
,	O
000	O
per	O
annum	O
inclusive	O
of	O
statutory	O
superannuation.	O

Mr	O
Kelly	O
may	O
also	O
receive	O
an	O
annual	O
short	O
term	O
performance	O
based	O
bonus	O
which	O
may	O
be	O
calculated	O
as	O
a	O
percentage	O
of	O
his	O
current	O
base	O
salary	O
,	O
the	O
performance	O
criteria	O
,	O
assessment	O
and	O
timing	O
of	O
which	O
is	O
negotiated	O
annually	O
with	O
the	O
Non-Executive	O
Directors.	O

If	O
a	O
cash	O
bonus	O
is	O
paid	O
it	O
is	O
likely	O
to	O
be	O
capped	O
at	O
50%	O
of	O
the	O
base	O
salary.	O

Mr	O
Kelly	O
may	O
,	O
subject	O
to	O
shareholder	O
approval	O
,	O
participate	O
in	O
the	O
Riversgold	O
Incentive	O
Option	O
Plan	O
and	O
other	O
long	O
term	O
incentive	O
plans	O
adopted	O
by	O
the	O
Board.	O

Short	O
Term	O
Incentive	O
Payments	O
Each	O
year	O
,	O
the	O
Non-Executive	O
Directors	O
set	O
the	O
Key	O
Performance	O
Indicators	O
(	O
KPI	O
’	O
s	O
)	O
for	O
Executive	O
Directors.	O

The	O
KPI	O
’	O
s	O
are	O
chosen	O
to	O
align	O
the	O
reward	O
of	O
the	O
individual	O
Executives	O
to	O
the	O
strategy	O
and	O
performance	O
of	O
the	O
Company.	O

Performance	O
objectives	O
,	O
which	O
may	O
be	O
financial	O
or	O
non-financial	O
,	O
or	O
a	O
combination	O
of	O
both	O
,	O
are	O
weighted	O
when	O
calculating	O
the	O
maximum	O
short	O
term	O
incentives	O
payable	O
to	O
Executives.	O

At	O
the	O
end	O
of	O
the	O
year	O
,	O
the	O
Non-Executive	O
Directors	O
will	O
assess	O
the	O
actual	O
performance	O
of	O
the	O
Executives	O
against	O
the	O
set	O
Performance	O
Objectives.	O

The	O
maximum	O
amount	O
of	O
the	O
Short	O
Term	O
Incentive	O
,	O
or	O
a	O
lesser	O
amount	O
depending	O
on	O
actual	O
performance	O
achieved	O
is	O
paid	O
to	O
the	O
Executives	O
as	O
a	O
cash	O
payment.	O

No	O
Short	O
Term	O
incentives	O
are	O
payable	O
to	O
Executives	O
where	O
it	O
is	O
considered	O
that	O
the	O
actual	O
performance	O
has	O
fallen	O
below	O
the	O
minimum	O
requirement.	O

Shareholding	O
Qualifications	O
The	O
Directors	O
are	O
not	O
required	O
to	O
hold	O
any	O
shares	O
in	O
Riversgold	O
under	O
the	O
terms	O
of	O
the	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
constitution.	O

Group	O
Performance	O

the	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
performance	O
,	O
the	O

will	O

the	O

indices	O
in	O
respect	O
of	O
the	O
current	O
financial	O

Officers	O
’	O
Indemnities	O
and	O
Insurance	O
During	O
the	O
year	O
the	O
Company	O
paid	O
an	O
insurance	O
premium	O
to	O
insure	O
certain	O
officers	O
of	O
the	O
Company.	O

The	O
officers	O
of	O
the	O
Company	O
covered	O
by	O
the	O
insurance	O
policy	O
include	O
the	O
Directors	O
named	O
in	O
this	O
report.	O

The	O
Directors	O
and	O
Officers	O
Liability	O
insurance	O
provides	O
cover	O
against	O
all	O
costs	O
and	O
expenses	O
that	O
may	O
be	O
incurred	O
in	O
defending	O
civil	O
or	O
criminal	O
proceedings	O
that	O
fall	O
within	O
the	O
scope	O
of	O
the	O
indemnity	O
and	O
that	O
may	O
be	O
brought	O
against	O
the	O
officers	O
in	O
their	O
capacity	O
as	O
officers	O
of	O
the	O
Company.	O

The	O
insurance	O
policy	O
does	O
not	O
contain	O
details	O
of	O
the	O
premium	O
paid	O
in	O
respect	O
of	O
individual	O
officers	O
of	O
the	O
Company.	O

Disclosure	O
of	O
the	O
nature	O
of	O
the	O
liability	O
cover	O
and	O
the	O
amount	O
of	O
the	O
premium	O
is	O
subject	O
to	O
a	O
confidentiality	O
clause	O
under	O
the	O
insurance	O
policy.	O

Company	O
has	O
not	O
provided	O
any	O
insurance	O
for	O
an	O
auditor	O
of	O

The	O
board	O
considers	O
any	O
non-audit	O
services	O
provided	O
during	O
the	O
year	O
by	O
the	O
auditor	O
and	O
satisfies	O
itself	O

any	O

during	O
the	O
year	O
by	O
the	O
auditor	O
is	O
compatible	O
with	O
,	O
and	O
does	O
not	O
compromise	O
,	O
the	O
auditor	O
independence	O
requirements	O
of	O
the	O
Corporations	O
Act	O
2001	O
for	O
the	O
following	O
reasons	O
:	O
	O

all	O

services	O
are	O
reviewed	O
by	O
the	O
board	O
to	O

they	O
do	O
not	O
impact	O
the	O
impartiality	O
and	O
objectivity	O
of	O
the	O
auditor	O
;	O
and	O
	O

the	O
non-audit	O
services	O
provided	O
do	O
not	O
undermine	O
the	O
general	O
principles	O
relating	O
to	O
auditor	O
independence	O
as	O
set	O
out	O
in	O
APES	O
110	O
Code	O
of	O

for	O

Accountants	O
,	O

they	O
do	O
not	O

or	O
auditing	O

own	O
work	O
,	O

33	O
Riversgold	O

64	O
617	O
614	O
598	O
Notes	O
to	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Financial	O
Statements	O
For	O
the	O
financial	O
year	O
ended	O
30	O
June	O
2018	O
Note	O
1	O
Summary	O
of	O
significant	O
accounting	O
policies	O
Riversgold	O
Limited	O
(	O
‘	O
the	O
Company	O
’	O
)	O
is	O
a	O
listed	O
public	O
company	O
domiciled	O
in	O
Australia.	O

The	O
consolidated	O
financial	O
report	O
of	O
the	O
Company	O
for	O
the	O
financial	O
year	O
ended	O
30	O
June	O
2018	O
comprises	O
the	O
Company	O
and	O
its	O
subsidiaries	O
(	O
together	O
referred	O
to	O
as	O
the	O
‘	O
Group	O
’	O
)	O
.	O

The	O
following	O
is	O
a	O
summary	O
of	O
the	O
material	O
accounting	O
policies	O
adopted	O
by	O
the	O
Group	O
in	O
the	O
preparation	O
of	O
the	O
financial	O
report.	O

The	O
accounting	O
policies	O
have	O
been	O
consistently	O
applied	O
,	O
unless	O
otherwise	O
stated.	O

The	O
comparative	O
figures	O
in	O
the	O
statement	O
of	O
profit	O
or	O
loss	O
and	O
other	O
comprehensive	O
income	O
,	O
statement	O
of	O
changes	O
in	O
equity	O
,	O
statement	O
of	O
cashflows	O
and	O
related	O
notes	O
are	O
for	O
the	O
period	O
from	O
the	O
date	O
of	O
incorporation	O
24	O
February	O
2017	O
to	O
30	O
June	O
2017.	O

(	O
a	O
)	O
Basis	O
of	O
preparation	O
This	O
general	O
purpose	O
financial	O
report	O
has	O
been	O
prepared	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
Australian	O
equivalents	O
to	O
International	O
Financial	O
Reporting	O
Standards	O
(	O
AIFRS	O
)	O
,	O
other	O
authoritative	O
pronouncements	O
of	O
the	O
Australian	O
Accounting	O
Standards	O
Board	O
and	O
the	O
Corporations	O
Act	O
2001.The	O
Group	O
is	O
a	O
for-profit	O
entity	O
for	O
financial	O
reporting	O
purposes	O
under	O
Australian	O
Accounting	O
Standards.	O

The	O
financial	O
report	O
is	O
presented	O
in	O
Australian	O
dollars	O
and	O
all	O
values	O
are	O
rounded	O
to	O
the	O
nearest	O
dollar.	O

The	O
financial	O
report	O
of	O
the	O
Group	O
was	O
authorised	O
for	O
issue	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
a	O
resolution	O
of	O
Directors	O
on	O
27th	O
September	O
2018.	O

Going	O
Concern	O
Notwithstanding	O
the	O
Group	O
had	O
working	O
capital	O
of	O
$2	O
,	O
702	O
,	O
552	O
(	O
2017	O
:	O
$162	O
,	O
602	O
)	O
as	O
at	O
balance	O
date	O
,	O
the	O
Directors	O
recognise	O
the	O
Group	O
is	O
dependent	O
on	O
capital	O
raises	O
to	O
meet	O
expenditure	O
forecasts.	O

The	O
Directors	O
believe	O
the	O
Group	O
will	O
be	O
able	O
to	O
raise	O
sufficient	O
funds	O
to	O
meet	O
its	O
obligations	O
as	O
and	O
when	O
they	O
fall	O
due.	O

In	O
the	O
event	O
the	O
Group	O
does	O
not	O
achieve	O
the	O
matter	O
set	O
out	O
above	O
,	O
there	O
is	O
a	O
material	O
uncertainty	O
that	O
may	O
cast	O
significant	O
doubt	O
whether	O
the	O
Group	O
will	O
continue	O
as	O
a	O
going	O
concern	O
and	O
therefore	O
whether	O
it	O
will	O
realise	O
its	O
assets	O
and	O
extinguish	O
its	O
liabilities	O
in	O
the	O
normal	O
course	O
of	O
business	O
and	O
at	O
the	O
amounts	O
stated	O
in	O
the	O
financial	O
statements.	O

Statement	O
of	O
Compliance	O
The	O
consolidated	O
financial	O
report	O
of	O
Riversgold	O
Limited	O
complies	O
with	O
Australian	O
Accounting	O
Standards	O
,	O
which	O
include	O
Australian	O
Equivalents	O
to	O
International	O
Financial	O
Reporting	O
Standards	O
(	O
AIFRS	O
)	O
,	O
in	O
their	O
entirety.	O

Compliance	O
with	O
AIFRS	O
ensures	O
that	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
also	O
complies	O
with	O
International	O
Financial	O
Reporting	O
Standards	O
(	O
IFRS	O
)	O
in	O
their	O
entirety.	O

Adoption	O
of	O
New	O
and	O
Revised	O
Standards	O
-	O

Changes	O
in	O
accounting	O
policies	O
on	O
initial	O
application	O
of	O
accounting	O
standards	O
Application	O
of	O
new	O
or	O
revised	O
accounting	O
standards	O
In	O
the	O
year	O
ended	O
30	O
June	O
2018	O
,	O
the	O
Group	O
has	O
reviewed	O
all	O
of	O
the	O
new	O
and	O
revised	O
Standards	O
and	O
Interpretations	O
issued	O
by	O
the	O
AASB	O
that	O
are	O
relevant	O
to	O
its	O
operations	O
and	O
effective	O
for	O
the	O
current	O
reporting	O
period.	O

It	O
has	O
been	O
determined	O
by	O
the	O
Group	O
that	O
there	O
is	O
no	O
material	O
impact	O
of	O
the	O
new	O
and	O
revised	O
Standards	O
and	O
Interpretations	O
on	O
its	O
business	O
and	O
,	O
therefore	O
,	O
no	O
material	O
change	O
is	O
necessary	O
to	O
Group	O
accounting	O
policies.	O

New	O
Accounting	O
Standards	O
and	O
Interpretations	O
not	O
yet	O
mandatory	O
or	O
early	O
adopted	O
Australian	O
Accounting	O
Standards	O
and	O
Interpretations	O
that	O
have	O
recently	O
been	O
issued	O
or	O
amended	O
,	O
but	O
are	O
not	O
yet	O
mandatory	O
,	O
have	O
not	O
been	O
early	O
adopted	O
by	O
the	O
Group	O
for	O
the	O
reporting	O
period	O
ended	O
30	O
June	O
2018.	O

The	O
Group	O
’	O
s	O
assessment	O
of	O
the	O
impact	O
of	O
these	O
new	O
or	O
amended	O
Accounting	O
Standards	O
and	O
Interpretations	O
most	O
relevant	O
to	O
the	O
Group	O
are	O
set	O
out	O
below	O
:	O
34	O
Riversgold	O
Limited	O
ABN	O
64	O
617	O
614	O
598	O
Notes	O
to	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Financial	O
Statements	O
For	O
the	O
financial	O
year	O
ended	O
30	O
June	O
2018	O
Note	O
1	O
Summary	O
of	O
significant	O
accounting	O
policies	O
(	O
continued	O
)	O
(	O
a	O
)	O
Basis	O
of	O
preparation	O
(	O
continued	O
)	O
New	O
Accounting	O
Standards	O
and	O
Interpretations	O
not	O
yet	O
mandatory	O
or	O
early	O
adopted	O
(	O
continued	O
)	O
AASB	O
9	O
Financial	O
Instruments	O
This	O
standard	O
is	O
applicable	O
to	O
annual	O
reporting	O
periods	O
beginning	O
on	O
or	O
after	O
1	O
January	O
2018.	O

The	O
standard	O
replaces	O
all	O
previous	O
versions	O
of	O
AASB	O
9	O
and	O
completes	O
the	O
project	O
to	O
replace	O
IAS	O
39	O
“	O
Financial	O
Instruments	O
:	O
Recognition	O
and	O
Measurement	O
”	O
.	O

AASB	O
9	O
introduces	O
new	O
classification	O
and	O
measurement	O
models	O
for	O
financial	O
assets.	O

A	O
financial	O
asset	O
shall	O
be	O
measured	O
at	O
amortised	O
cost	O
,	O
if	O
it	O
is	O
held	O
within	O
a	O
business	O
model	O
whose	O
objective	O
is	O
to	O
hold	O
assets	O
in	O
order	O
to	O
collect	O
contractual	O
cash	O
flows	O
,	O
which	O
arise	O
on	O
specified	O
dates	O
and	O
solely	O
principal	O
and	O
interest.	O

All	O
other	O
financial	O
instrument	O
assets	O
are	O
to	O
be	O
classified	O
and	O
measured	O
at	O
fair	O
value	O
through	O
profit	O
or	O
loss	O
unless	O
the	O
entity	O
makes	O
an	O
irrevocable	O
election	O
on	O
initial	O
recognition	O
to	O
present	O
gains	O
and	O
losses	O
on	O
equity	O
instruments	O
(	O
that	O
are	O
not	O
held-for-trading	O
)	O
in	O
other	O
comprehensive	O
income	O
(	O
“	O
OCI	O
”	O
)	O
.	O

For	O
financial	O
liabilities	O
,	O
the	O
standard	O
requires	O
the	O
portion	O
of	O
the	O
change	O
in	O
fair	O
value	O
that	O
relates	O
to	O
the	O
entity	O
’	O
s	O
own	O
credit	O
risk	O
to	O
be	O
presented	O
in	O
OCI	O
(	O
unless	O
it	O
would	O
create	O
an	O
accounting	O
mismatch	O
)	O
.	O

New	O
simpler	O
hedge	O
accounting	O
requirements	O
are	O
intended	O
to	O
more	O
closely	O
align	O
the	O
accounting	O
treatment	O
with	O
the	O
risk	O
management	O
activities	O
of	O
the	O
entity.	O

New	O
impairment	O
requirements	O
will	O
use	O
an	O
‘	O
expected	O
credit	O
loss	O
’	O
(	O
“	O
ECL	O
”	O
)	O
model	O
to	O
recognise	O
an	O
allowance.	O

Impairment	O
will	O
be	O
measured	O
under	O
a	O
12-month	O
ECL	O
method	O
unless	O
the	O
credit	O
risk	O
on	O
a	O
financial	O
instrument	O
has	O
increased	O
significantly	O
since	O
initial	O
recognition	O
in	O
which	O
case	O
the	O
lifetime	O
ECL	O
method	O
is	O
adopted.	O

The	O
standard	O
introduces	O
additional	O
new	O
disclosures.	O

The	O
Group	O
does	O
not	O
expect	O
any	O
material	O
impact	O
from	O
the	O
ultimate	O
adoption	O
of	O
AASB	O
9.	O

AASB	O
16	O
Leases	O
This	O
standard	O
is	O
applicable	O
to	O
annual	O
reporting	O
periods	O
beginning	O
on	O
or	O
after	O
1	O
January	O
2019.	O

The	O
standard	O
replaces	O
AASB	O
117	O
”	O
Leases	O
”	O
and	O
for	O
lessees	O
will	O
eliminate	O
the	O
classifications	O
of	O
operating	O
leases	O
and	O
finance	O
leases.	O

Subject	O
to	O
exceptions	O
,	O
a	O
”	O
right-of-use	O
”	O
asset	O
will	O
be	O
capitalised	O
in	O
the	O
statement	O
of	O
financial	O
position	O
,	O
measured	O
as	O
the	O
present	O
value	O
of	O
the	O
unavoidable	O
future	O
lease	O
payments	O
to	O
be	O
made	O
over	O
the	O
lease	O
term.	O

The	O
exceptions	O
relate	O
to	O
short-term	O
leases	O
of	O
12	O
months	O
or	O
less	O
and	O
leases	O
of	O
low-value	O
assets	O
(	O
such	O
as	O
personal	O
computers	O
and	O
small	O
office	O
furniture	O
)	O
where	O
an	O
accounting	O
policy	O
choice	O
exists	O
whereby	O
either	O
a	O
”	O
right-of-use	O
”	O
asset	O
is	O
recognised	O
or	O
lease	O
payments	O
are	O
expensed	O
to	O
profit	O
or	O
loss	O
as	O
incurred.	O

A	O
liability	O
corresponding	O
to	O
the	O
capitalised	O
lease	O
will	O
also	O
be	O
recognised	O
,	O
adjusted	O
for	O
lease	O
prepayments	O
,	O
lease	O
incentives	O
received	O
,	O
initial	O
direct	O
costs	O
incurred	O
and	O
an	O
estimate	O
of	O
any	O
future	O
restoration	O
,	O
removal	O
or	O
dismantling	O
costs.	O

Straight-line	O
operating	O
lease	O
expense	O
recognition	O
will	O
be	O
replaced	O
with	O
a	O
depreciation	O
charge	O
for	O
the	O
leased	O
asset	O
(	O
included	O
in	O
operating	O
costs	O
)	O
and	O
an	O
interest	O
expense	O
on	O
the	O
recognised	O
lease	O
liability	O
(	O
included	O
in	O
finance	O
costs	O
)	O
.	O

In	O
the	O
earlier	O
periods	O
of	O
the	O
lease	O
,	O
the	O
expenses	O
associated	O
with	O
the	O
lease	O
under	O
AASB	O
16	O
will	O
be	O
higher	O
when	O
compared	O
to	O
lease	O
expenses	O
under	O
AASB	O
117.	O

However	O
,	O
EBITDA	O
(	O
Earnings	O
Before	O
Interest	O
,	O
Tax	O
,	O
Depreciation	O
and	O
Amortisation	O
)	O
results	O
will	O
be	O
improved	O
as	O
the	O
operating	O
expense	O
is	O
replaced	O
by	O
interest	O
expense	O
and	O
depreciation	O
in	O
profit	O
or	O
loss	O
under	O
AASB	O
16.	O

For	O
classification	O
within	O
the	O
statement	O
of	O
cash	O
flows	O
,	O
the	O
lease	O
payments	O
will	O
be	O
separated	O
into	O
both	O
a	O
principal	O
(	O
financing	O
activities	O
)	O
and	O
interest	O
(	O
either	O
operating	O
or	O
financing	O
activities	O
)	O
component.	O

For	O
lessor	O
accounting	O
,	O
the	O
standard	O
does	O
not	O
substantially	O
change	O
how	O
a	O
lessor	O
accounts	O
for	O
leases.	O

The	O
Group	O
will	O
adopt	O
this	O
standard	O
from	O
1	O
July	O
2019.	O

Management	O
has	O
reviewed	O
the	O
impact	O
and	O
recognises	O
there	O
will	O
be	O
a	O
material	O
change	O
in	O
relation	O
to	O
the	O
accounting	O
treatment	O
for	O
its	O
office	O
lease.	O

Whilst	O
this	O
will	O
result	O
in	O
recognising	O
both	O
an	O
asset	O
and	O
liability	O
,	O
it	O
will	O
not	O
materially	O
impact	O
the	O
overall	O
net	O
asset	O
position.	O

Riversgold	O

Note	O
1	O
Summary	O
of	O
significant	O
accounting	O
policies	O
(	O
continued	O
)	O
(	O
a	O
)	O
Basis	O
of	O
preparation	O
(	O
continued	O
)	O
Reporting	O
basis	O
and	O
conventions	O
These	O
financial	O
statements	O
have	O
been	O
prepared	O
under	O
the	O
historical	O
cost	O
convention	O
,	O
and	O
on	O
an	O
accrual	O
basis.	O

Critical	O
accounting	O
estimates	O
The	O
preparation	O
of	O
financial	O
statements	O
in	O
conformity	O
with	O
AIFRS	O
requires	O
the	O
use	O
of	O
certain	O
critical	O
accounting	O
estimates.	O

It	O
also	O
requires	O
management	O
to	O
exercise	O
its	O
judgement	O
in	O
the	O
process	O
of	O
applying	O
the	O
Group	O
’	O
s	O
accounting	O
policies.	O

The	O
areas	O
involving	O
a	O
higher	O
degree	O
of	O
judgement	O
or	O
complexity	O
,	O
or	O
areas	O
where	O
assumptions	O
and	O
estimates	O
are	O
significant	O
to	O
the	O
financial	O
statements	O
,	O
are	O
disclosed	O
in	O
note	O
3.	O

Principles	O
of	O
consolidation	O
The	O
financial	O
statements	O
of	O
subsidiary	O
companies	O
are	O
included	O
in	O
the	O
consolidated	O
financial	O
statements	O
from	O
the	O
date	O
control	O
commences	O
until	O
the	O
date	O
control	O
ceases.	O

The	O
financial	O
statements	O
of	O
subsidiary	O
companies	O
are	O
prepared	O
for	O
the	O
same	O
reporting	O
period	O
as	O
the	O
parent	O
company	O
,	O
using	O
consistent	O
accounting	O
policies.	O

Inter-entity	O
balances	O
resulting	O
from	O
transactions	O
with	O
or	O
between	O
controlled	O
entities	O
are	O
eliminated	O
in	O
full	O
on	O
consolidation.	O

Investments	O
in	O
subsidiary	O
companies	O
are	O
accounted	O
for	O
at	O
cost	O
in	O
the	O
individual	O
financial	O
statements	O
of	O
the	O
Company.	O

(	O
b	O
)	O
Segment	O
reporting	O
Operating	O
segments	O
are	O
identified	O
and	O
segment	O
information	O
disclosed	O
,	O
where	O
appropriate	O
,	O
on	O
the	O
basis	O
of	O
internal	O
reports	O
reviewed	O
by	O
the	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
board	O
of	O
directors	O
,	O
being	O
the	O
Group	O
’	O
s	O
Chief	O
Operating	O
Decision	O
Maker	O
,	O
as	O
defined	O
by	O
AASB	O
8.	O

Adoption	O
of	O
AASB	O
8	O
by	O
the	O
Group	O
has	O
not	O
resulted	O
in	O
a	O
redefinition	O
of	O
previously	O
reported	O
operating	O
segments.	O

(	O
c	O
)	O
Revenue	O
recognition	O
and	O
receivables	O
Revenue	O
is	O
measured	O
at	O
the	O
fair	O
value	O
of	O
the	O
consideration	O
received	O
or	O
receivable.	O

Amounts	O
disclosed	O
as	O
revenue	O
are	O
net	O
of	O
returns	O
,	O
allowances	O
and	O
amounts	O
collectable	O
on	O
behalf	O
of	O
third	O
parties.	O

Interest	O
income	O
Interest	O
income	O
is	O
recognised	O
on	O
a	O
time	O
proportion	O
basis	O
and	O
is	O
recognised	O
as	O
it	O
accrues.	O

(	O
d	O
)	O
Income	O
tax	O
The	O
income	O
tax	O
expense	O
or	O
revenue	O
for	O
the	O
period	O
is	O
the	O
tax	O
payable	O
on	O
the	O
current	O
period	O
’	O
s	O
taxable	O
income	O
based	O
on	O
the	O
national	O
income	O
tax	O
rate	O
for	O
each	O
jurisdiction	O
adjusted	O
by	O
changes	O
in	O
deferred	O
tax	O
assets	O
and	O
liabilities	O
attributable	O
to	O
the	O
temporary	O
differences	O
between	O
the	O
tax	O
bases	O
of	O
assets	O
and	O
liabilities	O
and	O
their	O
carrying	O
amounts	O
in	O
the	O
financial	O
statements	O
,	O
and	O
to	O
unused	O
tax	O
losses.	O

Deferred	O
tax	O
assets	O
and	O
liabilities	O
are	O
recognised	O
for	O
temporary	O
timing	O
differences	O
at	O
the	O
tax	O
rates	O
expected	O
to	O
apply	O
when	O
the	O
assets	O
are	O
recovered	O
or	O
liabilities	O
are	O
settled	O
,	O
based	O
on	O
those	O
tax	O
rates	O
which	O
are	O
enacted	O
or	O
substantially	O
enacted	O
for	O
each	O
jurisdiction.	O

The	O
relevant	O
tax	O
rates	O
are	O
applied	O
to	O
the	O
cumulative	O
amounts	O
of	O
deductible	O
and	O
taxable	O
temporary	O
differences	O
to	O
measure	O
the	O
deferred	O
tax	O
asset	O
or	O
liability.	O

An	O
exception	O
is	O
made	O
for	O
certain	O
temporary	O
differences	O
arising	O
from	O
the	O
initial	O
recognition	O
of	O
an	O
asset	O
or	O
a	O
liability.	O

No	O
deferred	O
tax	O
asset	O
or	O
liability	O
is	O
recognised	O
in	O
relation	O
to	O
those	O
timing	O
differences	O
if	O
they	O
arose	O
in	O
a	O
transaction	O
,	O
other	O
than	O
a	O
business	O
combination	O
,	O
that	O
at	O
the	O
time	O
of	O
the	O
transaction	O
did	O
not	O
affect	O
either	O
accounting	O
profit	O
or	O
taxable	O
profit	O
or	O
loss.	O

36	O
Riversgold	O
Limited	O
ABN	O
64	O
617	O
614	O
598	O
Notes	O
to	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Financial	O
Statements	O
For	O
the	O
financial	O
year	O
ended	O
30	O
June	O
2018	O
Note	O
1	O
Summary	O
of	O
significant	O
accounting	O
policies	O
(	O
continued	O
)	O
(	O
d	O
)	O
Income	O
tax	O
(	O
continued	O
)	O
Deferred	O
tax	O
assets	O
are	O
recognised	O
for	O
deductible	O
temporary	O
differences	O
and	O
unused	O
tax	O
losses	O
only	O
if	O
it	O
is	O
probable	O
that	O
future	O
taxable	O
amounts	O
will	O
be	O
available	O
to	O
utilise	O
those	O
temporary	O
differences	O
and	O
losses.	O

Deferred	O
tax	O
liabilities	O
and	O
assets	O
are	O
not	O
recognised	O
for	O
temporary	O
differences	O
between	O
the	O
carrying	O
amount	O
and	O
tax	O
bases	O
of	O
investments	O
in	O
controlled	O
entities	O
where	O
the	O
parent	O
is	O
able	O
to	O
control	O
the	O
timing	O
of	O
the	O
reversal	O
of	O
the	O
temporary	O
differences	O
and	O
it	O
is	O
probable	O
that	O
the	O
differences	O
will	O
not	O
reverse	O
in	O
the	O
foreseeable	O
future.	O

Deferred	O
tax	O
assets	O
and	O
liabilities	O
are	O
offset	O
when	O
there	O
is	O
a	O
legally	O
enforceable	O
right	O
to	O
offset	O
current	O
tax	O
assets	O
and	O
liabilities	O
and	O
when	O
the	O
deferred	O
tax	O
balances	O
relate	O
to	O
the	O
same	O
taxation	O
authority.	O

Current	O
tax	O
assets	O
and	O
liabilities	O
are	O
offset	O
where	O
the	O
entity	O
has	O
a	O
legally	O
enforceable	O
right	O
to	O
offset	O
and	O
intends	O
either	O
to	O
settle	O
on	O
a	O
net	O
basis	O
,	O
or	O
to	O
realise	O
the	O
asset	O
and	O
settle	O
the	O
liability	O
simultaneously.	O

Current	O
and	O
deferred	O
tax	O
balances	O
attributable	O
to	O
amounts	O
recognised	O
directly	O
in	O
equity	O
are	O
also	O
recognised	O
directly	O
in	O
equity.	O

(	O
e	O
)	O
Leases	O
Leases	O
in	O
which	O
a	O
significant	O
portion	O
of	O
the	O
risks	O
and	O
rewards	O
of	O
ownership	O
are	O
retained	O
by	O
the	O
lessor	O
are	O
classified	O
as	O
operating	O
leases	O
(	O
note	O
25	O
)	O
.	O

Payments	O
made	O
under	O
operating	O
leases	O
(	O
net	O
of	O
any	O
incentives	O
received	O
from	O
the	O
lessor	O
)	O
are	O
charged	O
to	O
profit	O
or	O
loss	O
on	O
a	O
straight	O
line	O
basis	O
over	O
the	O
period	O
of	O
the	O
lease.	O

(	O
f	O
)	O
Impairment	O
of	O
assets	O
Assets	O
are	O
reviewed	O
for	O
impairment	O
whenever	O
events	O
or	O
changes	O
in	O
circumstances	O
indicate	O
that	O
the	O
carrying	O
amount	O
may	O
not	O
be	O
recoverable.	O

An	O
impairment	O
loss	O
is	O
recognised	O
for	O
the	O
amount	O
by	O
which	O
the	O
asset	O
’	O
s	O
carrying	O
amount	O
exceeds	O
its	O
recoverable	O
amount.	O

The	O
recoverable	O
amount	O
is	O
the	O
higher	O
of	O
an	O
asset	O
’	O
s	O
fair	O
value	O
less	O
costs	O
to	O
sell	O
and	O
value	O
in	O
use.	O

For	O
the	O
purposes	O
of	O
assessing	O
impairment	O
,	O
assets	O
are	O
grouped	O
at	O
the	O
lowest	O
levels	O
for	O
which	O
there	O
are	O
separately	O
identifiable	O
cash	O
inflows	O
which	O
are	O
largely	O
independent	O
of	O
the	O
cash	O
inflows	O
from	O
other	O
assets	O
or	O
groups	O
of	O
assets	O
(	O
cash	O
generating	O
units	O
)	O
.	O

Non	O
financial	O
assets	O
,	O
other	O
than	O
goodwill	O
,	O
that	O
suffered	O
an	O
impairment	O
are	O
reviewed	O
for	O
possible	O
reversal	O
of	O
the	O
impairment	O
at	O
each	O
reporting	O
date.	O

(	O
g	O
)	O
Cash	O
and	O
cash	O
equivalents	O
For	O
cash	O
flow	O
statement	O
presentation	O
purposes	O
,	O
cash	O
and	O
cash	O
equivalents	O
includes	O
cash	O
on	O
hand	O
,	O
deposits	O
held	O
at	O
call	O
with	O
financial	O
institutions	O
,	O
other	O
short	O
term	O
,	O
highly	O
liquid	O
investments	O
with	O
original	O
maturities	O
of	O
three	O
months	O
or	O
less	O
that	O
are	O
readily	O
convertible	O
to	O
known	O
amounts	O
of	O
cash	O
and	O
which	O
are	O
subject	O
to	O
an	O
insignificant	O
risk	O
of	O
changes	O
in	O
value.	O

(	O
h	O
)	O
Government	O
grants	O
Government	O
grants	O
are	O
recognised	O
at	O
fair	O
value	O
where	O
there	O
is	O
reasonable	O
assurance	O
that	O
the	O
grant	O
will	O
be	O
received	O
and	O
all	O
grant	O
conditions	O
will	O
be	O
met.	O

Grants	O
relating	O
to	O
expense	O
items	O
are	O
recognised	O
as	O
income	O
over	O
the	O
periods	O
necessary	O
to	O
match	O
the	O
grant	O
to	O
the	O
costs	O
they	O
are	O
compensating.	O

Grants	O
relating	O
to	O
assets	O
are	O
deducted	O
from	O
the	O
carrying	O
value	O
of	O
the	O
relevant	O
asset.	O

Amounts	O
receivable	O
from	O
the	O
Australian	O
Tax	O
Office	O
in	O
respect	O
of	O
research	O
and	O
development	O
tax	O
concession	O
claims	O
are	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
year	O
in	O
which	O
the	O
claim	O
is	O
lodged	O
with	O
the	O
Australian	O
Tax	O
Office.	O

Amounts	O
receivable	O
are	O
allocated	O
in	O
the	O
financial	O
statements	O
against	O
the	O
corresponding	O
expense	O
or	O
asset	O
in	O
respect	O
of	O
which	O
the	O
research	O
and	O
development	O
concession	O
claim	O
has	O
arisen.	O

1	O
Summary	O
of	O
significant	O

policies	O
(	O

)	O
(	O
i	O
)	O
Fair	O
value	O
estimation	O
The	O
nominal	O
value	O
less	O
estimated	O
credit	O
adjustments	O
of	O
trade	O
receivables	O
and	O
payables	O
are	O
assumed	O
to	O
approximate	O
their	O
fair	O
values.	O

The	O
fair	O
value	O
of	O
financial	O
liabilities	O
for	O
disclosure	O
purposes	O
is	O
estimated	O
by	O
discounting	O
the	O
future	O
contractual	O
cash	O
flows	O
at	O
the	O
current	O
market	O
interest	O
rate	O
that	O
is	O
available	O
to	O
the	O
Group	O
for	O
similar	O
financial	O
instruments.	O

(	O
j	O
)	O
Property	O
,	O
plant	O
and	O
equipment	O
Property	O
,	O
plant	O
and	O
equipment	O
is	O
stated	O
at	O
historical	O
cost	O
less	O
depreciation.	O

Historical	O
cost	O
includes	O
expenditure	O
that	O
is	O
directly	O
attributable	O
to	O
the	O
acquisition	O
of	O
the	O
assets.	O

Subsequent	O
costs	O
are	O
included	O
in	O
the	O
asset	O
’	O
s	O
carrying	O
amount	O
or	O
recognised	O
as	O
a	O
separate	O
asset	O
,	O
as	O
appropriate	O
,	O
only	O
when	O
it	O
is	O
probable	O
that	O
future	O
economic	O
benefits	O
associated	O
with	O
the	O
item	O
will	O
flow	O
to	O
the	O
Group	O
and	O
the	O
cost	O
of	O
the	O
item	O
can	O
be	O
measured	O
reliably.	O

All	O
other	O
repairs	O
and	O
maintenance	O
are	O
charged	O
to	O
the	O
income	O
statement	O
during	O
the	O
financial	O
period	O
in	O
which	O
they	O
are	O
incurred.	O

Depreciation	O
of	O
property	O
,	O
plant	O
and	O
equipment	O
is	O
calculated	O
using	O
the	O
straight	O
line	O
and	O
diminishing	O
value	O
methods	O
to	O
allocate	O
their	O
cost	O
,	O
net	O
of	O
residual	O
values	O
,	O
over	O
their	O
estimated	O
useful	O
lives.	O

The	O
asset	O
’	O
s	O
residual	O
values	O
and	O
useful	O
lives	O
are	O
reviewed	O
,	O
and	O
adjusted	O
if	O
appropriate	O
,	O
at	O
each	O
balance	O
sheet	O
date.	O

An	O
asset	O
’	O
s	O
carrying	O
amount	O
is	O
written	O
down	O
immediately	O
to	O
its	O
recoverable	O
amount	O
if	O
the	O
asset	O
’	O
s	O
carrying	O
amount	O
is	O
greater	O
than	O
its	O
estimated	O
recoverable	O
amount	O
(	O
note	O
1	O
(	O
f	O
)	O
)	O
.	O

Gains	O
and	O
losses	O
on	O
disposal	O
are	O
determined	O
by	O
comparing	O
proceeds	O
with	O
the	O
carrying	O
amount.	O

These	O
gains	O
and	O
losses	O
are	O
included	O
in	O
the	O
profit	O
or	O
loss.	O

(	O
k	O
)	O
Mineral	O
exploration	O
and	O
evaluation	O
expenditure	O
Mineral	O
exploration	O
and	O
evaluation	O
expenditure	O
is	O
written	O
off	O
as	O
incurred	O
or	O
accumulated	O
in	O
respect	O
of	O
each	O
identifiable	O
area	O
of	O
interest	O
and	O
capitalised.	O

These	O
costs	O
are	O
carried	O
forward	O
only	O
if	O
they	O
relate	O
to	O
an	O
area	O
of	O
interest	O
for	O
which	O
rights	O
of	O
tenure	O
are	O
current	O
and	O
in	O
respect	O
of	O
which	O
:	O
•	O

such	O
costs	O
are	O
expected	O
to	O
be	O
recouped	O
through	O
the	O
successful	O
development	O
and	O
exploitation	O
of	O
the	O
area	O
of	O
interest	O
,	O
or	O
alternatively	O
by	O
its	O
sale	O
;	O
or	O
•	O

exploration	O
and/or	O
evaluation	O
activities	O
in	O
the	O
area	O
have	O
not	O
reached	O
a	O
stage	O
which	O
permits	O
a	O
reasonable	O
assessment	O
of	O
the	O
existence	O
or	O
otherwise	O
of	O
economically	O
recoverable	O
reserves	O
and	O
active	O
or	O
significant	O
operations	O
in	O
,	O
or	O
in	O
relation	O
to	O
,	O
the	O
area	O
of	O
interest	O
are	O
continuing.	O

In	O
the	O
event	O
that	O
an	O
area	O
of	O
interest	O
is	O
abandoned	O
or	O
if	O
the	O
Directors	O
consider	O
the	O
expenditure	O
to	O
be	O
of	O
reduced	O
value	O
,	O
accumulated	O
costs	O
carried	O
forward	O
are	O
written	O
off	O
in	O
the	O
year	O
in	O
which	O
that	O
assessment	O
is	O
made.	O

A	O
regular	O
review	O
is	O
undertaken	O
of	O
each	O
area	O
of	O
interest	O
to	O
determine	O
the	O
appropriateness	O
of	O
continuing	O
to	O
carry	O
forward	O
costs	O
in	O
relation	O
to	O
that	O
area	O
of	O
interest.	O

Immediate	O
restoration	O
,	O

and	O
environmental	O
costs	O
necessitated	O
by	O
exploration	O
and	O

activities	O
are	O
expensed	O
as	O
incurred	O
and	O

as	O

and	O

Exploration	O

costs	O

,	O
of	O
restoration	O
and	O

over	O
the	O
useful	O

of	O
the	O
asset.	O

The	O

of	O

effect	O
of	O

on	O
the	O
provision	O
is	O
recorded	O
as	O
a	O
finance	O
cost	O
in	O

income	O
statement.	O

)	O

)	O
Farm-in	O

(	O

and	O

)	O
For	O
exploration	O
and	O
evaluation	O
asset	O
acquisitions	O
(	O

)	O
in	O
which	O
the	O
Group	O
has	O

to	O

a	O

of	O
the	O
selling	O
partner's	O
(	O
farmor's	O
)	O

and/or	O
future	O

(	O

interests	O
)	O
,	O
these	O

are	O

as	O
and	O
when	O
the	O
exploration	O
and	O

work	O

Farm-out	O
arrangements	O
(	O
in	O
the	O
exploration	O
and	O
evaluation	O
phase	O
)	O
The	O
Group	O
does	O
not	O
record	O
any	O
expenditure	O
made	O
by	O
the	O
farmee	O
on	O
its	O
account.	O

It	O
also	O
does	O
not	O
recognise	O
any	O
gain	O
or	O
loss	O
on	O
its	O
exploration	O
and	O
evaluation	O
farm-out	O
arrangements	O
but	O
redesignates	O
any	O
costs	O
previously	O
capitalised	O
in	O
relation	O
to	O
the	O
whole	O
interest	O
as	O
relating	O
to	O
the	O
partial	O
interest	O
retained.	O

Monies	O
received	O
pursuant	O
to	O

agreements	O
are	O
treated	O
as	O
a	O
liability	O
on	O
receipt	O
and	O
until	O
such	O
time	O
as	O
the	O
relevant	O
expenditure	O
is	O
incurred.	O

(	O
l	O
)	O
Joint	O
ventures	O
and	O
joint	O
operations	O
Joint	O
ventures	O
A	O
joint	O
venture	O
is	O
a	O
joint	O
arrangement	O
whereby	O
the	O
parties	O
that	O
have	O
joint	O
control	O
of	O
the	O
arrangement	O
have	O
rights	O
to	O
the	O
net	O
assets	O
of	O
the	O
arrangement.	O

Investments	O
in	O
joint	O
ventures	O
are	O
accounted	O
for	O
using	O
the	O
equity	O
method.	O

Under	O
the	O
equity	O
method	O
,	O
the	O
share	O
of	O
the	O
profits	O
or	O
losses	O
of	O
the	O
joint	O
venture	O
is	O
recognised	O
in	O
profit	O
or	O
loss	O
and	O
the	O
share	O
of	O
the	O
movements	O
in	O
equity	O
is	O
recognised	O
in	O
other	O
comprehensive	O
income.	O

Investments	O
in	O
joint	O
ventures	O
are	O
carried	O
in	O
the	O
statement	O
of	O
financial	O
position	O
at	O
cost	O
plus	O
post-acquisition	O
changes	O
in	O
the	O
Group's	O
share	O
of	O
net	O
assets	O
of	O
the	O
joint	O
venture.	O

Goodwill	O
relating	O
to	O
the	O
joint	O
venture	O
is	O
included	O
in	O
the	O
carrying	O
amount	O
of	O
the	O
investment	O
and	O
is	O
neither	O
amortised	O
nor	O
individually	O
tested	O
for	O
impairment.	O

Income	O
earned	O
from	O
joint	O
venture	O
entities	O
reduce	O
the	O
carrying	O
amount	O
of	O
the	O
investment.	O

Joint	O
operations	O
A	O
joint	O
operation	O
is	O
a	O
joint	O
arrangement	O
whereby	O
the	O
parties	O
that	O
have	O
joint	O
control	O
of	O
the	O
arrangement	O
have	O
rights	O
to	O
the	O
assets	O
,	O
and	O
obligations	O
for	O
the	O
liabilities	O
,	O
relating	O
to	O
the	O
arrangement.	O

The	O
Group	O
has	O
recognised	O
its	O
share	O
of	O
jointly	O
held	O
assets	O
,	O
liabilities	O
,	O
revenues	O
and	O
expenses	O
of	O
joint	O
operations.	O

These	O
have	O
been	O
incorporated	O
in	O
the	O
financial	O
statements	O
under	O
the	O
appropriate	O
classifications.	O

(	O
m	O
)	O
Trade	O
and	O
other	O
payables	O
These	O
amounts	O
represent	O
liabilities	O
for	O
goods	O
and	O
services	O
provided	O
to	O
the	O
Group	O
prior	O
to	O
the	O
end	O
of	O
the	O
financial	O
year	O
which	O
are	O
unpaid.	O

The	O
amounts	O
are	O
unsecured	O
and	O
usually	O
paid	O
within	O
30	O
days	O
of	O
recognition.	O

(	O
n	O
)	O
Employee	O
benefits	O
Wages	O
,	O
salaries	O
and	O
annual	O
leave	O
Liabilities	O
for	O
wages	O
and	O

,	O
including	O
non-monetary	O
benefits	O
,	O
and	O
annual	O

expected	O
to	O
be	O
settled	O
within	O
12	O
months	O
of	O
the	O
reporting	O
date	O
are	O
recognised	O
in	O
other	O
payables	O
in	O
respect	O
of	O
employees	O
’	O
services	O
up	O
to	O
the	O
reporting	O
date	O
and	O

at	O
the	O
amounts	O
expected	O
to	O

Riversgold	O

Statements	O
For	O
the	O

year	O
ended	O
30	O
June	O
2018	O
Note	O
1	O
Summary	O
of	O
significant	O
accounting	O
policies	O
(	O
continued	O
)	O
(	O
n	O
)	O
Employee	O
benefits	O
(	O
continued	O
)	O
Long	O
service	O
leave	O
The	O
liability	O
for	O
long	O
service	O
leave	O
is	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
provision	O
for	O
employee	O
benefits	O
and	O
measured	O
as	O
the	O
present	O
value	O
of	O
expected	O
future	O
payments	O
to	O
be	O
made	O
in	O
respect	O
of	O
services	O
provided	O
by	O
employees	O
up	O
to	O
the	O
reporting	O
date	O
using	O
the	O
projected	O
unit	O
credit	O
method.	O

Consideration	O
is	O
given	O
to	O
expected	O
future	O
salaries	O
,	O
experience	O
of	O
employee	O
departures	O
and	O
periods	O
of	O
service.	O

Expected	O
future	O
payments	O
are	O
discounted	O
at	O
the	O
corporate	O
bond	O
rate	O
with	O
terms	O
to	O
maturity	O
and	O
currency	O
that	O
match	O
,	O
as	O
closely	O
as	O
possible	O
,	O
the	O
estimated	O
future	O
cash	O
outflows.	O

Share-based	O
payments	O
Share-based	O
compensation	O
payments	O
are	O
made	O
available	O
to	O
Directors	O
and	O
employees.	O

The	O
fair	O
value	O
of	O
options	O
granted	O
is	O
recognised	O
as	O
an	O
employee	O
benefit	O
expense	O
with	O
a	O
corresponding	O
increase	O
in	O
equity.	O

The	O
fair	O
value	O
is	O
measured	O
at	O
grant	O
date	O
and	O
recognised	O
over	O
the	O
period	O
during	O
which	O
the	O
employees	O
become	O
unconditionally	O
entitled	O
to	O
the	O
options.	O

The	O
fair	O
value	O
at	O
grant	O
date	O
is	O
independently	O
determined	O
using	O
a	O
Black-Scholes	O
option	O
pricing	O
model	O
that	O
takes	O
into	O
account	O
the	O
exercise	O
price	O
,	O
the	O
term	O
of	O
the	O
option	O
,	O
the	O
impact	O
of	O
dilution	O
,	O
the	O
share	O
price	O
at	O
grant	O
date	O
and	O
expected	O
price	O
volatility	O
of	O
the	O
underlying	O
share	O
,	O
the	O
expected	O
dividend	O
yield	O
and	O
the	O
risk	O
free	O
rate	O
for	O
the	O
term	O
of	O
the	O
option.	O

A	O
discount	O
is	O
applied	O
,	O
where	O
appropriate	O
,	O
to	O
reflect	O
the	O
non-marketability	O
and	O
non-transferability	O
of	O
unlisted	O
options	O
,	O
as	O
the	O
Black-Scholes	O
option	O
pricing	O
model	O
does	O
not	O
incorporate	O
these	O
factors	O
into	O
its	O
valuation.	O

The	O
fair	O
value	O
of	O
the	O
options	O
granted	O
is	O
adjusted	O
to	O
reflect	O
market	O
vesting	O
conditions.	O

Non-market	O
vesting	O
conditions	O
are	O
included	O
in	O
assumptions	O
about	O
the	O
number	O
of	O
options	O
that	O
are	O
expected	O
to	O
become	O
exercisable.	O

At	O
each	O
balance	O
sheet	O
date	O
,	O
the	O
entity	O
revises	O
its	O
estimate	O
of	O
the	O
number	O
of	O
options	O
that	O
are	O
expected	O
to	O
become	O
exercisable.	O

The	O
employee	O
benefit	O
expense	O
recognised	O
each	O
period	O
takes	O
into	O
account	O
the	O
most	O
recent	O
estimate.	O

Upon	O
the	O
exercise	O
of	O
options	O
,	O
the	O
balance	O
of	O
the	O
share-based	O
payments	O
reserve	O
relating	O
to	O
those	O
options	O
is	O
transferred	O
to	O
share	O

to	O

other	O

of	O

(	O
q	O
)	O
Goods	O
and	O
services	O
tax	O
(	O
GST	O
)	O
Revenues	O
,	O
expenses	O
and	O
assets	O
are	O
recognised	O
net	O
of	O
the	O
amount	O
of	O
associated	O
GST	O
,	O
unless	O
the	O
GST	O
incurred	O
is	O
not	O
recoverable	O
from	O
the	O
taxation	O
authority.	O

In	O
this	O
case	O
it	O
is	O
recognised	O
as	O
part	O
of	O
the	O
cost	O
of	O
acquisition	O
of	O
the	O
asset	O
or	O
as	O
a	O
part	O
of	O
the	O
expense.	O

Receivables	O
and	O
payables	O
are	O
stated	O
inclusive	O
of	O
the	O
amount	O
of	O
GST	O
receivable	O
or	O
payable.	O

The	O
net	O
amount	O
of	O
GST	O
recoverable	O
from	O
,	O
or	O
payable	O
to	O
,	O
the	O
taxation	O
authority	O
is	O
included	O
with	O
other	O
receivables	O
or	O
payables	O
in	O
the	O
balance	O
sheet.	O

Cash	O
flows	O
are	O
presented	O
on	O
a	O
gross	O
basis.	O

The	O
GST	O
components	O
of	O
cash	O
flows	O
arising	O
from	O
investing	O
or	O
financing	O
activities	O
which	O
are	O
recoverable	O
from	O
,	O
or	O
payable	O
to	O
,	O
the	O
taxation	O
authority	O
,	O
are	O
presented	O
as	O
operating	O
cash	O
flow.	O

(	O
r	O
)	O

figures	O

in	O

(	O
s	O
)	O
Investments	O
and	O
other	O
financial	O
assets	O
Recognition	O
When	O
financial	O
assets	O
are	O
recognised	O
initially	O
,	O
they	O
are	O
measured	O
at	O
fair	O
value	O
,	O
plus	O
in	O
the	O
case	O
of	O
investments	O
not	O
at	O
fair	O
value	O
through	O
profit	O
or	O
loss	O
,	O
directly	O
attributable	O
transaction	O
costs.	O

The	O
Group	O
determines	O
the	O
classification	O
of	O
its	O
financial	O
assets	O
after	O
initial	O
recognition	O
and	O
,	O
when	O
allowed	O
and	O
appropriate	O
,	O
re-evaluates	O
this	O
designation	O
at	O
each	O
financial	O
year-end.	O

All	O
regular	O
way	O
purchases	O
and	O
sales	O
of	O
financial	O
assets	O
are	O
recognised	O
on	O
the	O
trade	O
date	O
,	O
i.e.	O

the	O
date	O
that	O
the	O
Group	O
commits	O
to	O
purchase	O
the	O
asset.	O

Regular	O
way	O
purchases	O
or	O
sales	O
are	O
purchases	O
or	O
sales	O
of	O
financial	O
assets	O
under	O
contracts	O
that	O
require	O
delivery	O
of	O
the	O
assets	O
within	O
the	O
period	O
established	O
generally	O
by	O
regulation	O
or	O
convention	O
in	O
the	O
marketplace.	O

(	O
i	O
)	O
Financial	O
assets	O
at	O
fair	O
value	O
through	O
profit	O
or	O
loss	O
A	O
financial	O
asset	O
designated	O
on	O
initial	O
recognition	O
as	O
one	O
to	O
be	O
measured	O
at	O
fair	O
value	O
with	O
fair	O
value	O
changes	O
in	O
profit	O
and	O
loss	O
is	O
included	O
in	O
the	O
category	O
‘	O
financial	O
assets	O
at	O
fair	O
value	O
through	O
profit	O
or	O
loss	O
’	O
.	O

Financial	O
assets	O
are	O
classified	O
as	O
held	O
for	O
trading	O
if	O
they	O
are	O
acquired	O
for	O
the	O
purpose	O
of	O
selling	O
in	O
the	O
near	O
term.	O

Derivatives	O
are	O
also	O
classified	O
as	O
held	O
for	O
trading	O
unless	O
they	O
are	O
designated	O
as	O
effective	O
hedging	O
instruments.	O

Gains	O
or	O
losses	O
on	O
investments	O
held	O
for	O
trading	O
are	O
recognised	O
in	O
profit	O
or	O
loss.	O

1	O
Summary	O
of	O
significant	O

policies	O
(	O
continued	O
)	O
(	O
s	O
)	O
Investments	O
and	O
other	O
financial	O
assets	O
(	O
continued	O
)	O
(	O
ii	O
)	O
Held-to-maturity	O
investments	O
Non-derivative	O
financial	O
assets	O
with	O
fixed	O
or	O
determinable	O
payments	O
and	O
fixed	O
maturity	O
are	O
classified	O
as	O
held-to-maturity	O
when	O
the	O
Group	O
has	O
the	O
positive	O
intention	O
and	O
ability	O
to	O
hold	O
to	O
maturity.	O

Investments	O
included	O
to	O
be	O
held	O
for	O
an	O
undefined	O
period	O
are	O
not	O
included	O
in	O
this	O
classification.	O

Investments	O
that	O
are	O
intended	O
to	O
be	O
held-to-maturity	O
,	O
such	O
as	O
bonds	O
,	O
are	O
subsequently	O
measured	O
at	O
amortised	O
cost.	O

This	O
cost	O
is	O
computed	O
as	O
the	O
amount	O
initially	O
recognised	O
minus	O
principal	O
repayments	O
,	O
plus	O
or	O
minus	O
the	O
cumulative	O
amortisation	O
using	O
the	O
effective	O
interest	O
method	O
of	O
any	O
difference	O
between	O
the	O
initially	O
recognised	O
amount	O
and	O
the	O
maturity	O
amount.	O

This	O
calculation	O
includes	O
all	O
fees	O
and	O
points	O
paid	O
or	O
received	O
between	O
parties	O
to	O
the	O
contract	O
that	O
are	O
an	O
integral	O
part	O
of	O
the	O
effective	O
interest	O
rate	O
,	O
transaction	O
costs	O
and	O
all	O
other	O
premiums	O
and	O
discounts.	O

For	O
investments	O
carried	O
at	O
amortised	O
cost	O
,	O
gains	O
and	O
losses	O
are	O
recognised	O
in	O
profit	O
or	O
loss	O
when	O
the	O
investments	O
are	O
derecognised	O
or	O
impaired	O
,	O
as	O
well	O
as	O
through	O
the	O
amortisation	O
process.	O

(	O
iii	O
)	O
Loans	O
and	O
receivables	O
Loans	O
and	O
receivables	O
are	O
non-derivative	O
financial	O
assets	O
with	O
fixed	O
or	O
determinable	O
payments	O
that	O
are	O
not	O
quoted	O
in	O
an	O
active	O
market	O
and	O
are	O
stated	O
at	O
amortised	O
cost	O
using	O
the	O
effective	O
interest	O
rate	O
method.	O

(	O
iv	O
)	O
Financial	O
liabilities	O
Non-derivative	O
financial	O
liabilities	O
are	O
recognised	O
at	O
amortised	O
cost	O
,	O
comprising	O
original	O
debt	O
less	O
principal	O
payments	O
and	O
amortisation.	O

(	O
t	O
)	O
Fair	O
value	O
estimation	O
A	O
number	O
of	O
the	O
Group	O
’	O
s	O
accounting	O
policies	O
and	O
disclosures	O
require	O
the	O
determination	O
of	O
fair	O
value	O
,	O
for	O
both	O
financial	O
and	O
non-financial	O
assets	O
and	O
liabilities.	O

Fair	O
values	O
have	O
been	O
determined	O
for	O
measurement	O
and/or	O
disclosure	O
purposes	O
based	O
on	O
the	O
following	O
methods	O
:	O
Investments	O
in	O
equity	O
and	O
debt	O
securities	O
The	O
fair	O
value	O
of	O
financial	O
assets	O
at	O
fair	O
value	O
through	O
profit	O
or	O
loss	O
,	O
held	O
to	O
maturity	O
investments	O
and	O
available	O
for	O
sale	O
financial	O
assets	O
is	O
determined	O
by	O
reference	O
to	O
their	O
quoted	O
bid	O
price	O
at	O
the	O
reporting	O
date.	O

The	O
fair	O
value	O
of	O
held	O
to	O
maturity	O
investments	O
is	O
determined	O
for	O
disclosure	O
purposes	O
only.	O

For	O
investments	O
with	O
no	O
active	O
market	O
,	O
fair	O
value	O
is	O
determined	O
using	O
valuation	O
techniques.	O

Such	O
techniques	O
include	O
using	O
recent	O
arm	O
’	O
s	O
length	O
market	O
transactions	O
,	O
reference	O
to	O
the	O
current	O
market	O
value	O
of	O
another	O
instrument	O
that	O
is	O
substantially	O
the	O
same	O
,	O
discounted	O
cash	O
flow	O
analysis	O
and	O
option	O
pricing	O
models.	O

42	O
Riversgold	O
Limited	O
ABN	O
64	O
617	O
614	O
598	O
Notes	O
to	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Financial	O
Statements	O
For	O
the	O
financial	O
year	O
ended	O
30	O
June	O
2018	O
Note	O
1	O
Summary	O
of	O
significant	O
accounting	O
policies	O
(	O
continued	O
)	O
(	O
t	O
)	O
Fair	O
value	O
estimation	O
(	O
Continued	O
)	O
Trade	O
and	O
other	O
receivables	O
The	O
fair	O
value	O
of	O
trade	O
and	O
other	O
receivables	O
is	O
estimated	O
as	O
the	O
present	O
value	O
of	O
future	O
cash	O
flows	O
,	O
discounted	O
at	O
the	O
market	O
rate	O
of	O
interest	O
at	O
the	O
reporting	O
date.	O

Fair	O
value	O
measurement	O
When	O
an	O
asset	O
or	O
liability	O
,	O
financial	O
or	O
non-financial	O
,	O
is	O
measured	O
at	O
fair	O
value	O
for	O
recognition	O
or	O
disclosure	O
purposes	O
,	O
the	O
fair	O
value	O
is	O
based	O
on	O
the	O
price	O
that	O
would	O
be	O
received	O
to	O
sell	O
an	O
asset	O
or	O
paid	O
to	O
transfer	O
a	O
liability	O
in	O
an	O
orderly	O
transaction	O
between	O
market	O
participants	O
at	O
the	O
measurement	O
date	O
;	O
and	O
assumes	O
that	O
the	O
transaction	O
will	O
take	O
place	O
either	O
:	O
in	O
the	O
principal	O
market	O
;	O
or	O
in	O
the	O
absence	O
of	O
a	O
principal	O
market	O
,	O
in	O
the	O
most	O
advantageous	O
market.	O

Fair	O
value	O
is	O
measured	O
using	O
the	O
assumptions	O
that	O
market	O
participants	O
would	O
use	O
when	O
pricing	O
the	O
asset	O
or	O
liability	O
,	O
assuming	O
they	O
act	O
in	O
their	O
economic	O
best	O
interests.	O

For	O
non-financial	O
assets	O
,	O
the	O
fair	O
value	O
measurement	O
is	O
based	O
on	O
its	O
highest	O
and	O
best	O
use.	O

Valuation	O
techniques	O
that	O
are	O
appropriate	O
in	O
the	O
circumstances	O
and	O
for	O
which	O
sufficient	O
data	O
are	O
available	O
to	O
measure	O
fair	O
value	O
,	O
are	O
used	O
,	O
maximising	O
the	O
use	O
of	O
relevant	O
observable	O
inputs	O
and	O
minimising	O
the	O
use	O
of	O
unobservable	O
inputs.	O

Assets	O
and	O
liabilities	O
measured	O
at	O
fair	O
value	O
are	O
classified	O
,	O
into	O
three	O
levels	O
,	O
using	O
a	O
fair	O
value	O
hierarchy	O
that	O
reflects	O
the	O
significance	O
of	O
the	O
inputs	O
used	O
in	O
making	O
the	O
measurements.	O

Classifications	O
are	O
reviewed	O
at	O
each	O
reporting	O
date	O
and	O
transfers	O
between	O
levels	O
are	O
determined	O
based	O
on	O
a	O
reassessment	O
of	O
the	O
lowest	O
level	O
of	O
input	O
that	O
is	O
significant	O
to	O
the	O
fair	O
value	O
measurement.	O

For	O
recurring	O
and	O
non-recurring	O
fair	O
value	O
measurements	O
,	O
external	O
valuers	O
may	O
be	O
used	O
when	O
internal	O
expertise	O
is	O
either	O
not	O
available	O
or	O
when	O
the	O
valuation	O
is	O
deemed	O
to	O
be	O
significant.	O

External	O
valuers	O
are	O
selected	O
based	O
on	O
market	O
knowledge	O
and	O
reputation.	O

Where	O
there	O
is	O
a	O
significant	O
change	O
in	O
fair	O
value	O
of	O
an	O
asset	O
or	O
liability	O
from	O
one	O
period	O
to	O
another	O
,	O
an	O
analysis	O
is	O
undertaken	O
,	O
which	O
includes	O
a	O
verification	O
of	O
the	O
major	O
inputs	O
applied	O
in	O
the	O
latest	O
valuation	O
and	O
a	O
comparison	O
,	O
where	O
applicable	O
,	O
with	O
external	O
sources	O
of	O
data.	O

Note	O
2	O
Financial	O
risk	O
management	O
The	O
Group	O
has	O
exposure	O
to	O
a	O
variety	O
of	O
risks	O
arising	O
from	O
its	O
use	O
of	O
financial	O
instruments.	O

This	O
note	O
presents	O
information	O
about	O
the	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
exposure	O
to	O
the	O
specific	O
risks	O
,	O
and	O
the	O
policies	O
and	O
processes	O
for	O
measuring	O
and	O
managing	O
those	O
risks.	O

The	O
Board	O
of	O
Directors	O
has	O
the	O
overall	O
responsibility	O
for	O
the	O
risk	O
management	O
framework	O
and	O
has	O
adopted	O
a	O
Risk	O
Management	O
Policy.	O

(	O
a	O
)	O
Credit	O
risk	O
Credit	O
risk	O
is	O
the	O
risk	O
of	O
financial	O
loss	O
to	O
the	O
Group	O
if	O
a	O
customer	O
or	O
counterparty	O
to	O
a	O
financial	O
instrument	O
fails	O
to	O
meet	O
its	O
contractual	O
obligations	O
,	O
and	O
arises	O
principally	O
from	O
transactions	O
with	O
customers	O
and	O
investments.	O

Trade	O
and	O
other	O
receivables	O
The	O
nature	O
of	O
the	O
business	O
activity	O
of	O
the	O
Group	O
does	O
not	O
result	O
in	O
trading	O
receivables.	O

The	O
receivables	O
that	O
the	O
Group	O
does	O
experience	O
through	O
its	O
normal	O
course	O
of	O
business	O
are	O
short	O
term	O
and	O
the	O
most	O
significant	O
recurring	O
by	O
quantity	O
is	O
receivable	O
from	O
the	O
Australian	O
Taxation	O
Office	O
,	O
the	O
risk	O
of	O
non-	O
recovery	O
of	O
receivables	O
from	O
this	O
source	O
is	O
considered	O
to	O
be	O
negligible.	O

Cash	O
deposits	O
The	O
Directors	O
believe	O
any	O
risk	O
associated	O
with	O
the	O
use	O
of	O
predominantly	O
only	O
one	O
bank	O
is	O
addressed	O
through	O
the	O
use	O
of	O
at	O
least	O
an	O
A-rated	O
bank	O
as	O
a	O
primary	O
banker	O
and	O
by	O
the	O
holding	O
of	O
a	O
portion	O
of	O
funds	O
on	O
deposit	O
with	O
alternative	O
A-rated	O
institutions.	O

Except	O
for	O
this	O
matter	O
the	O
Group	O
currently	O
has	O
no	O
significant	O
concentrations	O
of	O
credit	O
risk.	O

Note	O
2	O
Financial	O
risk	O
management	O
(	O
Continued	O
)	O
(	O
b	O
)	O
Liquidity	O
risk	O
Liquidity	O
risk	O
is	O
the	O
risk	O
that	O
the	O
Group	O
will	O
not	O
be	O
able	O
to	O
meet	O
its	O
financial	O
obligations	O
as	O
they	O
fall	O
due.	O

The	O
Group	O
’	O
s	O
approach	O
to	O
managing	O
liquidity	O
is	O
to	O
ensure	O
,	O
as	O
far	O
as	O
possible	O
,	O
that	O
it	O
will	O
always	O
have	O
sufficient	O
liquidity	O
to	O
meet	O
its	O
liabilities	O
when	O
due	O
,	O
under	O
both	O
normal	O
and	O
stressed	O
conditions	O
,	O
without	O
incurring	O
unacceptable	O
losses	O
or	O
risking	O
damage	O
to	O
the	O
Group	O
’	O
s	O
reputation.	O

The	O
Group	O
manages	O
its	O
liquidity	O
risk	O
by	O
monitoring	O
its	O
cash	O
reserves	O
and	O
forecast	O
spending.	O

Management	O
is	O
cognisant	O
of	O
the	O
future	O
demands	O
for	O
liquid	O
finance	O
resources	O
to	O
finance	O
the	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
current	O
and	O
future	O
operations	O
,	O
and	O
consideration	O
is	O
given	O
to	O
the	O
liquid	O
assets	O
available	O
to	O
the	O
Company	O
before	O
commitment	O
is	O
made	O
to	O
future	O
expenditure	O
or	O
investment.	O

(	O
c	O
)	O
Market	O
risk	O
Market	O
risk	O
is	O
the	O
risk	O
that	O
changes	O
in	O
market	O
prices	O
,	O
such	O
as	O
foreign	O
exchange	O
rates	O
,	O
interest	O
rates	O
and	O
equity	O
prices	O
will	O
affect	O
the	O
Group	O
’	O
s	O
income	O
or	O
the	O
value	O
of	O
its	O
holdings	O
of	O
financial	O
instruments.	O

The	O
objective	O
of	O
market	O
risk	O
management	O
is	O
to	O
manage	O
and	O
control	O
market	O
risk	O
exposures	O
within	O
acceptable	O
parameters	O
,	O
while	O
optimising	O
any	O
return.	O

Interest	O
rate	O
risk	O
The	O
Group	O
has	O
significant	O
cash	O
assets	O
which	O
may	O
be	O
susceptible	O
to	O
fluctuations	O
in	O
changes	O
in	O
interest	O
rates.	O

Whilst	O
the	O
Group	O
requires	O
the	O
cash	O
assets	O
to	O
be	O
sufficiently	O
liquid	O
to	O
cover	O
any	O
planned	O
or	O
unforeseen	O
future	O
expenditure	O
,	O
which	O
prevents	O
the	O
cash	O
assets	O
being	O
committed	O
to	O
long	O
term	O
fixed	O
interest	O
arrangements	O
;	O
the	O
Group	O
does	O
mitigate	O
potential	O
interest	O
rate	O
risk	O
by	O
entering	O
into	O
short	O
to	O
medium	O
term	O
fixed	O
interest	O
investments.	O

Equity	O
risk	O
The	O
Group	O
has	O
no	O
direct	O
exposure	O
to	O
equity	O
price	O
risk.	O

Foreign	O
exchange	O
risk	O
The	O
Group	O
undertakes	O
operations	O
outside	O
of	O
Australia	O
that	O
are	O
denominated	O
in	O
currencies	O
other	O
than	O
Australian	O
Dollars.	O

The	O
Group	O
may	O
,	O
in	O
respect	O
of	O
these	O
operations	O
,	O
be	O
exposed	O
to	O
fluctuations	O
in	O
foreign	O
exchange	O
rates	O
which	O
will	O
have	O
direct	O
impact	O
on	O
the	O
Group	O
’	O
s	O
net	O
assets.	O

Movements	O
in	O
foreign	O
exchange	O
may	O
favourably	O
or	O
adversely	O
affect	O
future	O
amounts	O
to	O
be	O
incurred	O
by	O
the	O
Group.	O

Other	O
than	O
the	O
above	O
,	O
the	O
Group	O
does	O
not	O
have	O
any	O
direct	O
contact	O
with	O
foreign	O
exchange	O
fluctuations	O
other	O
than	O
their	O
effect	O
on	O
the	O
general	O
economy.	O

Note	O
3	O
Critical	O
accounting	O
estimates	O
and	O
judgements	O
Estimates	O
and	O
judgements	O
are	O
continually	O
evaluated	O
and	O
are	O
based	O
on	O
historical	O
experience	O
and	O
other	O
factors	O
,	O
including	O
expectations	O
of	O
future	O
events	O
that	O
may	O
have	O
a	O
financial	O
impact	O
on	O
the	O
Group	O
and	O
that	O
are	O
believed	O
to	O
be	O
reasonable	O
under	O
the	O
circumstances.	O

Accounting	O
for	O
capitalised	O
exploration	O
and	O
evaluation	O
expenditure	O
The	O
application	O
of	O
the	O
Group	O
’	O
s	O
accounting	O
policy	O
for	O
exploration	O
and	O
evaluation	O
expenditure	O
(	O
see	O
note	O
1	O
(	O
k	O
)	O
)	O
requires	O
judgment	O
in	O
determining	O
whether	O
it	O
is	O
likely	O
that	O
future	O
economic	O
benefits	O
are	O
likely	O
either	O
from	O
future	O
exploitation	O
or	O
sale	O
or	O
where	O
activities	O
have	O
not	O
reached	O
a	O
stage	O
which	O
permits	O
a	O
reasonable	O
assessment	O
of	O
the	O
existence	O
of	O
reserves.	O

The	O
deferral	O
policy	O
requires	O
management	O
to	O
make	O
certain	O
estimates	O
and	O
assumptions	O
about	O
future	O
events	O
or	O
circumstances	O
,	O
in	O
particular	O
whether	O
an	O
economically	O
viable	O
extraction	O
operation	O
can	O
be	O
established.	O

Estimates	O
and	O
assumptions	O
made	O
may	O
change	O
if	O
new	O
information	O
becomes	O
available.	O

estimates	O
and	O
judgements	O
(	O
continued	O
)	O
Accounting	O
for	O
share-based	O
payments	O
The	O
values	O
of	O
amounts	O
recognised	O
in	O
respect	O
of	O
share-based	O
payments	O
have	O
been	O
estimated	O
based	O
on	O
the	O
fair	O
value	O
of	O
the	O
equity	O
instruments	O
granted.	O

Fair	O
values	O
of	O
options	O
issued	O
are	O
estimated	O
by	O
using	O
an	O
appropriate	O
option	O
pricing	O
model.	O

There	O
are	O
many	O
variables	O
and	O
assumptions	O
used	O
as	O
inputs	O
into	O
the	O
models.	O

If	O
any	O
of	O
these	O
assumptions	O
or	O
estimates	O
were	O
to	O
change	O
this	O
could	O
have	O
a	O
significant	O
effect	O
on	O
the	O
amounts	O
recognised.	O

See	O
note	O
17	O
for	O
details	O
of	O
inputs	O
into	O
option	O
pricing	O
models	O
in	O
respect	O
of	O
options	O
issued	O
during	O
the	O
reporting	O
period.	O

Note	O
4	O
Segment	O
information	O
The	O
Group	O
has	O
identified	O
its	O
operating	O
segments	O
based	O
on	O
the	O
internal	O
reports	O
that	O
are	O
reviewed	O
and	O
used	O
by	O
the	O
board	O
of	O
directors	O
in	O
assessing	O
performance	O
and	O
determining	O
the	O
allocation	O
of	O
resources.	O

Reportable	O
segments	O
disclosed	O
are	O
based	O
on	O
aggregating	O
operating	O
segments	O
,	O
where	O
the	O
segments	O
have	O
similar	O
characteristics.	O

as	O

a	O
)	O
Joint	O
Venture	O
Agreements	O
–	O

Joint	O
Operations	O
Joint	O
venture	O
agreements	O
may	O
be	O
entered	O
into	O
with	O
third	O
parties.	O

Assets	O
employed	O
by	O
these	O
joint	O
ventures	O
and	O
the	O
Group	O
’	O
s	O
expenditure	O
in	O
respect	O
of	O
them	O
is	O
brought	O
to	O
account	O
initially	O
as	O
capitalised	O
exploration	O
and	O
evaluation	O
expenditure	O
until	O
a	O
formal	O
joint	O
venture	O
agreement	O
is	O
entered	O
into.	O

Thereafter	O
,	O
investment	O
in	O
joint	O
ventures	O
is	O
recorded	O
distinctly	O
from	O

exploration	O

on	O
the	O
company	O
’	O
s	O
100%	O
owned	O
projects.	O

)	O

Alloy	O
Joint	O
Venture	O
–	O

Earning	O
In	O
The	O
Company	O
has	O
entered	O
into	O
an	O
agreement	O
with	O
Alloy	O
Resources	O
Limited	O
(	O
“	O
Alloy	O
”	O
)	O
whereby	O

Company	O

up	O
to	O
an	O
85%	O
interest	O
in	O

its	O

and	O
Acra	O
South	O
targets	O
in	O
Western	O
Australia.	O

Significant	O
terms	O
of	O
the	O
farm-in	O
arrangement	O
as	O
follows	O
:	O
•	O

The	O
Company	O
will	O
pay	O
Alloy	O
$30	O
,	O
000	O
cash	O
as	O

for	O
previous	O

on	O
the	O
tenements.	O

•	O

The	O
Company	O
must	O
meet	O
the	O
minimum	O
statutory	O
expenditure	O
of	O
$114	O
,	O
000	O
for	O
the	O
first	O
year	O
before	O
withdrawing	O
from	O
the	O
agreement.	O

•	O

The	O
Company	O
can	O
earn	O
an	O
initial	O
70%	O
interest	O
in	O
the	O
tenements	O
by	O
meeting	O
statutory	O
minimum	O
expenditure	O
requirements	O
$114	O
,	O
000pa	O
for	O
3	O
years	O
,	O
including	O
the	O
first	O
year.	O

•	O

Upon	O
the	O
Company	O

70%	O
,	O
Alloy	O
can	O
elect	O
to	O
contribute	O
pro-rata	O
to	O
further	O
exploration	O
or	O
revert	O
to	O
a	O
15%	O
free-carried	O
interest	O
to	O
completion	O
of	O
a	O
Definitive	O
Feasibility	O
Study	O
(	O
“	O
DFS	O
”	O
)	O
,	O
whereby	O
the	O
Company	O
will	O
have	O
earned	O
an	O
85%	O
interest	O
in	O
the	O
tenements.	O

•	O

Upon	O
completion	O
of	O
the	O
DFS	O
,	O
Alloy	O
will	O
have	O
an	O

)	O
Ordinary	O
shares	O
The	O
Company	O
is	O
a	O
public	O
company	O
limited	O
by	O
shares.	O

The	O
Company	O
was	O
incorporated	O
in	O
Perth	O
,	O
Western	O
Australia.	O

The	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
shares	O
are	O
limited	O
whereby	O
the	O
liability	O
of	O
its	O
members	O
is	O
limited	O
to	O
the	O
amount	O
(	O
if	O
any	O
)	O
unpaid	O
on	O
the	O
shares	O
respectively	O
held	O
by	O
them.	O

Ordinary	O
shares	O
entitle	O
the	O
holder	O
to	O
participate	O
in	O
dividends	O
and	O
the	O
proceeds	O
on	O
winding	O
up	O
of	O
the	O
Company	O
in	O
proportion	O
to	O
the	O
number	O
of	O
and	O
amounts	O
paid	O
on	O
the	O
shares	O
held.	O

On	O
a	O
show	O
of	O
hands	O
every	O
holder	O
of	O
ordinary	O
shares	O
present	O
at	O
a	O
meeting	O
in	O
person	O
or	O
by	O
proxy	O
,	O
is	O
entitled	O
to	O
one	O
vote	O
,	O
and	O
upon	O
a	O
poll	O
each	O
share	O
is	O
entitled	O
to	O
one	O
vote.	O

Ordinary	O
shares	O
have	O
no	O
par	O
value.	O

There	O
is	O
no	O
limit	O
to	O
the	O
authorised	O
share	O
capital	O
of	O
the	O
Company.	O

,	O

rights	O
in	O

of	O

of	O

whereby	O

vote	O
and	O
upon	O
a	O

share	O
will	O
have	O
one	O
vote.	O

6	O
About	O
Vango	O
Mining	O
Vango	O
Mining	O
Limited	O
(	O
ASX	O
:	O
VAN	O

is	O
a	O
minerals	O
exploration	O
mining	O
company	O
with	O
ambitions	O
of	O
becoming	O
a	O
high-grade	O
y	O
WA	O
gold	O
miner	O
by	O
developing	O
the	O
100%	O
owned	O
Marymia	O
Gold	O
Project	O
(	O
Marymia	O
)	O
in	O
the	O
mid-west	O
region	O
of	O
Western	O
Australia.	O

The	O
Project	O
comprises	O
45	O
granted	O
mining	O
leases	O
over	O
300km.	O

It	O
has	O
an	O
established	O
high-grade	O
resource	O
of	O
l	O
1Moz	O
@	O
3g/t	O
Au^	O
,	O
underpinned	O
by	O
the	O
Trident	O
Deposit	O
,	O
whose	O
resource	O
is	O
410koz	O
@	O
8g/t	O
Au	O
,	O
with	O
immediate	O
n	O
extensions	O
open	O
at	O
depth/along	O
strike.	O

The	O
Marymia	O
Project	O
has	O
the	O
potential	O
to	O
become	O
one	O
of	O
Australia's	O
largest	O
high-grade	O
producers.	O

The	O
Greenstone	O
o	O

Belt	O
in	O
the	O
Marymia	O
region	O
includes	O
six	O
major	O
gold	O
corridors	O
,	O
which	O
remain	O
largely	O
un-tested	O
beyond	O
100m	O
depth	O
-	O

supported	O
with	O
an	O
extensive	O
drilling	O
and	O
geophysical	O
database.	O

Previous	O
mining	O
between	O
1992-2001	O
,	O
produced	O
580	O
,	O
000	O
ounces	O
of	O
gold	O
almost	O
entirely	O
from	O
open	O
pits.	O

Vango	O
is	O
focused	O
on	O
growing	O
its	O
high-grade	O
gold	O
resource	O
to	O
support	O
a	O
proposed	O
stand-alone	O
gold	O
mining	O

e	O
production	O

at	O

ABOUT	O
MEEKA	O
GOLD	O
LIMITED	O
Meeka	O
Gold	O
(	O
ASX	O
:	O
MEK	O
)	O
is	O
a	O
junior	O
gold	O
and	O
rare	O
earths	O
explorer	O
with	O
a	O
portfolio	O
of	O
exploration	O
projects	O
across	O
Western	O
Australia.	O

Meeka	O
’	O
s	O
flagship	O
Murchison	O
Gold	O
Project	O
has	O
a	O
combined	O
343km	O
²	O

landholding	O
in	O
the	O
prolific	O
Murchison	O
Gold	O
Fields	O
of	O
Western	O
Australia	O
and	O
hosts	O
a	O
large	O
high	O
grade	O
1.1Moz	O
Mineral	O
Resource.	O

The	O
Company	O
is	O
actively	O
exploring	O
on	O
this	O
tenure	O
while	O
also	O
progressing	O
toward	O
production	O
with	O
the	O
release	O
of	O
the	O
Murchison	O
Gold	O
Project	O
Scoping	O
Study	O
in	O
December	O
2021	O
outlining	O
a	O
robust	O
Project	O
that	O
produces	O
over	O
420koz	O
of	O
gold	O
and	O
delivers	O
significant	O
free	O
cashflow.	O

to	O
the	O
Murchison	O
Gold	O
Project	O
,	O
the	O
Company	O
owns	O
the	O

in	O
southern	O
WA.	O

sits	O
in	O
the	O

Mobile	O
Belt	O
,	O
which	O
hosts	O
the	O
Tropicana	O
gold	O
mine	O

past	O
production	O
)	O
.	O

mineralisation	O
has	O
been	O
identified	O
in	O
four	O

of	O

“	O
The	O
Zemplin	O
prospect	O
is	O
an	O
underexplored	O
,	O
high-grade	O
,	O
silver	O
rich	O
epithermal	O
vein	O
system	O
which	O
,	O
unusually	O
for	O
the	O
Western	O
Tethyan	O
mineral	O
belt	O
,	O
is	O
mostly	O
covered	O
by	O
a	O
thin	O
layer	O
of	O
younger	O
rocks	O
or	O
sediments.	O

The	O
drone	O
magnetics	O
,	O
very	O
detailed	O
LIDAR	O
survey	O
have	O
helped	O
generate	O
decision	O
points	O
for	O
the	O
drill	O
program.	O

including	O
a	O
limited	O
metallurgical	O
testing	O
program	O
will	O
be	O
reviewed	O
in	O
the	O
current	O
quarter.	O

west	O
,	O
on	O
the	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
flagship	O
Hodrusa	O
exploration	O
licence	O
,	O
drilling	O
is	O

on	O
the	O

gold-silver	O

mine.	O

on	O
base	O

at	O
Hodrusa	O

gold	O
and	O
silver	O
shoots	O
remaining	O
at	O
depth.	O

A.B.N.	O

FINANCIAL	O

27	O
Directors'	O
Declaration	O
52	O

Auditor's	O
Report	O
53	O
Additional	O
ASX	O
Information	O
58	O
Corporate	O
Directory	O
60	O
PROSPECH	O
LIMITED	O
and	O
its	O
controlled	O
entities	O
REVIEW	O
OF	O
OPERATIONS	O
Dear	O
Fellow	O
Shareholders	O
,	O
During	O
the	O
past	O
year	O
your	O
Directors	O
have	O
been	O
busy	O
understanding	O
the	O
many	O
drill	O
targets	O
in	O
the	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
portfolio.	O

To	O
this	O
endeavour	O
we	O
instigated	O
an	O
IP	O
survey	O
over	O
a	O
portion	O
of	O
the	O
Hodrusa-Hamre	O
exploration	O
licence	O
–	O

the	O
first	O
modern	O
,	O
large	O
scale	O
geophysical	O
survey	O
ever	O
carried	O
out	O
over	O
the	O
Stiavnica	O
caldera	O
,	O
the	O
biggest	O
mineralised	O
centre	O
of	O
central	O
Slovakia	O
and	O
,	O
with	O
the	O
exception	O
of	O
an	O
operating	O
mine	O
within	O
our	O
tenement	O
,	O
entirely	O
held	O
by	O
Prospech.	O

The	O
IP	O
survey	O
resulted	O
in	O
the	O
delineation	O
of	O
several	O
anomalies	O
supportive	O
of	O
the	O
detachment	O
fault	O
(	O
LANF	O
)	O
concept	O
,	O
providing	O
a	O
fresh	O
perspective	O
and	O
new	O
tool	O
to	O
facilitate	O
the	O
discovery	O
of	O
gold	O
and	O
silver	O
deposits	O
within	O
the	O
Hodrusa-Hamre	O
licence	O
area.	O

A	O
drill	O
program	O
has	O
already	O
been	O
designed	O
and	O
permitted	O
to	O
test	O
these	O
anomalies	O
during	O
the	O
2022	O
field	O
and	O
drilling	O
season.	O

Further	O
,	O
an	O
airborne	O
drone	O
magnetic	O
survey	O
has	O
been	O
carried	O
out	O
over	O
the	O
Zemplin	O
prospect	O
within	O
the	O
Cejkov-Zemplin	O
tenement	O
and	O
is	O
currently	O
being	O
drill	O
tested.	O

Assay	O
results	O
will	O
follow	O
with	O
interest.	O

Despite	O
the	O
COVID-19	O
interrupted	O
past	O
year	O
,	O
the	O
outlook	O
is	O
interesting	O
with	O
ongoing	O
drilling	O
on	O
our	O
tenements.	O

To	O
this	O
end	O
,	O
our	O
geologic	O
crew	O
have	O
over	O
sixty	O
drill	O
sites	O
permitted	O
and	O
scheduled	O
to	O
be	O
drilled	O
during	O
the	O
current	O
northern	O
hemisphere	O
summer.	O

,	O

would	O
like	O
to	O
thank	O

Hodrusa-Hamre	O
Exploration	O
Licence	O
Located	O
200	O

east	O
of	O
Vienna	O
,	O

100%	O
owned	O
Hodrusa-Hamre	O
exploration	O
licence	O
is	O
approximately	O
102	O
km2	O
in	O
area	O
and	O
covers	O
the	O
majority	O
of	O
the	O
Neogene	O
Stiavnica	O
Stratovolcano	O
caldera	O
within	O
the	O
Central	O
Slovakian	O
Volcanic	O
Belt	O
and	O
includes	O
the	O
historic	O
Hodrusa-Hamre/Banska	O
Stiavnica	O
mining	O
district.	O

The	O
exploration	O
licence	O
encompasses	O
some	O
120	O
gold-silver-bearing	O
epithermal	O
veins	O
with	O
the	O
major	O
veins	O
individually	O
reaching	O
a	O
length	O
of	O
up	O
to	O
6	O
kilometres.	O

Drilling	O
During	O
the	O
year	O
,	O
Company	O
drilled	O
the	O
Anton	O
prospect	O
,	O
where	O
past	O
records	O
report	O
mining	O
to	O
a	O
depth	O
of	O
over	O
500	O
metres	O
below	O
surface.	O

This	O
has	O
been	O
the	O
first	O
modern	O
exploration	O
drilling	O
for	O
the	O
extensive	O
Anton	O
target.	O

Drill	O
targets	O
selected	O
by	O
the	O
Company	O
were	O
generally	O
shallower	O
targets	O
where	O
historical	O
records	O
indicated	O
that	O
effective	O
mining	O
was	O
prevented	O
by	O
water	O
ingress	O
due	O
to	O
the	O
poor	O
capability	O
of	O
primitive	O
pumps	O
of	O
the	O
era.	O
