(	O
r	O
)	O
Impairment	O
of	O
non-financial	O
assets	O
At	O
each	O
reporting	O
date	O
,	O
the	O
Company	O
reviews	O
the	O
carrying	O
values	O
of	O
its	O
assets	O
to	O
determine	O
whether	O
there	O
is	O
any	O
indication	O
that	O
those	O
assets	O
have	O
been	O
impaired.	O

If	O
such	O
an	O
indication	O
exists	O
,	O
the	O
recoverable	O
amount	O
of	O
the	O
asset	O
,	O
being	O
the	O
higher	O
of	O
the	O
asset	O
’	O
s	O
fair	O
value	O
less	O
costs	O
to	O
sell	O
and	O
value	O
in	O
use	O
,	O
is	O
compared	O
to	O
the	O
asset	O
’	O
s	O
carrying	O
value.	O

When	O
the	O
carrying	O
amount	O
of	O
an	O
asset	O
exceeds	O
its	O
carrying	O
amount	O
,	O
the	O
asset	O
is	O
considered	O
impaired	O
and	O
written	O
down	O
to	O
its	O
recoverable	O
amount.	O

Where	O
it	O
is	O
not	O
possible	O
to	O
estimate	O
the	O
recoverable	O
amount	O
of	O
an	O
individual	O
asset	O
,	O
the	O
Group	O
estimates	O
the	O
recoverable	O
amount	O
of	O
the	O
cash-generating	O
unit	O
to	O
which	O
the	O
asset	O
belongs.	O

In	O
assessing	O
value	O
in	O
use	O
,	O
the	O
estimated	O
future	O
cash	O
flows	O
are	O
discounted	O
to	O
their	O
present	O
value	O
using	O
a	O
pre-tax	O
discount	O
rate	O
that	O
reflects	O
current	O
market	O
assessments	O
of	O
the	O
time	O
value	O
of	O
money	O
and	O
the	O
risks	O
specific	O
to	O
the	O
asset.	O

In	O
determining	O
fair	O
value	O
less	O
costs	O
of	O
disposal	O
,	O
recent	O
market	O
transactions	O
are	O
taken	O
into	O
account.	O

If	O
no	O
such	O
transactions	O
can	O
be	O
identified	O
,	O
an	O
appropriate	O
valuation	O
model	O
is	O
used.	O

These	O
calculations	O
are	O
corroborated	O
by	O
valuation	O
multiples	O
,	O
quoted	O
shares	O
prices	O
for	O
publicly	O
traded	O
companies	O
or	O
other	O
available	O
fair	O
value	O
indicators.	O

(	O
s	O
)	O
Trade	O
and	O
other	O
payables	O
These	O
amounts	O
represent	O
liabilities	O
for	O
goods	O
and	O
services	O
provided	O
to	O
the	O
Group	O
prior	O
to	O
the	O
end	O
of	O
the	O
financial	O
year	O
and	O
which	O
are	O
unpaid.	O

Due	O
to	O
their	O
short-term	O
nature	O
they	O
are	O
measured	O
at	O
amortised	O
cost	O
and	O
are	O
not	O
discounted.	O

The	O
amounts	O
are	O
unsecured	O
and	O
are	O
usually	O
paid	O
within	O
30	O
days	O
of	O
recognition.	O

(	O
t	O
)	O
Provisions	O
Provisions	O
are	O
recognised	O
when	O
the	O
Group	O
has	O
a	O
present	O
(	O

June	O
2021	O
Fair	O
value	O
is	O
measured	O
using	O
the	O
assumptions	O
that	O
market	O
participants	O
would	O
use	O
when	O
pricing	O
the	O
asset	O
or	O
liability	O
,	O
assuming	O
they	O
act	O
in	O
their	O
economic	O
best	O
interests.	O

For	O
non-financial	O
assets	O
,	O
the	O
fair	O
value	O
measurement	O
is	O
based	O
on	O
its	O
highest	O
and	O
best	O
use.	O

Valuation	O
techniques	O
that	O
are	O
appropriate	O
in	O
the	O
circumstances	O
and	O
for	O
which	O
sufficient	O
data	O
are	O
available	O
to	O
measure	O
fair	O
value	O
,	O
are	O
used	O
,	O
maximising	O
the	O
use	O
of	O
relevant	O
observable	O
inputs	O
and	O
minimising	O
the	O
use	O
of	O
unobservable	O
inputs.	O

Assets	O
and	O
liabilities	O
measured	O
at	O
fair	O
value	O
are	O
classified	O
into	O
three	O
levels	O
,	O
using	O
a	O
fair	O
value	O
hierarchy	O
that	O
reflects	O
the	O
significance	O
of	O
the	O
inputs	O
used	O
in	O
making	O
the	O
measurements.	O

Classifications	O
are	O
reviewed	O
at	O
each	O
reporting	O
date	O
and	O
transfers	O
between	O
levels	O
are	O
determined	O
based	O
on	O
a	O
reassessment	O
of	O
the	O
lowest	O
level	O
of	O
input	O
that	O
is	O
significant	O
to	O
the	O
fair	O
value	O
measurement.	O

For	O
recurring	O
and	O
non-recurring	O
fair	O
value	O
measurements	O
,	O
external	O
valuers	O
may	O
be	O
used	O
when	O
internal	O
expertise	O
is	O
either	O
not	O
available	O
or	O
when	O
the	O
valuation	O
is	O
deemed	O
to	O
be	O
significant.	O

External	O
valuers	O
are	O
selected	O
based	O
on	O
market	O
knowledge	O
and	O
reputation.	O

Where	O
there	O
is	O
a	O
significant	O
change	O
in	O
fair	O
value	O
of	O
an	O
asset	O
or	O
liability	O
from	O
one	O
period	O
to	O
another	O
,	O
an	O
analysis	O
is	O
undertaken	O
,	O
which	O
includes	O
a	O
verification	O
of	O
the	O
major	O
inputs	O
applied	O
in	O
the	O
latest	O
valuation	O
and	O
a	O
comparison	O
,	O
where	O
applicable	O
,	O
with	O
external	O
sources	O
of	O
data.	O

(	O
y	O
)	O
Earnings	O
per	O
share	O
Basic	O
earnings	O
per	O
share	O
Basic	O
earnings	O
per	O
share	O
is	O
determined	O
by	O
dividing	O
net	O
profit	O
or	O
loss	O
after	O
income	O
tax	O
attributable	O
to	O
members	O
of	O
the	O
Company	O
,	O
excluding	O
any	O
costs	O
of	O
servicing	O
equity	O
other	O
than	O
ordinary	O
shares	O
,	O
by	O
the	O
weighted	O
average	O
number	O
of	O
ordinary	O
shares	O
outstanding	O
during	O
the	O
financial	O
year	O
,	O
adjusted	O
for	O
bonus	O
elements	O
in	O
ordinary	O
shares	O
issued	O
during	O
the	O
year.	O

Diluted	O
earnings	O
per	O
share	O
Diluted	O
earnings	O
per	O
share	O
adjusts	O
the	O
figures	O
used	O
in	O
the	O
determination	O
of	O
basic	O
earnings	O
per	O
share	O
to	O
take	O
into	O
account	O
the	O
after	O
income	O
tax	O
effect	O
of	O
interest	O
and	O
other	O
financing	O
costs	O
associated	O
with	O
dilutive	O
potential	O
ordinary	O
shares	O
and	O
the	O
weighted	O
average	O
number	O
of	O
shares	O
assumed	O
to	O
have	O
been	O
issued	O
for	O
no	O
consideration	O
in	O
relation	O
to	O
dilutive	O
potential	O
ordinary	O
shares.	O

(	O
z	O
)	O
Compound	O
financial	O
instruments	O
Compound	O
financial	O
instruments	O
issued	O
by	O
the	O
Group	O
comprise	O
convertible	O
notes	O
denominated	O
in	O
AUD	O
that	O
can	O
be	O
converted	O
to	O
ordinary	O
shares	O
at	O
the	O
option	O
of	O
the	O
holder	O
,	O
when	O
the	O
number	O
of	O
shares	O
to	O
be	O
issued	O
is	O
fixed	O
and	O
does	O
not	O
vary	O
with	O
changes	O
in	O
fair	O
value.	O

The	O
liability	O
component	O
of	O
compound	O
financial	O
instruments	O
is	O
initially	O
recognised	O
at	O
the	O
fair	O
value	O
of	O
a	O
similar	O
liability	O
that	O
does	O
not	O
have	O
an	O
equity	O
conversion	O
option.	O

The	O
equity	O
component	O
is	O
initially	O
recognised	O
at	O
the	O
difference	O
between	O
the	O
fair	O
value	O
of	O
the	O
compound	O
financial	O
instrument	O
as	O
a	O
whole	O
and	O
the	O
fair	O
value	O
of	O
the	O
liability	O
component.	O

Any	O
directly	O
attributable	O
transaction	O
costs	O
are	O
allocated	O
to	O
the	O
liability	O
and	O
equity	O
components	O
in	O
proportion	O
to	O
their	O
initial	O
carrying	O
amounts.	O

Subsequent	O
to	O
initial	O
recognition	O
,	O
the	O
liability	O
component	O
of	O
a	O
compound	O
financial	O
instrument	O
is	O
measured	O
at	O
amortised	O
cost	O
using	O
the	O
effective	O
interest	O
method.	O

The	O
equity	O
component	O
of	O
a	O
compound	O
financial	O
instrument	O
is	O
not	O
remeasured.	O

Interest	O
related	O
to	O
the	O
financial	O
liability	O
is	O
recognised	O
in	O
profit	O
or	O
loss.	O

On	O
conversion	O
at	O
maturity	O
,	O
the	O
financial	O
liability	O
is	O
reclassified	O
to	O
equity	O
and	O
no	O
gain	O
or	O
loss	O
is	O
recognised.	O

De-recognition	O
of	O
financial	O
liabilities	O
The	O
Company	O
de-recognises	O
financial	O
liabilities	O
when	O
,	O
and	O
only	O
when	O
,	O
the	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
obligations	O
are	O
discharged	O
,	O
cancelled	O
or	O
they	O
expire.	O

The	O
difference	O
between	O
the	O
carrying	O
amount	O
of	O
the	O
financial	O
liability	O
derecognised	O
and	O
the	O
consideration	O
paid	O
and	O
payable	O
is	O
recognised	O
in	O
profit	O
or	O
loss.	O

economicextraction.Thelocation	O

Group	O
estimates	O
its	O
ore	O

information	O
compiled	O
by	O

to	O
interpret	O
the	O
geological	O
data.	O

of	O

reserves	O
is	O
based	O
on	O
factors	O
such	O
as	O
estimates	O
of	O

rates	O

in	O

sizeand	O

the	O
orebody.Changesinthereservesorresource	O
estimatesmay	O

valueofexplorationandevaluation	O

)	O

Provision	O
forsite	O
rehabilitation	O
(	O
Key	O
Estimate	O
)	O
In	O
accordance	O
with	O
the	O
Group	O
’	O
s	O
legal	O
requirements	O
,	O
provision	O
is	O
made	O
for	O

costs	O
of	O
future	O
restoration	O
and	O
rehabilitation	O
of	O
areas	O
from	O
which	O

resources	O
have	O
been	O
extracted.	O

The	O
provision	O
has	O
been	O
based	O
upon	O
the	O
levies	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
the	O
requirements	O
of	O
the	O
Government	O
of	O
Western	O
Australia	O
under	O
the	O
Mining	O
Rehabilitation	O

Act	O
2012	O
and	O
used	O
to	O

abandoned	O
mines.	O

Management	O
in	O
consultation	O
with	O
independent	O
external	O
advisors	O
has	O
concluded	O
that	O
this	O
basis	O
is	O
an	O
appropriate	O
basis	O
to	O
estimate	O
the	O
likely	O
actual	O
costs	O
to	O
rehabilitate	O
its	O
sites.	O

Any	O
change	O
in	O
the	O
restoration	O
provision	O
is	O
recorded	O
against	O
the	O
carrying	O
value	O
of	O
the	O
provision	O
and	O
the	O
related	O
asset	O
,	O
only	O
to	O

extent	O
that	O
it	O
is	O

that	O

with	O

will	O
flow	O
tothe	O
entity	O
,	O
with	O
theeffectbeing	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
incomestatement	O
on	O
a	O
prospective	O
basis	O
over	O
the	O
remaining	O

of	O
the	O
relevant	O
operation.	O

Capital	O
risk	O
management	O
The	O
consolidated	O

when	O

and	O

to	O

of	O
capital.	O

24.	O

Financial	O
instruments	O
Capital	O
is	O
regarded	O
as	O
total	O
equity	O
,	O
as	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
statement	O
of	O
financial	O
position	O
,	O
plus	O
net	O
debt.	O

is	O

as	O
total	O
borrowings	O
less	O
cash	O
and	O
cash	O
equivalents.	O

Financial	O
risk	O
management	O

entity	O

of	O

’	O

and	O

by	O
SARCO	O
in	O
Laos	O
and	O
since	O
1	O
October	O
2010	O
NFC	O
has	O
been	O
funding	O
ongoing	O
exploration	O
activities.	O

In	O
accordance	O
with	O
the	O
Joint	O
Venture	O
agreement	O
,	O
at	O
the	O
time	O
NFC	O
’	O
s	O
contribution	O
has	O
reached	O
the	O
level	O
of	O
the	O
company	O
’	O
s	O
initial	O
contribution	O
,	O
both	O
the	O
Company	O
and	O
NFC	O
are	O
obliged	O
to	O
contribute	O
their	O
respective	O
share	O
of	O
funding	O
requirements	O
for	O
any	O
further	O
activity.	O

An	O
audit	O
of	O
the	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
contributions	O
to	O
SARCO	O
JV	O
expenditures	O
from	O
inception	O
to	O
30	O
September	O
2009	O
was	O
performed	O
by	O
NFC	O
in	O
2012.	O

completion	O
NFC	O
challenged	O
a	O
total	O
of	O
$1.1	O
million	O
in	O
expenditure	O
that	O
is	O
currently	O
included	O
as	O
part	O

total	O
Company	O

the	O

although	O

claim	O

been	O

NFC.	O

dispute	O
is	O
$1	O
,	O
109	O
,	O
000	O
which	O
forms	O
the	O
contingent	O

has	O

to	O
audit	O
the	O
NFC	O
contributions.	O

this	O
time	O

NFC.	O

Other	O
Information	O
The	O
directors	O
are	O
responsible	O
for	O
the	O
other	O
information.	O

The	O
other	O
information	O
comprises	O
the	O
information	O
included	O
in	O
the	O
Group's	O
annual	O
report	O
for	O
the	O
year	O
ended	O
30	O
June	O
2021	O

but	O
does	O
not	O
include	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
and	O
the	O
auditor's	O
report	O
thereon.	O

Our	O
opinion	O
on	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
does	O
not	O
cover	O
the	O
other	O
information	O
and	O
accordingly	O
we	O
do	O
not	O
express	O
any	O
form	O
of	O
assurance	O
conclusion	O
thereon.	O

In	O
connection	O
with	O
our	O
audit	O
of	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
,	O
our	O
responsibility	O
is	O
to	O
read	O
the	O
other	O
information	O
and	O
,	O
in	O
doing	O
so	O
,	O
consider	O
whether	O
the	O
other	O
information	O
is	O
materially	O
inconsistent	O
with	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
or	O
our	O
knowledge	O
obtained	O
in	O
the	O
audit	O
or	O
otherwise	O
appears	O
to	O
be	O
materially	O
misstated.	O

If	O
,	O
based	O
on	O
the	O
work	O
we	O
have	O
performed	O
,	O
we	O
conclude	O
that	O
there	O
is	O
a	O
material	O
misstatement	O
of	O
this	O
other	O
information	O
,	O
we	O
are	O
required	O
to	O
report	O
that	O
fact.	O

We	O
have	O
nothing	O
to	O
report	O
in	O
this	O
regard.	O

Responsibilities	O
of	O
the	O
Directors	O
for	O
the	O
Financial	O
Report	O
The	O
directors	O
of	O
the	O
Company	O
are	O
responsible	O
for	O
the	O
preparation	O
of	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
that	O
gives	O
a	O
true	O
and	O
fair	O
view	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
Australian	O
Accounting	O
Standards	O
and	O
the	O
Corporations	O
Act	O
2001	O
and	O
for	O
such	O
internal	O
control	O
as	O
the	O
directors	O
determine	O
is	O
necessary	O
to	O
enable	O
the	O
preparation	O
of	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
that	O
gives	O
a	O
true	O
and	O
fair	O
view	O
and	O
is	O
free	O
from	O
material	O
misstatement	O
,	O
whether	O
due	O
to	O
fraud	O
or	O
error.	O

In	O
preparing	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
,	O
the	O
directors	O
are	O
responsible	O
for	O
assessing	O
the	O
ability	O
of	O
the	O
Group	O
to	O
continue	O
as	O
a	O
going	O
concern	O
,	O
disclosing	O
,	O
as	O
applicable	O
,	O
matters	O
related	O
to	O
going	O
concern	O
and	O
using	O
the	O
going	O
concern	O
basis	O
of	O
accounting	O
unless	O
the	O
directors	O
either	O
intend	O
to	O
liquidate	O
the	O
Group	O
or	O
to	O
cease	O
operations	O
,	O
or	O
have	O
no	O
realistic	O
alternative	O
but	O
to	O
do	O
so.	O

93	O
94	O
Vango	O
Mining	O
Limited	O
Annual	O
Report	O
2020	O
Independent	O
Auditor	O
’	O
s	O
Report	O
continued	O
Auditor's	O
Responsibilities	O
for	O
the	O
Audit	O
of	O
the	O
Financial	O
Report	O
Our	O
objectives	O
are	O
to	O
obtain	O
reasonable	O
assurance	O
about	O
whether	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
as	O
a	O
whole	O
is	O
free	O
from	O
material	O
misstatement	O
,	O
whether	O
due	O
to	O
fraud	O
or	O
error	O
,	O
and	O
to	O
issue	O
an	O
auditor's	O
report	O
that	O
includes	O
our	O
opinion.	O

Reasonable	O
assurance	O
is	O
a	O
high	O
level	O
of	O
assurance	O
,	O
but	O
is	O
not	O
a	O
guarantee	O
that	O
an	O
audit	O
conducted	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
the	O
Australian	O
Auditing	O
Standards	O
will	O
always	O
detect	O
a	O
material	O
misstatement	O
when	O
it	O
exists.	O

Misstatements	O
can	O
arise	O
from	O
fraud	O
or	O
error	O
and	O
are	O
considered	O
material	O
if	O
,	O
individually	O
or	O
in	O
the	O
aggregate	O
,	O
they	O
could	O
reasonably	O
be	O
expected	O
to	O
influence	O
the	O
economic	O
decisions	O
of	O
users	O
taken	O
on	O
the	O
basis	O
of	O
this	O
financial	O
report.	O

A	O
further	O
description	O
of	O
our	O
responsibilities	O
for	O
the	O
audit	O
of	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
is	O
located	O
at	O
the	O
Auditing	O
and	O
Assurance	O
Standards	O
Board	O
website	O
at	O
:	O
https	O
:	O
This	O
description	O
forms	O
part	O
of	O
our	O
auditor's	O
report.	O

Report	O
on	O
the	O
Remuneration	O
Report	O
Opinion	O
on	O
the	O
Remuneration	O
Report	O
We	O
have	O
audited	O
the	O
Remuneration	O
Report	O
included	O
in	O
pages	O
20	O
to	O
26	O
of	O
the	O
directors'	O
report	O
for	O
the	O
year	O
ended	O
30	O
June	O
2021.	O

In	O
our	O
opinion	O
,	O
the	O
Remuneration	O
Report	O
of	O
Vango	O
Mining	O
Limited.	O

,	O
for	O
the	O
year	O
ended	O
30	O
June	O
2021	O
complies	O
with	O
section	O
300A	O
of	O
the	O
Corporations	O
Act	O
2001.	O

Responsibilities	O
The	O
directors	O
of	O
the	O
Company	O
are	O
responsible	O
for	O
the	O
preparation	O
and	O
presentation	O
of	O
the	O
Remuneration	O
Report	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
section	O
300A	O
of	O
the	O
Corporations	O
Act	O
2001.	O

Our	O
responsibility	O
is	O
to	O
express	O
an	O
opinion	O
on	O
the	O
Remuneration	O
Report	O
,	O
based	O
on	O
our	O
audit	O

in	O

Australian	O

Standards.	O

RSM	O
Australia	O

N	O
Sherwood	O
Partner	O
Sydney	O
,	O
NSW	O
Dated	O
:	O
30	O
September	O
2021	O
94	O
Vango	O
Mining	O
Limited	O
Annual	O
Report	O
2021	O
95	O
Shareholder	O
and	O
Investor	O
Information	O
Quoted	O
Shares	O
Subject	O
to	O
any	O
rights	O
or	O
restrictions	O
for	O
the	O
time	O
being	O
attached	O
to	O
any	O
class	O
or	O
classes	O
of	O
shares	O
,	O
at	O
meetings	O
of	O
shareholders	O
or	O
classes	O
of	O
shareholders	O
:	O
a.	O

each	O
shareholder	O
entitled	O
to	O
vote	O
may	O
vote	O
in	O
person	O
or	O
by	O
proxy	O
,	O
attorney	O
or	O
representative	O
;	O
b.	O

on	O
a	O
show	O
of	O
hands	O
,	O
every	O
person	O
present	O
who	O
is	O
a	O
shareholder	O
or	O
a	O
proxy	O
,	O
attorney	O
or	O
representative	O
of	O
a	O
Shareholder	O
has	O
one	O
vote	O
(	O
even	O
though	O
he	O
or	O
she	O
may	O
represent	O
more	O
than	O
one	O
member	O
)	O
;	O
and	O
c.	O

on	O
a	O
poll	O
,	O
every	O
person	O
present	O
who	O
is	O
a	O
shareholder	O
or	O
a	O
proxy	O
,	O
attorney	O
or	O
representative	O
of	O
a	O
shareholder	O
shall	O
,	O
in	O
respect	O
of	O
each	O
fully	O
paid	O
share	O
held	O
by	O
him	O
,	O
or	O
in	O
respect	O
of	O
which	O
he	O
is	O
appointed	O
a	O
proxy	O
,	O
attorney	O
or	O
representative	O
,	O
have	O
one	O
vote	O
for	O
the	O
share	O
,	O
but	O
in	O
respect	O
of	O
partly	O
paid	O
shares	O
,	O
shall	O
have	O
such	O
number	O
of	O
votes	O
being	O
equivalent	O
to	O
the	O
proportion	O
which	O
the	O
amount	O
paid	O
(	O
not	O
credited	O
)	O
is	O
of	O
the	O
total	O
amounts	O
paid	O
and	O
payable	O
in	O
respect	O
of	O
those	O
shares	O
(	O
excluding	O
amounts	O
credited	O
)	O
.	O

Options	O

the	O
right	O
for	O
the	O
option	O
holder	O
to	O
be	O
issued	O
one	O
fully	O
paid	O
share	O
by	O
the	O
Company	O

of	O

exercise	O
price	O
of	O
each	O
option.	O

Forward-Looking	O
Statements	O

statements.	O

Forward-looking	O
statements	O
may	O
generally	O
be	O
identified	O
by	O
the	O
use	O
of	O
forward-looking	O
verbs	O
such	O

,	O

plans	O
,	O
projects	O
,	O

,	O
estimates	O
,	O
envisages	O
,	O
potential	O
,	O
possible	O
,	O
strategy	O
,	O
goals	O
,	O
objectives	O
,	O
or	O
variations	O
thereof	O
or	O

that	O
certain	O
actions	O
,	O

or	O
results	O
may	O
,	O

,	O
would	O
,	O

,	O

of	O

which	O

only	O

are	O

Actual	O

to	O

Sandstone	O
Project	O
JORC	O
(	O
2012	O
)	O
Section	O
1	O
Sampling	O
Techniques	O
and	O
Data	O

Item	O
Comments	O
Sampling	O
•	O

2020	O
RC	O
drilling	O
by	O
Alto	O
Metals	O
Ltd	O
used	O
similar	O
sampling	O
techniques	O
as	O
Troy	O
Resources	O
,	O
except	O
a	O
techniques	O
for	O
a	O
4	O
metre	O
composite	O
sample	O
being	O
collected	O
for	O
laboratory	O
assay.	O

•	O

From	O
the	O
bulk	O
1m	O
sample	O
,	O
a	O
4	O
metre	O
composite	O
sample	O
was	O
collected	O
using	O
a	O
split	O
PVC	O
scoop	O
and	O
then	O
submitted	O
to	O
the	O
laboratory	O
for	O
analysis.	O

•	O

RC	O
1m	O
splits	O
were	O
submitted	O
(	O
2016	O
and	O
2019	O
RC	O
program	O
)	O
or	O
are	O
to	O
be	O
submitted	O
(	O
the	O
current	O
2020	O
RC	O
program	O
)	O
to	O
the	O
laboratory	O
if	O
the	O
composite	O
sample	O
assay	O
values	O
are	O
equal	O
to	O
or	O
greater	O
than	O
0.2g/t	O
Au.	O

•	O

All	O
drilling	O
up	O
to	O
2010	O
was	O
carried	O
out	O
by	O
Troy	O
Resources	O
NL	O
(	O
Troy	O
)	O
.	O

•	O

Troy	O
’	O
s	O
RC	O
samples	O
were	O
passed	O
directly	O
from	O
the	O
in-line	O
cyclone	O
through	O
a	O
rig	O
mounted	O
multi-tier	O
riffle	O
splitter.	O

Samples	O
were	O
collected	O
in	O
1	O
m	O
intervals	O
into	O
bulk	O
plastic	O
bags	O
and	O
1	O
m	O
calico	O
splits	O
(	O
which	O
were	O
retained	O
for	O
later	O
use	O
)	O
.	O

•	O

From	O
the	O
bulk	O
sample	O
,	O
a	O
5	O
m	O
composite	O
sample	O
was	O
collected	O
using	O
a	O
split	O
PVC	O
scoop	O
and	O
then	O
submitted	O
to	O
the	O
laboratory	O
for	O
analysis.	O

The	O
1	O
m	O
calico	O
splits	O
were	O
submitted	O
to	O
the	O
laboratory	O
if	O
the	O
composite	O
sample	O
returned	O
assay	O
values	O
equal	O
to	O
or	O
greater	O
than	O
0.2	O
g/t	O
Au.	O

In	O
certain	O
cases	O
,	O
selected	O
samples	O
from	O
some	O
holes	O
were	O
passed	O
from	O
the	O
cyclone	O
through	O
a	O
rig	O
mounted	O
multi-tier	O
riffle	O
splitter	O
,	O
and	O
samples	O
collected	O
into	O
calico	O
bags	O
at	O
1	O
m	O
intervals	O
were	O
submitted	O
directly	O
for	O
analyses.	O

The	O
remaining	O
bulk	O
sample	O
was	O
placed	O
on	O
the	O
ground	O
in	O
1	O
m	O
intervals.	O

•	O

Diamond	O
cores	O
were	O
marked	O
on	O
the	O
core	O
by	O
the	O
geologist	O
according	O
to	O
geological	O
intervals.	O

The	O
core	O
was	O
cut	O
in	O
half	O
by	O
Troy	O
field	O
technicians	O
,	O
with	O
half	O
being	O
placed	O
in	O
a	O
pre-numbered	O
calico	O
bag	O
and	O
the	O
other	O
half	O
returned	O
to	O
the	O
core	O
tray.	O

For	O
duplicate	O
samples	O
the	O
core	O
to	O
be	O
submitted	O
for	O
analysis	O
is	O
quartered.	O

Drilling	O
•	O

Alto	O
’	O
s	O
2019	O
RC	O
drilling	O
program	O
used	O
a	O
KWL	O
350	O
drill	O
rig	O
with	O
an	O
onboard	O
1100/350	O
compressor	O
techniques	O
using	O
a	O
sampling	O
hammer	O
of	O
nominal	O
140mm	O
hole.	O

•	O

The	O
2017	O
Mineral	O
Resource	O
Estimate	O
for	O
Lord	O
Nelson	O
was	O
based	O
on	O
260	O
reverse	O
circulation	O
(	O
RC	O
)	O
and	O
18	O
diamond	O
drill	O
holes	O
(	O
DDH	O
)	O
and	O
18	O
rotary	O
air	O
blast	O
(	O
RAB	O
)	O
drill	O
holes.	O

RAB	O
drill	O
holes	O
were	O
used	O
to	O
guide	O
mineralisation	O
interpretation	O
and	O
excluded	O
for	O
estimation	O
purposes.	O

•	O

For	O
diamond	O
drilling	O
,	O
triple	O
tube	O
coring	O
was	O
used	O
due	O
to	O
the	O
friable	O
nature	O
of	O
the	O
oxide	O
zone	O
lithologies	O
being	O
drilled.	O

The	O
angled	O
core	O
holes	O
were	O
orientated	O
where	O
possible	O
using	O
a	O
crayon	O
marker	O
spear	O
tool	O
and	O
the	O
holes	O
were	O
regularly	O
surveyed	O
using	O
an	O
Eastman	O
downhole	O
camera.	O

Due	O
to	O
the	O
deeply	O
weathered	O
,	O
soft	O
and	O
friable	O
nature	O
of	O
the	O
core	O
,	O
most	O
of	O
the	O
orientations	O
either	O
failed	O
or	O
could	O
not	O
be	O
pieced	O
together	O
over	O
any	O
useful	O
continuous	O
lengths.	O

Drill	O
sample	O
•	O

For	O
Alto	O
’	O
s	O
2020	O
drilling	O
program	O
,	O
RC	O
samples	O
generally	O
had	O
good	O
recovery.	O

recovery	O
•	O

Recovery	O
was	O
estimated	O
as	O
a	O
percentage	O
and	O
recorded	O
on	O
field	O
sheets	O
prior	O
to	O
entry	O
into	O
the	O
database.	O

•	O

Snowden	O
has	O
no	O
quantitative	O
information	O
on	O
sample	O
recovery	O
for	O
TRC	O
holes.	O

•	O

Review	O
of	O
the	O
available	O
DDH	O
core	O
in	O
the	O
core	O
yard	O
shows	O
generally	O
good	O
recovery.	O

Logging	O
•	O

Alto	O
’	O
s	O
RC	O
drill	O
chips	O
were	O
sieved	O
from	O
each	O
1m	O
sample	O
and	O
geologically	O
logged.	O

•	O

Washed	O
drill	O
chips	O

3kg	O

Alto	O
’	O
s	O
4m	O

•	O

About	O
the	O
MinAnalytical	O
Photon	O
Assay	O
Analysis	O
Technique	O
:	O
Developed	O
by	O
CSIRO	O
and	O
the	O
Chrysos	O
Corporation	O
,	O
the	O
Photon	O
Assay	O
technique	O
is	O
a	O
fast	O
o	O

and	O
chemical	O
free	O
alternative	O
to	O
the	O
traditional	O
fire	O
assay	O
process	O
and	O
utilizes	O
high	O
energy	O
x-rays.	O

The	O
process	O
is	O
nondestructive	O
on	O
and	O
utilises	O
a	O
significantly	O
larger	O
sample	O
than	O
the	O
conventional	O
50g	O
fire	O
assay.	O

MinAnalytical	O
has	O
thoroughly	O
tested	O
and	O
validated	O
the	O
Photon	O
Assay	O
process	O
with	O
o	O

results	O
benchmarked	O
against	O
conventional	O
fire	O
assay.	O

The	O
National	O
Association	O
of	O
Testing	O
Authorities	O
(	O
NATA	O
)	O
,	O
Australia	O
’	O
s	O
national	O
o	O

accreditation	O
body	O
for	O
laboratories	O
,	O
has	O
issued	O
MinAnalytical	O
with	O
accreditation	O
for	O
the	O
technique	O
in	O
compliance	O
with	O
ISO/IEC	O
17025	O
:	O
2018-Testing.	O

•	O

Subsequently	O
,	O
intervals	O
of	O
4m	O
composite	O
samples	O
reporting	O
greater	O
than	O
0.2g/t	O
Au	O
were	O
selected	O
for	O

,	O
and	O
1m	O

samples	O
were	O
submitted	O
(	O

)	O
for	O
50gm	O
fire	O
assay.	O

to	O

•	O

Geological	O
and	O
mineralised	O
structures	O
have	O
been	O
interpreted	O
from	O
RC	O
drilling.	O

structure	O
•	O

Previous	O
mapping	O
in	O
the	O
area	O
indicates	O
that	O
there	O
are	O
west-northwest	O
striking	O
veins	O
and	O
a	O

of	O

at	O
Lord	O
Nelson	O
which	O
are	O
oblique	O
to	O
this	O
north-	O
northwest	O
trend	O
of	O
the	O
mineralised	O
interpretation.	O

This	O
suggests	O
that	O
within	O
the	O
ore	O
zone	O
the	O
sheeted	O
veins	O
may	O
produce	O
sub-horizontal	O
shoots	O
oriented	O
west-northwest.	O

Sample	O
•	O

For	O

Geology	O
•	O

The	O
Lord	O
Nelson	O
deposit	O
occurs	O
along	O
the	O
north-south	O
trending	O
Trafalgar	O
shear	O
zone.	O

•	O

The	O
Lord	O
Nelson	O
deposit	O
is	O
hosted	O
within	O
a	O
zone	O
of	O
intermixed	O
high-magnesium	O
basalt	O
and	O
granodiorite	O
intrusive	O
rocks	O
above	O
a	O
footwall	O
ultramafic	O
unit.	O

The	O
mineralisation	O
trends	O
north-	O
north-west	O
,	O
dipping	O
approximately	O
50	O
°	O

to	O
the	O
west	O
increasing	O
to	O
70	O
°	O

with	O
depth.	O

The	O
main	O
eastern	O
lode	O
is	O
a	O
zone	O
of	O
pyrite	O
+	O
silica	O
+	O
biotite	O
+/-	O
quartz	O
veining	O
that	O
follows	O
the	O
ultramafic	O
footwall	O
contact.	O

West-northwest	O
striking	O
veins	O
and	O
a	O
sheeted	O
swarm	O
of	O
granodiorite	O
intrusions	O
at	O
Lord	O
Nelson	O
are	O
oblique	O
to	O
the	O
north-northwest	O
trend	O
of	O
the	O
ore	O
envelope	O
inferred	O
from	O
drilling.	O

This	O
suggests	O
that	O
within	O
the	O
ore	O
zone	O
the	O
sheeted	O
veins	O
may	O
produce	O
sub-horizontal	O
shoots	O
oriented	O
west	O
northwest.	O

•	O

The	O
interpreted	O
mineralisation	O
domains	O
are	O
based	O
on	O
a	O
nominal	O
0.2	O
g/t	O
Au	O
to	O
0.3	O
g/t	O
Au	O
cut-	O
off	O
which	O
appears	O
to	O
be	O
a	O
natural	O
break	O
in	O
the	O
grade	O
distribution.	O

hole	O

Au	O

methods	O

Geological	O
•	O

that	O
the	O

interpretation	O
•	O

The	O
interpreted	O
mineralisation	O
domains	O
are	O
based	O
on	O
a	O
nominal	O
0.2	O
g/t	O
Au	O
to	O
0.3	O
g/t	O
Au	O
cut-off	O
which	O
appears	O
to	O
be	O
a	O
natural	O
break	O
in	O
the	O
grade	O
distribution.	O

The	O
interpreted	O
domains	O
include	O
:	O
−	O

Eastern	O
mineralisation	O
–	O

main	O
ultramafic	O
contact	O
:	O
A	O
continuous	O
domain	O
of	O
mineralisation	O
which	O
runs	O
along	O
the	O
ultramafic	O
to	O
intermediate	O
contact	O
on	O
the	O
eastern	O
edge	O
of	O
the	O
deposit.	O

−	O

Eastern	O
mineralisation	O
–	O

southern	O
extension	O
:	O
Poorly	O
informed	O
extension	O
to	O
the	O
main	O
ultramafic	O
contact	O
domain.	O

−	O

Western	O
mineralisation	O
:	O
A	O
continuous	O
domain	O
of	O
mineralisation	O
on	O
the	O
western	O
edge	O
of	O
the	O
deposit.	O

−	O

Central	O
,	O
disconnected	O
mineralisation	O
:	O
A	O
series	O
of	O
less	O
continuous	O
mineralised	O
pods	O
between	O
the	O
two	O
main	O
domains	O
,	O
with	O
the	O
larger	O
areas	O
potentially	O
related	O
to	O
west-northwest	O
structures.	O

−	O

Flat	O
lying	O
near	O
surface	O
mineralisation	O
:	O
A	O
lower	O
grade	O
flat	O
lying	O
,	O
near	O
surface	O
domain	O
overlying	O
the	O
main	O
mineralisation.	O

A	O
second	O
flat	O
lying	O
,	O
near	O
surface	O
domain	O
lies	O
to	O
the	O
east	O
in	O
an	O
area	O
which	O
is	O
poorly	O
drilled	O
at	O
depth.	O

This	O
eastern	O
near	O
surface	O
domain	O
indicates	O
potential	O
for	O
a	O
repeat	O
of	O
the	O
Lord	O
Nelson	O
mineralisation	O
and	O
is	O
a	O
target	O
for	O
further	O
exploration.	O

•	O

Alternative	O
interpretations	O
of	O
the	O
mineralisation	O
are	O
unlikely	O
to	O
significantly	O
change	O
the	O
overall	O
volume	O
of	O
the	O
mineralised	O
envelopes	O
in	O
terms	O
of	O
the	O
reported	O
classified	O
resources.	O

Dimensions	O
•	O

The	O
Lord	O
Nelson	O
gold	O
mineralisation	O
covers	O
an	O
area	O
of	O
around	O
750	O
m	O
along	O
strike	O
by	O
400	O
m	O
across	O
strike	O
and	O
extends	O
to	O
over	O
200	O
m	O
below	O
surface.	O

The	O
mineralisation	O
interpretation	O
extends	O
around	O
150	O
m	O
down	O
dip	O
from	O
the	O
base	O
of	O
the	O
current	O
pit.	O

•	O

The	O
mineralisation	O
is	O
open	O
in	O
all	O
directions.	O

There	O
is	O
a	O
second	O
near	O
surface	O
mineralised	O
domain	O
to	O
the	O
east	O
of	O
the	O
area	O
reported	O
above	O
,	O
which	O
is	O
poorly	O
drilled	O
at	O
depth.	O

This	O
eastern	O
near	O
